column2: Raffaello Pantucci;2021-04-30 21:00:00;full;https://www.straitstimes.com/opinion/bumps-on-the-digital-silk-road;straitstimes.com;Opinion News -Chinese tech giants are superb builders but feared for their prowess and government links. But what if the greater risk lies in these firms themselves?. Read more at straitstimes.com.;"At the height of the Sino-Indian Himalayan border clash last year
column3: New Delhi suddenly slapped a ban on dozens of Chinese mobile phone apps on security grounds. Most prominent among them was TikTok
column4: the video-sharing app which has taken the world's teenagers by storm.The Indian ban came amid a wider wave of pushback against China's digital and technology companies
column5: led by the United States but taking effect globally in different ways
column6: creating bumps in the building of China's Digital Silk Road (DSR).

column1: 1;Commentary: Will Biden and G7's infrastructure partnership counter China's Belt and Road?;Stefanie Kam;2022-07-17 22:07:00;full;https://www.channelnewsasia.com/commentary/us-china-g7-infrastructure-belt-road-digital-green-2812941;channelnewsasia.com;United States and G7 leaders launched the Partnership for Global Infrastructure and Investment at their Germany summit as an alternative to China's Belt and Road Initiative
column2: but this competition may…;"Commentary United States and G7 leaders launched the Partnership for Global Infrastructure and Investment at their Germany summit as an alternative to China's Belt and Road Initiative
column3: but this competition may pave the way for more sustainable infrastructure development
column4: says RSIS' Stefanie Kam. 18 Jul 2022 06:07AM (Updated: 18 Jul 2022 06:06AM) SINGAPORE: In June
column5: United States President Joe Biden and the other Group of Seven (G7) leaders launched the Partnership for Global Infrastructure and Investment (PGII) at their summit – a US$600 billion commitment to finance the construction of global infrastructure by 2027. Much focus
column6: of course
column7: has been on how PGII will be an alternative mechanism to China's multitrillion-dollar Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)
column8: launched almost 10 years ago as a modern-day Silk Road stretching from East Asia to Europe and Africa. PGII is not exactly new: It is a repackaged version of the Build Back Better World (B3W) initiative the G7 proposed a year ago with the same aim to counter China's growing influence
column9: especially in developing countries. Biden stressed the PGII's tangible and political dimensions when he emphasised that it will not only 'deliver returns for everyone"" but would also allow countries to ""see the concrete benefits of partnering with democracies"". PGII RESPONSE TO EMERGING CHALLENGES LIKE CLIMATE AND ENERGY Why now? At first glance
column10: PGII may look better positioned to respond to emerging challenges of a world that has changed in the near-decade since BRI began. It aims to focus on climate and energy security and the development of soft infrastructure in the digital economy
column11: among other things. Flagship projects include a US$600 million global submarine telecommunications cable connecting Singapore to France through Egypt and the Horn of Africa; a US$40 million investment (and expected to mobilise US$2 billion in further investments) in Southeast Asia's Smart Power Program to accelerate rollout of clean energy technologies; and a US$2 billion solar project in southern Angola.

column1: The sprawling Belt and Road Initiative is the flagship of Xi Jinping's geostrategic vision for the Asia-Pacific region. AFP/Aidan JONES
The PGII will find a receptive audience in this region
column2: given the ever-growing appetite for infrastructure among Southeast Asian countries. Digital infrastructure is particularly important as a key part of ASEAN's digital masterplan is to technologically transform member states into a digital economy and a digital society by 2025. According to a recent Google-led survey
column3: ASEAN's digital economy is on track to grow to US$1 trillion by 2030
column4: particularly in e-commerce and virtual finance domains. Given Southeast Asia's severe vulnerability to climate change
column5: green infrastructure is another area of interest. ASEAN states signed the 2015 Paris Agreement and its Community Vision 2025 specifically recognised the complementarity between the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and ASEAN's community-building endeavours. South Korean manufacturing giants who have shifted their operations from China in recent years and to other countries
column6: like Vietnam
column7: may also view the PGII investments in a positive light
column8: as it would provide a more favourable business climate and investor outlook. CHINA PIVOT TO DIGITAL AND HEALTH SILK ROAD China's efforts to build and link up road
column9: rail and maritime port connections to facilitate trade in economic corridors are often thought of when it comes to BRI. But lockdowns and border closures in many BRI countries during the COVID-19 pandemic has led to a slowdown in infrastructure projects. This accelerated China's pivot from hard to soft infrastructure investment projects
column10: leading to an increase in focus on the Digital Silk Road (DSR)
column11: and health diplomacy vis-à-vis the Health Silk Road (HSR). The HSR
column12: interlinked with DSR
column13: has emerged as a vehicle for promoting international development cooperation amid the global pandemic
column14: and is evident in China's involvement in the Middle East and North Africa region through medicine and vaccine diplomacy.

column1: The DSR was introduced in 2015 to support the expansion and internationalisation of its technology companies
column2: with investments from the 'development of the digital service sector
column3: such as cross-border e-commerce
column4: smart cities
column5: telemedicine
column6: and internet finance
column8: big data
column9: Internet of Things
column10: artificial intelligence
column11: blockchain and quantum computing.' A key aspect of Beijing's technological cooperation with Southeast Asian countries is in information and telecommunication technologies (ICT). Through the DSR
column12: Beijing has invested in ICT-focused telecommunications and digital infrastructure
column13: as well as fibre optic terrestrial and submarine cable networks in this region.  CAN G7 PARTNERSHIP COUNTER BELT AND ROAD? Both initiatives will face challenges in governance and navigating local regulations in recipient countries. Here
column14: the Chinese approach may work in the BRI's favour. As one of Chinese President Xi Jinping's most ambitious international projects
column15: BRI benefits from the straightforward processes of a strong central government in terms of policies and resources. But in practice
column16: Chinese players have encountered challenges on the ground
column17: and have had to become more sensitive and adaptable to local conditions and more mindful of local politics. The increased capital investments can have enormous consequences on the host countries
column18: including exacerbating competition among power elites on a micro-level. On the flip side
column19: the Western approach to investments which tends towards more formalistic application of a uniform set of rules at the three levels of international or bilateral cooperation
column20: domestic regulation and private transactions could end up a strength
column21: as it lends potential to building a more uniform and common approach to global infrastructure standards financed by PGII.

column1: Without the same top-down structures as BRI
column2: PGII will need to mobilise both public and private resources across seven countries. This could get messy though it is yet unclear how G7 nations will share the risks and responsibilities and agree on the metrics for measuring success. Equally important to the issue of whether the PGII will be a primarily US-led initiative or a G7 (though US-fronted) affair
column3: is the issue of optics. At a time where American primacy appears to be in decline
column4: the PGII will serve to facilitate the US' soft power projection abroad. HEALTHY COMPETITION? It is too early to tell if PGII can counter BRI as a contrasting model of development. But as PGII pushes to gain ground
column5: BRI will not stand still either. Competition heating up may be very well what is needed to incentivise Beijing to push for more reforms
column6: to strengthen the quality of existing investment projects and to reform institutions and policies in two particular areas - emerging technologies and green financing. Through its China Standards 2035
column7: Beijing has ambitions to set global standards for emerging technologies in areas such as artificial intelligence and advanced communications technology. For Beijing
column8: the BRI has served as a conduit for making its own companies more competitive against American and other rivals internationally
column9: particularly in the area of technology standards.

column1: Another example is the Green Development Finance (GDF)
column2: developed by the Belt and Road Initiative International Green Development Coalition (BRIGC). The GDF's primary goal is to encourage Chinese financiers and infrastructure developers to voluntarily select BRI projects with low environmental risks. The emergence of PGII may very well yield positive dividends for global governance
column3: the outcomes which may not necessarily lead to a further bifurcation of the world in terms of bipolar opposites. Instead
column4: it has the potential to pave the way for more sustainable infrastructural development. Stefanie Kam is Associate Research Fellow at the S Rajaratnam School of International Studies at Nanyang Technological University.

column1: 3;Ecommerce development and initiatives in Malaysia and China;Search Scholar Series;2022-04-25 10:49:00;timezone unknown;https://www.thestar.com.my/opinion/columnists/search-scholar-series/2022/04/25/ecommerce-development-and-initiatives-in-malaysia-and-china;thestar.com.my;ECOMMERCE is transcending conventional trade and retail by reaching out to consumers not only in their homes but also across borders. It provides vast opportunities and geographic reach to both…;ECOMMERCE is transcending conventional trade and retail by reaching out to consumers not only in their homes but also across borders. It provides vast opportunities and geographic reach to both established businesses and new enterprises. On a macro level
column2: ecommerce is reshaping global trade. The Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the adoption of ecommerce and digital transformation. Consumers have resorted to ecommerce to meet their shopping needs. As a result
column3: ecommerce has become an important factor in domestic markets – supply and distribution of goods and services increasingly revolve around ecommerce. This is seen particularly in the rise of the gig economy – ehailing and delivery services have benefited greatly despite business closures and rising unemployment. Businesses that adopted ecommerce are also better equipped to mitigate the impact of lockdown. Ecommerce has brought new opportunities
column4: but also brought to light the importance of addressing existing barriers. As international trade has promoted economic growth and exchanges between countries in the past
column5: today ecommerce also provides opportunities for greater cooperation and economic growth between China and Malaysia. Ecommerce in Malaysia The Malaysian government has attempted to facilitate digitalisation with the myDigital initiative and Malaysia Digital Economy Blueprint. The government sees digital economy as an important contributor to the nation economy
column6: and it has focused on accelerating the country's progress through digitalisation
column7: while ensuring that no Malaysian gets left behind. In the private sector
column8: ecommerce platforms like Lazada
column9: Grab and Shopee enabled small businesses
column10: and even micro-businesses
column11: to open with minimal start-up costs and compete in global markets. Even though ecommerce in Malaysia is relatively robust
column12: room for improvement remains. Challenges exist in adoption of new digital tools
column13: cybersecurity threats
column14: digital marketing skills
column15: restricted production capacity
column16: high logistic cost
column17: and absence of knowledge regarding market access and rules in cross-border ecommerce. Other barriers include broadband services
column19: lack of consumers' trust
column20: poor digital skills among the population
column21: and lack of government support. International standards can play in enhancing national digital resilience and building trust in ecommerce. In this
column22: concrete initiatives are needed
column23: such as ecommerce willingness assessments and strategy formulation
column24: information and communications technology (ICT) infrastructure and services
column25: access to financing for ecommerce
column26: ecommerce skills development
column27: and empowering entrepreneurs in developing countries. What China has done in ecommerce
column28: and how Malaysia can learn from it. Leading Internet corporations are growing their ecommerce arm and mobile payment services
column29: especially in and South and Southeast Asia. Alibaba has been setting up logistic centres in key markets
column30: including Malaysia. Merger and acquisition activity also increasingly emphasise collaboration with local companies to speedup incorporation. This has been reinforced by a rise in ecommerce free trade areas. Cross-border ecommerce is a significant part of China's Internet Plus strategy. It reflects online sales as an effective way of boosting consumption
column31: as well as its growing contribution in regional value chains
column32: especially among SMEs and in the agricultural sector. This is further aided by fintech projects by AliPay and WeChat Pay
column33: China's foremost epayment service providers. Alibaba's subsidiary Ant Financial has followed a similar strategy
column34: obtaining shares of fintech companies
column35: such as in the Philippines (Mynt)
column36: Malaysia (Touch ‘n Go)
column37: and India (PayTM). Malaysia was the first country to host an eWTP (Electronic World Trade Platform) hub outside of China. Ecommerce entrees require guidance on setting up online stores and digital marketing strategies. Incubator programs play an important role to help grow these aspiring entrepreneurs. Malaysia can learn from China's ecommerce development by keeping pace with the latest trend and innovations
column38: engaging experts to further improve the local ecommerce ecosystem and apply big data to understand consumer demand. There is also room for Malaysia to benefit from China's untapped internet market potential
column39: as 45% of the Chinese population still lack internet access. How the BRI helps ecommerce The ecommerce push in the BRI-participating economies saw Alibaba and JD.com providing a platform for less-developed economies to access consumer goods from supermarket chains and shopping malls. The Digital Silk Road (DSR) has progressed into improving recipient countries' telecommunications networks and digital technologies
column41: cloud computing
column43: and other digital economic areas. Projects in telecommunications
column44: ecommerce and other forms of innovative technology applied to smart cities have benefited as a result. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang
column46: promised to accelerate the construction of new infrastructure such as 5G networks and data centres. Haitong Securities predicts new infrastructure investments will total RMB17.5 trillion (or US$2.47 trillion) in the next five years
column47: or roughly RMB3.0 trillion on average yearly. The new infrastructure investment will have spillover benefits for governments and firms along the Belt and Road
column48: which often receive low-interest soft loans from state banks to purchase Chinese tech products. China and economies cooperating with it under the BRI are an increasingly significant part of the world economy. The digital BRI could boost China's export of digital surveillance technologies to countries as part of the war against Covid-19
column49: especially in implementing contact tracing. While 5G rollout and China's surveillance equipment sales tend to dominate headlines
column50: the significance of information and communications technology to economic growth and development should not be overlooked. Investments in digital infrastructure could aid economic recovery by increasing demand and generating employment
column52: drive economic transformation by enhancing output and trade in goods and services. Dr Cheong Jia Qi is Senior Lecturer at University Malaysia Sabah. The views expressed here are entirely the writer's own. The SEARCH Scholar Series is a social responsibility programme jointly organised by the Southeast Asia Research Centre for Humanities (SEARCH) and the Centre of Business and Policy Research
column53: Tunku Abdul Rahman University College (TAR UC)
column54: and co-organised by the Association of Belt and Road Malaysia.;thestar.com.my;1823;news;MY;en;Search Scholar Series
column55: Dr Cheong Jia Qi;https://cdn.thestar.com.my/Themes/img/newTsol_logo_socmedia.png;False;;22.199532;fbe208e6cbb1ab29b749aedb56d77dca;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND DSR'

column1: 4;China's Digital Silk Road Initiative: A Boon for Developing Countries or a Danger to Freedom?;;2020-12-17 07:15:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2020/12/chinas-digital-silk-road-initiative-a-boon-for-developing-countries-or-a-danger-to-freedom/;thediplomat.com;Some observers worry that it will equip authoritarian governments with next-generation surveillance technologies.;"AdvertisementAs part of China's massive Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)
column2: Beijing launched the Digital Silk Road (DSR) in 2015 with a loose mandate. It has since become a significant part of Beijing's overall BRI strategy
column3: under which China provides aid
column4: political support
column5: and other assistance to recipient states. DSR also offers support to Chinese exporters
column6: including many well-known Chinese technology companies. The DSR assistance goes toward improving recipients' telecommunications networks
column8: cloud computing
column9: e-commerce and mobile payment systems
column10: surveillance technology
column11: smart cities
column12: and other high-tech areas.China has already signed agreements on DSR cooperation with
column13: or provided DSR-related investment to
column14: at least sixteen countries. But the true number of agreements and investments is likely much larger
column15: because many of these go unreported: memoranda of understanding (MOUs) do not necessarily show whether China and another country have embarked upon close cooperation in the digital sphere. Some estimates suggest that one-third of the countries participating in BRI — 138 at this point — are cooperating on DSR projects.Leaders of many developing countries have signed DSR agreements. Although these MOUs are not legally binding
column16: they show the scope of global interest in DSR. Countries in Africa
column19: Latin America
column20: and Southeast Asia desperately need inexpensive
column21: high-quality technology to expand wireless phone networks and broadband internet coverage. DSR-related investments can help fill that gap and spark growth by providing critical infrastructure. Chinese firms are bringing additional benefits to developing countries by establishing training centers and research and development programs to boost cooperation between scientists and engineers
column22: and to transfer technical knowledge in many areas.Still
column23: some democracies have raised serious concerns about the Digital Silk Road. They worry that
column24: at a time when Beijing is becoming more assertive globally
column25: China will use DSR to enable recipient countries to adopt its model of technology-enabled authoritarianism. Chinese technology companies have already helped governments in other countries develop surveillance capabilities that could be used against opposition groups
column26: and Beijing has provided training for interested DSR recipient countries on how to monitor and censor the internet. Although some of these Chinese companies are nominally private
column27: even the private firms have drawn global scrutiny for state links as they are required by Chinese cybersecurity legislation to store data on servers in China and submit to checks from authorities.Moreover
column28: allowing Chinese firms to build countries' fifth-generation (5G) networks and other infrastructure
column29: and to set technology standards
column30: could risk espionage and coercion of other states' politics if Beijing used data breaches to blackmail political elites in those states. DSR could also help recipient countries better control their internets through filtering
column31: content moderation
column32: data localization
column33: and surveillance. Doing so might accelerate a fracturing of the global internet
column34: as some countries pursue these policies of internet control while others remain committed to internet freedoms.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Silk Road Surveillance Looking at examples of countries where the DSR has already progressed can offer clues about both its positive and negative aspects. Take Ecuador
column35: for instance. Ecuador has participated in the Digital Silk Road in several ways. It has worked with China on a smart cities program designed to reduce crime. This system relies on footage from more than four thousand Chinese-made cameras installed throughout the country. Following the system's installation
column36: the cameras will likely have facial recognition capabilities. In addition
column37: several Ecuadorean hospitals have begun using artificial intelligence-enabled COVID-19 diagnostic tools developed by the Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column38: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: Although the installation of the surveillance cameras coincided with a drop in crime rates across Ecuador
column2: camera footage
column3: initially thought to be sent to the police
column4: is also being sent to the country's domestic intelligence agency. In the past
column5: the agency has regularly tracked and intimidated political opponents. In addition
column6: Chinese investment in the country has been implicated in multiple high-profile corruption cases
column7: as well as a significant debt to China. Ecuador has sought to renegotiate its debt with Beijing and has also agreed to export 80 percent of its crude oil to China to repay some of its debts.AdvertisementIn other countries
column8: like Egypt
column9: concerns about the DSR are more about the possibility that it will play a role in exporting a controlled type of domestic internet. China has courted North Africa and the Middle East as part of its technology push; it reportedly has signed Digital Silk Road memoranda of understanding with Egypt
column10: Saudi Arabia
column11: Turkey
column12: and the United Arab Emirates. Cooperation has moved quickly with Egypt. In 2019
column13: Egyptian officials visiting China met leaders of ten major Chinese firms to discuss increasing investment in areas including artificial intelligence
column14: high-performance computing
column15: and telecommunications infrastructure. Huawei has built a cloud computing center in Egypt
column16: and China is increasing financing to Egypt's telecommunications sector.Egypt desperately needs to upgrade its crumbling infrastructure and gain access to inexpensive 5G. But Chinese technical assistance could enhance the Egyptian government's ability to crack down on internet freedoms. In recent years
column17: Beijing has held training for Egyptian officials on censorship; such training could have provided an impetus for Egypt to adopt a 2018 cybercrime law that moves the country closer to China's internet model. The law expands the government's ability to censor online information and punish those who publish or even access certain information.Or
column18: the DSR could help authoritarian leaders stay in power in other ways. Zambia has cooperated on Digital Silk Road projects with China
column19: particularly in upgrades to Zambia's wireless networks. Huawei is building Zambia's 5G network
column20: as it is in many countries across Africa. Huawei has also built the data center that stores and processes the Zambian government's data.  But as Zambia
column21: once a democratic success story in southern Africa
column22: slides toward authoritarianism
column23: its technology cooperation with China could further empower Zambia's rulers. Huawei reportedly has provided technology to help the Zambian government spy on political opponents — a situation reportedly repeated in Uganda
column24: where Huawei has helped the government monitor political rivals. But concerns about China's influence in Zambia are likely being suppressed; the government of President Edgar Lungu has also worked to censor and discourage criticism of China in Zambian media outlets.Some democracies also worry that DSR projects could help the Chinese government gain access to sensitive data. While U.S. officials have pressured central and east European states not to use Chinese companies to build telecommunications and other infrastructure
column25: Serbia has tried to balance between the U.S. and China. Although European countries have agreed upon a plan to limit Huawei's penetration
column26: Serbia has welcomed Huawei's assistance in upgrading its digital infrastructure.Both the U.S. government and some European states worry that the Chinese government could obtain backdoor access to data on Huawei networks in Serbia. A secret backdoor for Chinese intelligence
column27: and possibly the Chinese military

Yet the Serbian government has given no indication that it actually intends to ban Huawei from its 5G network.Forging on with the DSR These existing Digital Silk Road deals are just the start. Beijing is making DSR a bigger foreign policy priority

column35: which has led many governments to monitor their populations

column37: a subset of the BRI that supports health infrastructure.But as DSR expands

column40: have expressed similar qualms as the U.S. and Europe about China's tech offensive. Beijing's increasingly nationalist diplomacy is also undermining its efforts to assuage policymakers in developing states about the potential downsides of DSR and BRI.To be sure

column43: and espionage abroad. Some U.S. tech giants have also used their networks to facilitate surveillance

column47: many governments have clear demands for surveillance and artificial intelligence

column51: Beijing has promoted DSR as a priority.As the Digital Silk Road expands

column1: 5;China's Digital Silk Road and the Global Digital Order;Richard Ghiasy and Rajeshwari Krishnamurthy;2021-04-13 12:39:00;full;https://thediplomat.com/2021/04/chinas-digital-silk-road-and-the-global-digital-order;thediplomat.com;China's Digital Silk Road is an ambitious vision to catalyze global digitalization. What will it mean for digital governance?;"AdvertisementChina's Digital Silk Road (DSR) was launched in 2015 as a component of Beijing's vast vision for global connectivity
column2: the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). Like the BRI
column3: the DSR is not monolithic and involves many actors at all levels across the Chinese public and private sectors. It is amorphous and the line between official and unofficial DSR projects is often blurry. Comprehensive data on DSR investments is difficult to come by. According to one estimate
column5: DSR-related investments in digital infrastructure projects outside of China had reached $79 billion.The DSR aims to improve digital connectivity in participating countries
column6: with China as the main driver of the process. On the macro level
column7: the DSR is about the development and interoperability of critical digital infrastructure such as terrestrial and submarine data cables
column8: 5G cellular networks
column9: data storage centers
column10: and global satellite navigation systems. In one of the most recent moves
column11: China completed the launch of its global satellite system
column12: BeiDou
column13: which
column14: in some regions
column15: is more accurate than the United States' global positioning system (GPS). In Asia
column16: Pakistan
column19: and Thailand are among the countries that have adopted BeiDou
column20: and there is growing use in West Asia (the Middle East) and Africa. At the micro level
column21: the DSR promotes connectivity between local businesses and consumers and among businesses and consumers. Examples include e-commerce
column22: taxi-hailing
column23: fintech (financial technology)
column24: and edtech (education technology) platforms and apps
column25: as well as hardware such as routers
column26: smartphones
column27: and PCs.What Drives the DSR?The DSR is far more than just an infrastructure project. For China
column28: the DSR is a solution that engenders a less U.S.-centric and a more Sino-centric Asian and global digital order. China pursues this goal by enabling the opening of new markets for Chinese tech giants such as Alibaba
column29: Tencent
column30: and Huawei
column31: and by strengthening the world's digital connectivity with China.The DSR fits right in with the Chinese authorities' ambitious national goals such as 'Made in China 2025' and 'China Standards 2035.' These initiatives aim to enhance China's domestic tech innovation
column32: production
column33: and transaction capabilities. In turn
column34: these goals are part of an overarching vision of the Chinese government for tech primacy and greater autonomy in the global digital order.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.But why?The Chinese government seeks to reduce the country's vulnerable dependence on other tech leaders
column35: especially the United States
column36: Japan
column37: and select European states. The DSR aids Chinese tech giants and smaller players to boost their sales and local knowhow and gain a foothold in overseas markets – often with the help of Chinese government policy facilitation. Regardless of what one makes of the approach
column38: the DSR expands the oligopolistic pool of digital products and services suppliers.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column39: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: Indeed
column2: a small number of actors lead the tech world
column3: and U.S. tech giants Alphabet (Google)
column4: Intel
column5: Amazon
column6: Cisco
column7: and Facebook in particular have a near-global monopoly in their respective domains. For example
column8: by the end of 2018
column9: content providers such as Microsoft
column10: Facebook
column11: and Amazon owned or leased more than half of the undersea cable bandwidth. These cables carry close to 98 percent of international internet data and telephone traffic. Such dominance is not healthy and several actors
column12: including the EU and Australia
column13: have taken steps to curb these tech giants' sway.AdvertisementThe DSR often focuses on BRI participants and developing economies; but the DSR's reach is not limited to these actors. The initiative fills digital 'voids' wherever it spots one. Top recipients of DSR investments even include large European economies such as Germany and Italy. In Europe
column14: projects focus on 5G networks
column15: fintech
column16: and smart city technologies. Through competitive Chinese public-private sector partnership deals
column17: the DSR catalyzes a more digitalized world from Serbia to Mexico to Myanmar. A more digitalized world is not exclusively beneficial to China and Chinese companies. Indeed
column19: if accompanied by economic growth
column20: could offer a host of spinoff investment and sales opportunities for non-Chinese tech and non-tech companies too.But There Are Significant ChallengesAs with any initiative of this scale
column21: the DSR comes with some challenges. Particularly
column22: these apply to existing tech giants and digital infrastructure providers who would wish to sustain their lead. Broadly
column23: however
column24: these challenges apply to all stakeholders who favor the vision of a more open
column25: transparent
column26: free
column27: and equitable global cyber domain – and digital governance at large.In this regard
column28: the DSR has four significant and far-reaching strategic implications. First
column29: China can build and offer digital backbones that are almost entirely homegrown. The backbones are the infrastructure that makes digital communication possible
column30: such as data cables
column31: cellular networks
column32: and data storage centers. Drawing an analogy with Legos
column33: the more backbone China builds
column34: the more it can build on and connect to that foundation – thus strengthening its position in the global digital order.Second
column35: the DSR may facilitate China to set standards for digital infrastructure and next-generation tech such as artificial intelligence
column36: robotics
column37: the Internet of Things
column38: blockchain
column40: and so on. Although all tech leaders seek to set standards
column41: existing tech leaders are bound to view emerging Chinese attempts to set standards as competition. Beyond the considerations of existing tech leaders and within the wider global considerations
column42: setting standards brings considerable strategic advantages with it. Moreover
column43: the DSR creates digital arteries that are likely to boost Chinese supply chains
column48: China's view on digital governance has a much more state-paternalistic nature. This differs starkly from the average liberal Western view on digital values and norms
column49: especially that of the United States. The Chinese government enforces strict restrictions on the cyberspace in China. It also does not hesitate to closely monitor its netizens in a considerably sealed off domestic 'intranet.' Granted
column50: China is certainly not the only country to practice a restrictive view on digital governance
column51: and different countries enforce different types and levels of restrictions over cyberspace. Countries like Singapore and India tend to enforce controls on content too
column55: while the DSR does not promote a liberal and transparent cyber domain per se
column56: it is important to note that there are no universal global cyber governance values. Perhaps this is reflective of the diversity of cultures and socio-political values on the human canvas – both online and offline.Fourth
column60: could gain access to large local data pools through the DSR. By strengthening other countries' reliance on Chinese infrastructure
column61: Beijing could – theoretically – gain a valuable tool of local political influence
column62: although this would depend considerably on local cybersecurity policies and enforcement capacities
column63: among other factors. Such potential exploitation
column65: is not exclusive to China. As the Edward Snowden revelations and the Facebook-Cambridge Analytica data scandal showed
column66: any tech provider or cyber tech-advanced actor could abuse their position
column67: if so desired.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.The DSR clearly serves a broader objective of narrowing the global digital divide. It also challenges the existing dominance of the U.S. digital value system and dominant market share of its tech companies. As such
column68: the DSR presents both serious partners in digital transformation for those countries in need of competitively priced digital products and services
column69: as well as competition to existing tech leaders. Regardless of where one stands
column70: amidst a pandemic that has wreaked havoc on the global economy
column71: digitalization and economic growth are as welcome as ever.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;['Richard Ghiasy and Rajeshwari Krishnamurthy'];https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat-network-3524352_1280.jpg;False;;37.122536;8d768c342fbfaac41ab34e9c79b52ffe;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND DSR'

column1: 6;For Indonesia
column2: Chinese 5G Cooperation Brings Promise and Peril;Sebastian Strangio;2021-01-20 13:04:43;full;https://thediplomat.com/2021/01/for-indonesia-chinese-5g-cooperation-brings-promise-and-peril;thediplomat.com;Like many nations
column3: Indonesia faces a difficult decision about how far to engage with China's Digital Silk Road.;AdvertisementEarlier this month
column4: on his four-nation tour of Southeast Asia
column5: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi visited Indonesia
column6: during which the two sides discussed cooperation on the development of 5G networks in the archipelago.Under the leadership of Xi Jinping
column7: China has stepped up its global engagement in a host of economic and political domains. An important part of this is positioning China as a global technological leader
column8: which has taken place under the aegis of the Digital Silk Road (DSR) a major pillar of the Belt and Road Initiative that was established in 2013.The DSR is has the aim of expanding China's digital connections abroad and thus increasing its commercial and political influence.The telecommunications firm Huawei is one of China's mainstays in its DSR push
column9: helping to develop  5G networks in various countries
column10: including Indonesia. Since 2009
column11: Huawei has invested $600 million in research for the development of 5G technology globally. In more recent years
column12: it has also offered to help governments build their 5G networks
column13: an offer made attractive by the fact that its technology is much more affordable than competing products produced by Western firms.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column14: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter However
column15: several countries have also boycotted collaboration with Huawei on 5G due to concerns about national security
column16: including the United States
column19: Britain
column20: and Canada. In addition
column21: France and Japan have also indirectly prohibited the use of technology assembled by Huawei.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.In Indonesia
column22: however
column23: the country has welcomed with open arms both the arrival of Huawei and of the DSR more broadly. Last year
column24: Huawei announced that it was collaborating with the country's Agency for the Assessment and Application of Technology (BPPT). The government of President Joko Widodo views collaboration between Huawei and Indonesia's technology industry
column25: government
column26: and universities as central to achieving its goal of producing a creative and digital economy by 2035 and a 'more developed' nation by 2045.This collaboration currently takes place in three fields: artificial intelligence (AI)
column27: cloud computing
column28: and 5G networks. On the first two counts
column29: Huawei is involved in developing BPPT's capacity and helping the agency develop and apply AI and cloud computing in the Indonesian economy.However
column30: the government in Jakarta is still unsure of Indonesia's readiness to make the leap to 5G technology
column31: the Head of Human Resources Development Research
column32: Basuki Yusuf Iskandar recently told the local media.AdvertisementIskandar believes that before Indonesia can build a 5G network
column33: it must take into account several factors beyond the basic technological challenges: namely
column34: whether Indonesia's industry and regulatory capacities
column35: as well as the population as a whole
column36: are ready to make the transition. He added that if this readiness is lacking
column37: the implementation of this 5G network will not bring the expected economic returns.To assist with this
column38: Huawei is helping prep the 5G market in Indonesia in several ways. First
column39: the company is helping to educate the public about 5G technology and its potential benefits. Muhammad Rosidi
column40: Huawei's national ICT strategy and marketing director in Indonesia
column41: stated recently that the firm has played an important role in disseminating information about 5G and its potential benefits to the Indonesian public. Huawei is also ready to help accelerate the digitalization of infrastructure in Indonesia
column42: specifically by helping develop the capacity of government workers.Second
column43: Huawei last year also began collaborating with the Indonesian Presidential Staff Office to put 100
column44: 000 Indonesian officials through a five-year vocational training course in digital literacy. Third
column45: Huawei also pledged to develop infrastructure such as band transceiver stations
column47: that can facilitate wireless communication in various regions so that 5G technology can be accessed evenly across the Indonesian islands.China's interest in implementing the DSR in Indonesia is not surprising
column48: given that the country has the sixth-largest internet user base in the world. This gives Chinese companies like Huawei added motivation for making Indonesia a priority market
column49: including on 5G infrastructure development.As this cooperation advances
column51: Indonesia's embrace of the DSR raises some concerns. Despite Huawei's efforts
column52: questions remain around equality of access to 5G technology
column53: given that the present internet infrastructure is still not developed equally across the country..There is also a worry that DSR will allow China to surveil the Indonesian government
column54: or that the latter will use Chinese technologies to spy on its own people. It is crucial to note that firms from China have already assisted governments in some parts of the world with developing surveillance capabilities that could be used against dissidents and opposition groups. China has also helped train foreign government officials on how to monitor and censor the internet.As for Indonesia
column55: it has signed with China a memorandum of understanding on boosting internet security and tech cooperation
column56: the first such agreement signed between China and a foreign countryEnjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Given the fact that the current Indonesian government has taken steps to undermine and repress its opponents
column57: it is possible that the country's cooperation with China on the DSR could lead to a decline in the quality of democracy in Indonesia.Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat is currently a lecturer at the Universitas Islam Indonesia. His research and teaching focuses on the politics of international cooperation
column58: with specific interest in China-Indonesia-Middle East relations.Yeta Purnama is a student majoring in International Relations at Universitas Islam Indonesia.;thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;['Sebastian Strangio'];https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat-2021-01-20-5.jpg;False;;33.62844;1f08c2d3a26b9a303270a646534ef081;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND DSR'

column1: 7;China's Digital Silk Road Grows With 5G in the Middle East;Sophie Zinser;2020-12-15 20:00:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2020/12/chinas-digital-silk-road-grows-with-5g-in-the-middle-east/;thediplomat.com;Huawei and other Chinese firms continue to make rapid inroads among Gulf countries – despite the United States' efforts.;"In this Oct. 14
column3: file photo
column4: a man wearing a face mask to protect against the coronavirus walks past a billboard advertising Chinese technology firm Huawei at the PT Expo in Beijing.

column1: Credit: AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein
column2: FileAdvertisement'New Value Together' was the slogan for the 40th annual GITEX Technology Week
column3: the only in-person global technology show of 2020 held December 6 to 10 at the Dubai World Trade Center. Its organizer is known across the Middle East – particularly the GCC countries – as the region's leader in 5G and cloud computing: Huawei.The global telecoms supplier and mobile phone manufacturer made headlines throughout 2020 – most recently in Southeast Asia with a blitz of deals monopolizing Indonesia's 5G network – for its role in a growing global 5G movement. Eleven telecom firms including those in the Gulf Cooperation countries (GCC) of the UAE
column4: Saudi Arabia
column5: Bahrain
column6: Kuwait
column7: and Oman have signed massive 5G contracts with Huawei over the last year.By 2025
column8: GCC countries will house much of the world's growing 5G subscribers. Huawei has jumped on the bandwagon to capitalize on what they perceive as a promising future for 5G in the Middle East. The company's leadership has been bullish on the Middle East since September 2019. And the region's $164 billion annual market for information and communication technology (ICT) products is a good reason for Huawei's enthusiasm. Over the last year
column9: there has been a surge in publicly administered cloud services in the Gulf worth nearly $3 billion. This Gulf government-led push is confirming for Huawei that 5G-enabled cloud computing in the GCC is an increasingly lucrative market.But what impact has this recent growth in 5G had on the everyday lives of the 54 million people living in the GCC? Not much. Locally
column10: 5G is mostly being implemented widely only insofar as to enable a more rapid pace of downloads to smartphones and quicker analog communications. As of December 1
column11: Huawei's new P40 PRO 5G phone is available for consumer purchase in the UAE. But analysts remain optimistic on the potential of 5G to positively impact multiple industries in the GCC
column12: specifically energy usage optimization
column13: cloud computing
column14: ultrafast broadband
column15: and internet of things (IoT) innovation
column16: including self-driving cars
column19: Huawei has been relentlessly extending its digital footprint across the Middle East despite Western efforts to curtail its global expansion. The United States has repeatedly expressed security concerns over Huawei's presence in international markets. Since 2018
column20: U.S. policymakers have been actively attempting to hinder the company and its China-side competitor ZTE's expansion abroad
column21: especially within the European Union. The Trump administration's pressure on Huawei – specifically its recent ploy to curb critical semiconductor technology sales to the Chinese company – has sparked global discussions about data privacy and security-related drawbacks to international reliance on Huawei's toolkit.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.While the U.S. government's efforts to halt Huawei's expansion have succeeded domestically and in parts of Europe
column22: the Gulf market has come out unscathed. This is perhaps due to the region's highly sensitive position in geopolitics. Given a heavy reliance on China's oil market as well as the significant U.S. military and diplomatic presence
column23: there is no incentive for Gulf economies to become a proxy war zone for the world's two largest superpowers.But COVID-19 has made Gulf economies increasingly reliant on China as the nation's economy recovers faster than the United States' from the global recession. Since COVID-19 restrictions lifted in China
column24: Chinese policymakers have undertaken major steps to develop what they are calling 'industrial internet' of global telecommunications providers at far cheaper prices than their Western competitors in the sector. Saudi Telecom Company (STC) reported a jump of over 1
column25: 000 percent in bandwidth due to the surge in remote education. They are currently scrambling to secure necessary network infrastructure to keep pace with the demands of Saudi's ambitious Vision 2030 strategy. Similarly
column26: Qatar is preparing to host in 2022 what it hopes will be the first 5G World Cup. The event's reliance on a critical partnership between British telecom giant Vodafone and Huawei may be jilted from the U.K.'s recent ban on Huawei products
column27: making the battle for 5G in the region over the next few years ever more relevant.NGet briefed on the story of the week

column1: Huawei's aforementioned growth in global 5G has occupied much of the 2020 conversation on Chinese companies comprising China's Digital Silk Road (DSR) initiative. The phrase DSR was initially launched in a government white paper in 2015 as an extension of China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)
column2: a global strategy for Chinese-led infrastructure development. Now the DSR is a widely used moniker for Chinese data and telecoms activity abroad. According to Fudan University
column3: the DSR policy itself is comprised of five key aspects: with infrastructure at its core
column4: the DSR relies on expanding influence to trade
column5: finance
column6: and 'people's hearts
column7: ' all geared toward shaping policies abroad. These include cybersecurity
column8: digital governance
column9: and data sharing practices across the developing world.AdvertisementBoth the BRI and DSR act in practice as catch-all monikers for economic and policy decisions that Chinese government actors and corporations make. The ambiguity of DSR's branding makes potentially disparate policies across many Chinese companies – each with varying levels of Chinese government involvement – look cohesive. Even within those companies China's hybridized structure of state-owned and private enterprises makes top-level decision-making incentives difficult for outsiders to disentangle.No single company or government entity is totally emblematic of China's DSR
column10: even Huawei. But U.S. 5G operations are still lagging behind that of Asia in the Middle East. The Japan Center for Economic Research predicts that given its performance in light of COVID-19
column11: the Chinese economy will surpass that of the United States before 2030. With rollout of 5G in the U.S. lagging in pace behind that of Asia
column12: Huawei and its peer companies' current moves into Middle Eastern markets could chart a course for Asian dominance in the region's future.Multinational coordination efforts – such as the digital infrastructure partnership launched last year between the EU and Japan – are a positive strategy for the U.S. government's competition to stay relevant on 5G. Republican Chairman of the U.S. Senate's Foreign Relations Committee Jim Risch recently released a report hoping to form a transatlantic partnership between the EU and U.S.
column13: citing concerns over the vast capacity for Chinese controlled firms to support data storage. Just like Huawei's 'New Value Together' slogan in the Middle East
column14: cooperation strategies may help the West stay relevant and bring increasingly competitive value to the Middle Eastern ICT market.Sophie Zinser is a researcher focusing on China's role in the Middle East

column1: 8;What Does the US-China AI Rivalry Mean For Southeast Asia?;;2022-02-07 08:30:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2022/02/what-does-the-us-china-ai-rivalry-mean-for-southeast-asia;thediplomat.com;Escalating superpower tech competition will force governments in the region to make some tough choices.;"AdvertisementArtificial intelligence (AI) development has become a race among nations
column2: with the winners expected to wield significant power in defining and dominating the future
column3: both economically and geopolitically. In this competition
column4: the United States and China are the front-runners
column5: with both countries surging forward based on their respective competitive advantages: the U.S. has cutting-edge hardware
column6: research
column8: while China has a massive trove of the AI-ready data that fuels technological development
column9: and a strong political will to succeed.The dominance of these two countries in the tech sector undoubtedly has strategic implications for Southeast Asia
column10: which predominantly relies on importing and using AI technology from the U.S. and China. What are the implications of choosing the technology of one country over the other? Will Southeast Asian countries face problems related to digital colonization and national sovereignty?Some scholars have described Southeast Asia as a testing ground and a gateway for China's expansion as a superpower. Indeed
column11: China is increasingly regarded by Southeast Asians as the most influential economic power in the region and
column12: to a lesser extent
column13: the most influential politically and strategically.China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)
column14: a trillion-dollar international infrastructure program spanning nearly 140 countries
column15: is part of its plan to increase its global influence. An important part of the BRI is its reach into the digital space through the Digital Silk Road (DSR). The DSR's key components – 5G technologies
column16: massive data centers
column18: and satellite navigation systems – have major implications for data privacy
column19: national security
column20: and the global governance of cyberspace. Observers have expressed concerns about cyber espionage and cybersecurity
column21: as these technological advances would give the Chinese government the ability to access
column22: analyze
column23: and exploit in real-time the large data sets of BRI recipient countries. Additionally
column24: think tanks and scholars have warned of China 'exporting authoritarianism
column25: ' 'exporting political illiberalism
column26: ' or pushing 'authoritarian capitalism' globally through the distribution of Chinese technologies.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column27: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: Discussions about the geopolitical risks of China achieving global dominance in AI paint the power struggle between the U.S. and China as a showdown between liberal democracy and digital authoritarianism. However
column2: while the U.S. is often considered as a more benign force
column3: worries about the Chinese state's overreach apply and overlap significantly in the case of the U.S.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.The 2013 revelations of Edward Snowden
column4: a former contractor to the U.S. intelligence agencies
column5: laid bare the impressive breadth and depth of Washington's global surveillance capabilities and cyber espionage practices. A particularly powerful example is the PRISM program
column6: which enables the routine mass collection of data from major big tech companies. But while these revelations shook the world
column7: privacy concerns regarding AI-enabled automated mass surveillance remain unaddressed.In the discourse on the geopolitics of AI
column8: some scholars have taken the theoretical lens of digital or data colonization to analyze the position of the Global South
column9: listing the ways in which algorithms can be used to oppress
column10: exploit
column11: and dispossess vulnerable populations.However
column12: experts and academics in the AI field interviewed for EngageMedia's recent study on AI governance in Southeast Asia pointed out that focusing on national sovereignty distracts us from seeing the matter holistically
column13: as a complex interplay of state and market forces working together and against each other.AdvertisementWhile the respondents acknowledged that data predominantly flows toward China and the U.S.
column14: and that Southeast Asia's dependency on technologies coming from the two AI superpowers may disadvantage the nations of the region
column15: some experts said that the exploitation of data would occur with or without the involvement of foreign companies. They noted that since Southeast Asia's data protection regulations are either weak or non-existent
column16: similar harms from misusing data collection would arise in any event with local players.It is therefore more important to focus on creating a strong regulatory and policy foundation locally
column17: so that data protection and technology usage do not merely rely on the ethics or goodwill of the owners of the technologies
column19: Chinese
column20: or from another nation.It is also important to recognize that Southeast Asian countries have the agency to choose the technologies that they use and to negotiate for favorable terms. Some respondents in the study alluded to this when asked about the implications of the U.S.-China tech rivalry; their position was that Southeast Asian states would decide what is best for their countries
column21: whether in terms of price and functionality
column22: or from a strategic point of view.For example
column23: a case study on Alibaba's activities in Malaysia (which includes a Digital Free Trade Zone and Alibaba's City Brain smart cities program) argues that Malaysia derives real economic and infrastructural benefits from working with Alibaba
column24: geopolitical and privacy concerns notwithstanding. The study concluded that other countries 'desperately need to improve the quality of their game in Southeast Asia
column25: ' and that 'railing against Chinese government-dominated initiatives and the DSR is not an adequate strategy.'A study from Singapore's ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute on 5G adoption in the region shows that countries in Southeast Asia display different levels of trust toward China
column26: with Laos and Cambodia having the highest preference for Chinese providers
column27: versus the Philippines
column28: Vietnam
column29: and Singapore with the lowest. While trust toward China was higher in 2019
column30: telecommunications providers in the region appear to have diversified their vendor selection in 2020
column31: following U.S. restrictions on Chinese technologies. At the moment
column32: Nokia (Finland) and Ericsson (Sweden)
column33: alongside Huawei and ZTE (both China) are the biggest players in the 5G landscape in Southeast Asia
column34: with U.S. companies (Altiostar
column35: Cisco
column36: and Qualcomm) having no significant presence.In the short term
column37: the rivalry between the U.S. and China in the region may offer Southeast Asian countries the leverage to negotiate better terms than they would get otherwise and provide more choices to balance their own interests. However
column38: in the longer term
column39: the bifurcation of Chinese and American technologies
column41: and norms will lead to a decline in multilateralism. This can create disadvantages for weaker countries
column42: as they may not have the negotiating power or enforcement capabilities of a bloc. Additionally
column43: international efforts at developing common norms
column45: may be derailed.Southeast Asian nations must find ways to identify and address some of the inherent weaknesses and challenges that undermine their capacity to plan for and support the adoption of AI technologies. This will enable them to reap the benefits of AI on their own terms and find their place in a future AI ecosystem dominated by the two superpowers.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2022-02-07-044540.jpg;False;;27.394989;9fdb1b3eaaa6320c4be66b49145970d5;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND DSR'

column1: 9;China's Tech Outreach in the Middle East and North Africa;;2022-11-17 15:45:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2022/11/chinas-tech-outreach-in-the-middle-east-and-north-africa/;thediplomat.com;Chinese companies
column2: acting out of both economic and geostrategic motives
column3: are providing much of the MENA region's digital infrastructure.;"AdvertisementThe Middle East and North Africa region has become a hub for Chinese technological outreach. Over the years
column4: Chinese entities have invested heavily in MENA's railways
column5: ports
column6: and the energy sector. However
column8: software
column9: and cybersecurity
column10: much of this architecture would not be able to operate effectively.Enter Chinese Big Tech.Huawei provides communication technology for Morocco's national railway system (ONCF)
column11: has constructed a logistics center at Tangier Med Port
column12: and was involved in building and launching the Marrakesh Safe City project. Roughly 7
column13: 000 kilometers away

column16: develop

column1: Unlike traditional Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) projects that are often led by state-owned enterprises (SOEs)
column2: this Digital Silk Road (DSR) is being spearheaded by private tech companies that are primarily profit-driven.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Efforts by MENA nations to digitize and diversify their economies have made them attractive markets for these Chinese firms to expand their presence abroad. Draws for companies looking to enter the region include a relatively stable physical and digital infrastructure compared to other developing BRI regions
column3: steadily growing internet penetration
column4: and a digital economy projected to reach $400 billion by 2030.All this creates the impression that China-MENA technology cooperation is simply being driven by market forces. However
column5: the logic driving China's engagement with the MENA region extends beyond the law of supply and demand and into the realm of geostrategy.Ubiquitous Connectivity AdvertisementIn a 2016 speech
column6: China's top leader Xi Jinping said
column7: 'We must encourage and support China's internet companies to go global … so as to achieve the principle of ‘wherever our national interests are
column8: [our] informatization [technology] will also cover those areas.'' Through the DSR
column9: China seeks to connect its civilian and military assets along the Belt and Road Initiative. The Pakistan & East Africa Connecting Europe fiber optic cable
column10: or PEACE
column11: exemplifies these efforts.PEACE travels from the BRI's flagship $62 billion China-Pakistan Economic Corridor to Djibouti –where the Chinese military established a naval base in 2017. From there
column12: it traverses the Bab al Mandab strait
column13: a critical maritime choke point
column14: and moves toward China-Egypt Teda Suez Economic and Trade Cooperation Zone
column15: where China has built a 7.34 sq km industrial estate. PEACE then travels through the Mediterranean and onward to Europe.Infrastructure like PEACE ensures that Chinese port operators enjoy the high-speed
column16: low-latency connectivity critical for maintaining the integrity of supply chains and other activities that promote China's economic stability. Add to the mix that China
column18: relies on this vulnerable civilian infrastructure to coordinate military operations and Beijing's impetus to establish control over these networks should come as no surprise.Scholars like Zheng Anqi of the China Academy of Information and Communications Technology have directly linked military power with 'information power.' According to Zheng
column19: 'The foundation of an information force is the network. Without the support of ubiquitous
column20: broadband
column21: and mobile networks
column22: a powerful information army is just empty talk.'The 1996 Taiwan strait missile crisis illuminated precisely how a missing link in the technology stack can disrupt military operations when the PLA lost track of two missiles it fired into the East China Sea. Chinese military officers attributed the failure to a disruption in the U.S.-controlled Global Positioning Satellite (GPS) technology. Since then
column23: China has worked hard to develop its own BeiDou Navigation Satellite System and has looked to MENA for cooperation partners.In 2017
column24: the country launched the China-Arab States BeiDou Cooperation Forum. Shortly after the second forum concluded in Tunis in 2019
column25: Saudi Arabia's Ministry of Defense and the Equipment Development Commission of China signed an MoU to cooperate in the military use of BeiDou. Admittedly
column26: the data gathered from these satellites have applications that extend far beyond the military domain. For example
column27: BeiDou has been deployed commercially in fields as diverse as environmental monitoring
column28: smart agriculture
column29: disaster relief
column30: and transportation in Saudi Arabia
column31: Algeria
column32: Lebanon
column33: Oman
column34: and Morocco.Data as a Source of PowerEnjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Much of the infrastructure along the Digital Silk Road is data-driven. Undersea cables
column35: for instance
column36: transmit more than 95 percent of global internet traffic and facilitate trillions of dollars in international financial transactions daily. Beyond the PEACE cable
column37: Chinese companies like HMN tech (formerly Huawei Marine)
column38: China Telecom
column41: or acquired ownership stakes in at least nine other cables traversing MENA.Meanwhile
column42: companies like Shenzhen-based Beijing Genomics Institute (BGI) have won hundreds of millions of dollars in contracts with U.S. allies like Israel
column43: the United Arab Emirates
column44: and Saudi Arabia. Thanks to these deals
column45: BGI is now privy to reams of sensitive biological data.China has come to view data as a critical commodity and source of power. Key policy documents like the Action Plan to Promote the Development of Big Data (2015) and the 13th Five-Year-Plan (2016) designate data as 'a foundational strategic resource' alongside land
column47: and capital. The Action Plan calls for the country to 'comprehensively advance the development and application of big data' and 'accelerate the construction of a strong data country.' Beijing has since created legal frameworks for companies to provide data to the central government on national security grounds.AdvertisementAnalysts have since raised concerns that data collected along China's Digital Silk Road may help China manipulate political perceptions
column49: and undermine democracy. The opaque public-private sector nexus and the ambiguity surrounding what constitutes ‘national security grounds' have only reinforced these fears.Countering US Containment Against the backdrop of renewed great power competition
column50: Beijing has come to view its technology cooperation with MENA as increasingly important in countering U.S. efforts to contain China's rising power and influence. Since 2018
column51: the United States has succeeded in persuading many firms and allied nations worldwide to 'decouple' from Chinese technology and supply chains. That year
column52: Chinese investment and infrastructure projects declined in every region – except the Middle East and North Africa.The flow of capital is also slowly becoming more bi-directional: Oil-rich Gulf countries are now investing in China's high-end manufacturing
column54: and research and development. For example
column56: a Chinese startup that makes collaborative robots
column57: pulled in a Series D funding round of over $150 million in July 2022
column58: a growth fund under Saudi Aramco Ventures was among the lead investors. Two months later
column59: the Saudi Company for Artificial Intelligence (SCAI) announced it would inject around $206 million into a joint venture with China's SenseTime to build a state-of-the-art AI lab and advance Saudi Arabia's AI-tech ecosystem.In its quest to dominate the strategic technologies of tomorrow
column60: China has also turned to MENA nations to acquire digital innovations and know-how. Israel's vibrant innovation ecosystem has become a prime target in this regard. Since 2002 the vast majority of Chinese investments and M&A deals in Israel have been in the tech sector – over $9 billion worth. Through these deals
column61: Huawei acquired Israeli cybersecurity startup Hexatier for $42 million and IT company Toga Networks for over $100 million. Today
column62: Toga employs over 350 leading experts and continues to serve as a Huawei R&D center.With 9
column64: Israel is undoubtedly the most enticing source of innovative technologies in the region. But when it comes to Chinese R&D partnerships
column65: Beijing has looked beyond Israel's 'Silicon Wadi.' Huawei has set up OpenLabs in Cairo
column67: and Istanbul to develop innovations in cloud computing
column70: and other core technologies. The facility in Turkey is Huawei's largest overseas R&D operation and receives over $20 million annually in funding.Beyond Huawei
column71: 2018 saw Alibaba Cloud and the UAE's Khalifa University of Science and Technology agree to launch a Joint Innovation Laboratory of Artificial Intelligence for Clean Energy. That same year the UAE's International Center for Biosaline Agriculture in the United Arab Emirates partnered with BGI to establish an advanced genomics center.China Wins TwiceOn the face of it
column72: these partnerships appear a win-win. However
column73: an April 2022 study by political economy researcher Tin Hinane El Kadi suggests that this is not always the case. In her examination of Huawei's localization efforts in Algeria and Egypt
column74: El Kadi notes that Huawei often 'engaged in training
column76: and R&D in a way designed to maintain the firm's technological edge' and 'without engaging in meaningful capacity building.'To qualify: not all Chinese technology systems are malignant. Moreover
column77: there are immense economic and social benefits to cooperating with China in the digital realm
column83: and more financial inclusion. Chinese companies offer cutting-edge technology at an affordable price
column84: and China doesn't condition cooperation on democratizing or liberalizing local institutions.Regardless of these perceived benefits
column85: pundits and policymakers would be naive to ignore the geostrategic dimensions of China's technology outreach. In a May 2021 speech before hundreds of the nation's elite scientists gathered in Beijing's Great Hall of the People
column86: Xi Jinping himself declared: 'Technological innovation has become the main battlefield of the international strategic game.' MENA countries are part of this game
column87: whether they acknowledge it or not.As MENA nations become ever more reliant on Chinese technology systems
column88: Beijing is accruing leverage and influence. These emerging dependencies serve as a deterrence mechanism in that any governments or companies that dare offend China would risk being cut off from its massive market and the critical technologies that enable daily life. From Beijing's perspective
column89: this framework would ideally contribute to shaping a world more accommodating to China and its interests.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2022-11-17-143105.jpg;False;;25.01968;5663237dc4db8fd741fb1e119ae8755d;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND DSR'
