column1: 10;How China Is Attempting to Control the ‘Information Pipes';;2023-03-03 13:45:09;full;https://thediplomat.com/2023/03/how-china-is-attempting-to-control-the-information-pipes/;thediplomat.com;In addition to beaming out its perspectives via Chinese state media
column2: Beijing is aspiring to control both the structure and norms of global information networks.;"Advertisement

column1: In the past decade
column2: China's government has stepped up its efforts to wield powerful tools of information around the globe – in its near neighborhood and
column3: increasingly in more distant places including North America
column4: Africa
column5: Latin America
column6: and Europe. These tools include Beijing's own major state media outlets
column8: which have been expanded while China tries to make them credible
column9: palatable alternatives to existing global newswires based in liberal democracies
column10: like The Associated Press
column11: Agence France-Presse
column12: Reuters
column13: Kyodo
column14: and others. It also includes Beijing's growing efforts to use proxies to control Chinese-language media outlets within other countries around the world
column15: as well as Beijing's increasingly sophisticated use of disinformation on major social media platforms in its neighborhood and globally.

column1: Yet even as China attempts to use the control over media and information it has amassed
column2: it is also working to dominate the 'pipes' through which this information moves. I use the term

column1: pipes
to mean the broad underpinnings of global information networks
column2: including the actual physical infrastructure and the rules and norms that govern how information flows. More specifically
column3: these pipes include the physical telecommunications networks for wireless and wired data; mobile phones and other devices that display information; tools that create the Internet of Things; tools that allow for surveillance; leading search engines
column4: web browsers
column5: and social media platforms; and the standards that govern the internet.

column1: With greater influence in these areas
column2: China would not have to rely as much on other countries to disseminate Xinhua
column3: CGTN
column4: and CRI
column5: or on media coverage from local Chinese-language outlets controlled by Beijing. Instead
column6: it could use its own pipes to more aggressively
column8: spread state media coverage onto internet networks
column9: social media platforms
column10: mobile phones and other devices
column11: browsers
column12: and television conglomerates controlled by or closely linked to the Chinese government
column13: which would deprive news consumers in many countries of independent coverage about China.

column1: If Beijing had more control of the pipes of information
column2: it also could
column3: within foreign countries
column4: more easily censor negative stories and social media conversations
column5: and spread stories
column6: rumors
column8: accusations
column9: blandishments
column10: and other types of disinformation
column11: obviously types of sharp power. Ultimately
column12: it could use the pipes to help foreign countries copy China's surveillance strategies and to export China's vision of a closed and controlled domestic internet
column13: part of Beijing's overall model of technology-enabled authoritarianism.

column1: N
Get briefed on the story of the week
column2: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.

column1: Get the Newsletter
Building the Internet
Enjoying this article?
Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.
Chinese state companies are laying down many of the new physical or virtual pipes for global information flows in the developing world. The state-controlled China Telecom
column2: for instance
column3: has rolled out the third-biggest mobile phone network in the Philippines
column4: despite concerns raised by security experts and some lawmakers about Beijing dominating a portion of the country's mobile infrastructure. China Telecom partnered with the tycoon Dennis Uy
column5: a close ally of former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte
column6: in obtaining and rolling out its mobile network. This is a strategy Chinese state firms have used in many countries. By partnering with local tycoons
column7: Chinese firms often are able to land contracts to build mobile and fixed internet infrastructure
column8: sometimes without any transparent bidding processes.

column1: In Africa
column2: Beijing has become by far the dominant builder of new physical infrastructure for the transmission of information. China Telecom and ZTE
column3: whose biggest shareholder is a state-owned enterprise
column4: are building the core of new mobile and fiber-optic networks across the African continent
column5: competing largely with Huawei
column6: which is a private Chinese company
column7: but with historic links to the People's Liberation Army.

column1: In return
column2: they get help. Under China's Digital Silk Road (DSR) initiative
column3: part of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)
column4: many Chinese companies that build telecommunications infrastructure in Africa and other regions get loans from Chinese banks on extremely generous terms. Non-Chinese competitors face huge hurdles in corralling the same level of diplomatic support from their own governments or getting anything like the cheap financing
column5: usually from Chinese state banks
column6: that Chinese companies enjoy.

column1: Advertisement
Huawei has signed numerous commercial contracts around the world to build next-generation 5G networks
column2: though it has been shut out of many liberal democracies. Still
column3: it is poised to be the dominant 5G provider in sub-Saharan Africa
column4: with competitors lagging behind. In Southeast Asia
column5: meanwhile
column6: Huawei already has built many of the shorter undersea cables linking the region's telecommunications networks
column7: and the company has inked deals to develop 5G networks in Cambodia
column8: the Philippines
column9: and Thailand – and possibly in Indonesia. And in the Pacific Islands
column10: Huawei and other Chinese tech giants have competed aggressively with Australian and other companies to make new deals in places like Fiji. Around the world
column11: Huawei is completing thousands of miles of undersea cable
column12: through which most telecommunications traffic travels. In Central Asia
column13: meanwhile
column14: Huawei has already become the dominant provider of new 5G technology
column15: including in the region's most populous state
column16: Uzbekistan

column1: Even in some democracies where leaders have significant concerns about allowing Chinese companies to build telecommunications infrastructure
column2: Huawei has made inroads
column3: although some of its efforts are now stalling in richer countries worried about the downsides of being reliant on Huawei and other Chinese tech firms. Yet Huawei's low costs and high levels of experience with technology often give them a leg up in getting contracts to build infrastructure
column4: particularly in developing countries. Huawei also has become increasingly innovative
column5: becoming one of the biggest investors in research and development of any tech company in the world.

column1: Chinese firms are winning Internet of Things (IoT) contracts as well. Beijing has placed a particular priority on this sector since at least the late 2000s
column2: when then-Premier Wen Jiabao declared it a national priority. Emily de La Bruyère and Nathan Picarsic
column3: formerly of the consulting firm Long Term Strategy Group
column4: have written that Chinese companies have built 'a network of sensors [in China] – including but not limited to surveillance cameras
column5: car navigation systems
column6: and smart electricity monitors.' Any information that is gathered is passed along to the China Academy of Sciences (CAS)
column7: a leading Chinese research institution. According to de La Bruyère and Picarsic
column8: CAS 'explains that the system is a ‘test zone for a global network.''

column1: Poland and other European states have given IoT contracts to Chinese companies
column2: like the surveillance camera giant Hikvision
column3: which is part of a massive state enterprise.  Chinese-built surveillance camera systems even have been used in official buildings in Europe and North America
column4: including departments of the U.K. government and U.S. military bases
column5: though they now have been banned. In 2019
column6: the U.S. government added Hikvision and several other Chinese firms to an economic blacklist
column7: in part due to their involvement in abuses in Xinjiang. (The Hikvision cameras were being used on U.S. bases right up until the ban.) But even these U.S. actions did not appear to stop the firms' global expansion.

column1: Apps and Screens
Social media platforms are another kind of information pipe. A decade ago
column2: Chinese companies had virtually no presence on social media. Since then
column3: Chinese firms like WeChat
column4: Weibo
column5: and TikTok have expanded quickly
column6: both at home and abroad.

column1: TikTok
column2: the short-video app
column3: now rivals longer-established social media networks like Twitter and Instagram in terms of its number of new users
column4: and is gaining massive cultural influence among preteens
column5: teens
column6: and young adults around the world. In 2021
column7: it had the most downloads of any app
column8: even though it was only launched globally in 2017.  The app has become omnipresent on the phones of high school and college students
column9: with an estimated 40 percent of its users between the ages of 16 and 24.

column1: Enjoying this article?
Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.
TikTok's parent company
column2: ByteDance Limited
column3: presents itself as a global firm
column4: and TikTok as no different from platforms run by U.S.-based companies like Facebook or Twitter. But these claims ring hollow
column5: as multiple reports have found that TikTok has at times tried to alter or suppress content related to China
column6: and as the Chinese government has taken a stake in ByteDance and gained an important seat on its board.

column1: The China-based app WeChat also has begun to spread outside China. WeChat
column2: owned by the Chinese conglomerate Tencent
column3: has become a ubiquitous tool in China: Many middle-class Chinese have come to rely on it for much of their family
column4: social
column5: and work lives.

column1: Usage of WeChat is spreading among Chinese speakers in every corner of the world. It has 1.24 billion users and it has expanded across Southeast Asia and South Asia. The United States
column2: meanwhile
column3: is believed to be the second largest-source of WeChat users
column4: behind China. The Trump administration tried to crack down on it and its parent company with an executive order – but WeChat is still accessible
column5: since the Biden administration rescinded plans to ban its service in the United States.

column1: Advertisement
In Thailand
column2: nearly 20 percent of the population uses the app.  In Malaysia
column3: a country of around 32 million people
column4: there are reportedly 20 million WeChat accounts. The app's group chats
column5: which can include up to 500 people
column6: are channels for the spread of information sympathetic to the Chinese Communist Party (CCP)
column7: while people who offer critical commentary in the chat are censored. (While WeChat is not known primarily as a news app
column8: its content often contains news stories
column9: links to stories
column10: and discussions about stories
column11: making it a major disseminator of information about Chinese domestic and foreign policies.) In Northeast Asia
column12: WeChat has become the second-most-popular messaging app in Mongolia
column13: and is widely used in Japan and South Korea.

column1: While Chinese social media platforms are spreading
column2: Chinese mobile phone makers also are enjoying success
column3: particularly in developing regions like Africa
column4: South Asia
column5: and Southeast Asia. In these places
column6: inexpensive Chinese phones have gained huge market shares
column7: competing with more expensive rivals like Samsung and Apple. And because China was an early adapter in many new smartphone-related features like having one super app like WeChat
column8: Chinese firms actually have surpassed non-Chinese rivals in developing many apps beloved by consumers
column9: as well as developing specific innovations for markets in Africa and other developing regions.

column1: The numbers do not lie. Today
column2: China-based mobile phone companies make more than half of the phones purchased annually in Africa
column3: including both smartphones and budget phones. In Southeast Asia
column4: they are becoming increasingly popular
column5: after garnering two-thirds of the market in India
column6: a major geopolitical rival
column7: and much of the market in China.

column1: Many Chinese-made phones come loaded with the apps of the biggest Chinese social media platforms and web browsers
column2: giving them an instant entrée to users in Africa
column3: Southeast Asia
column4: South Asia
column5: and other regions
column6: although they have also been accused of coming preloaded with spyware.

column1: Chinese companies also are gaining ground in the global digital television market. They are no longer just copying foreign technologies but have become innovative and competitive. The Chinese pay television company StarTimes
column2: for example
column3: has become one of Africa's leading digital television operators. With its cheap TV packages and easy-to-install hardware
column4: it can reach formerly unserved populations from Kenya to Nigeria to Rwanda.

column1: 'The pay TV company [i.e.
column2: StarTimes] is leading the continent's transition from analog to digital television with some of the world's most affordable cable/satellite TV packages priced as low as $4 per month. In the burgeoning Digital TV sector
column3: StarTimes is far and away the market leader. The company's reach covers 90 percent of the continent's population
column4: ' wrote Eric Olander. StarTimes has announced nascent plans to expand its inexpensive services into Latin America as well.

column1: Other large Chinese companies are entering the digital and satellite television markets in Africa
column2: South Asia
column3: and Southeast Asia. ZTE has launched digital television services in Pakistan and is exploring other markets
column4: while Chinese provincial and national state television networks are expanding into neighboring Southeast Asian cable markets like Laos
column5: Timor-Leste
column6: and Vietnam.

column1: Influence Through Omission
By controlling the information pipes
column2: Beijing can exert influence through omission. In other words
column3: what does not appear about China in the media in other states can be as important as what does appear.

column1: Beijing wants to silence conversations about many topics – Xinjiang
column2: Tibet
column3: the South China Sea
column4: its  policies
column5: and so on. It wants to make these tough topics disappear. And if they disappear for an extended period of time from media coverage and public conversations in other countries
column6: that disappearance feeds on itself
column7: creating a greater boon for China. Publics and opinion leaders do not learn about these issues sensitive to China; over time
column8: publics and opinion leaders become less informed about these issues; with less information
column9: they naturally speak and write about the topics less and less.

column1: It is next to impossible for China to get positive coverage about these topics if they are covered openly and fairly. China could achieve this outcome
column2: of course
column3: through clear and open threats to punish other countries with economic measures
column4: diplomatic measures
column5: or other sanctions
column6: for instance. But the bullying approach
column7: though it certainly has worked with foreign companies and some foreign states fearful of being excluded from China's market or facing other sanctions from Beijing
column8: has major downsides as well.

column1: WeChat provides an opportunity for Beijing to help contain what appears in the news about China in other countries. As users outside China have gravitated to the app
column2: including its popular messaging service
column3: WeChat has become a central source of news for many Chinese-language speakers beyond the mainland. Wanning Sun
column4: of the University of Technology Sydney
column5: has found that while most Mandarin speakers in Australia do not get much of their news directly from Chinese state media
column6: a majority of them do access WeChat and obtain news from it
column7: such as from news shared in groups and messages. In fact
column8: Sun found that about 60 percent of Mandarin speakers in Australia used WeChat as their primary source of news and information.

Yet much of the news shared on WeChat stems from Xinhua
Global Times
column2: CGTN
column3: and other state media outlets
column4: which are controlled by Beijing and uncritical of the Chi";thediplomat.com;2310;economics;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2023-03-03-011107.jpg;False;;14.284565;a200ed645b6489191ff8f07e3bac8e0b;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND DSR'

column1: 11;Xi calls for more fruitful practical cooperation with Ecuador;zhangrui;2021-08-31 19:45:00;timezone unknown;https://english.cctv.com/2021/08/31/ARTIs5aVYXra7tKhdB3WJJ7R210831.shtml;cctv.com;Chinese President Xi Jinping said Monday that China is ready to work with Ecuador to achieve more results in bilateral practical cooperation and create more benefits for their peoples.;BEIJING

India last year built 36.4km of highway roads per day
column2: up from 28.04km per day the previous year
column3: in what Minister for Road Transport and Highways Nitin Gadkari described as a world record in a year of disruptions.

column1: The Covid-19 pandemic saw the country go into a 21-day nationwide lockdown in March last year that brought economic activity to a grinding halt.
Road construction is just one part of a government-planned infrastructure push to boost exports and attract foreign companies to the country to better compete with China.

column1: 20;China-Asean Digital Silk Road under construction: China Daily contributor;Zhai Kun;2021-07-26 06:30:00;timezone unknown;https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/china-asean-digital-silk-road-under-construction-china-daily-contributor;straitstimes.com;East Asia News -The writer says that a good digital governance framework is needed for both global and regional development.. Read more at straitstimes.com.;"BEIJING (CHINA DAILY/ASIA NEWS NETWORK) - Data is in a stage of rapid growth. According to Statista
column2: an international data organisation
column3: the amount of data generated worldwide reached 59 zettabytes (59 trillion gigabytes) in 2020 and may increase about 35 times by 2035.

column1: The economic value created by data is also booming. According to an International Data Corporation forecast in 2019
column2: the global data market will feature three major players by 2025 - with the Chinese data market accounting for about 28 per cent of the pie; the United States about 17.5 per cent; and the Europe
column3: Middle East and Africa region about 27.6 per cent.

column1: Platform-based multinational corporations are also growing rapidly and becoming monopolistic by controlling user data. At the end of 2019
column2: there were about 74 leading digital platform businesses in the world
column3: of which 35 were US companies and 30 Chinese. However
column4: the US has obvious comparative advantages in terms of market value
column5: with US digital platforms accounting for 74.1 per cent of the global total
column6: while Chinese platforms account for 22.5 per cent.

column1: The rapid development of the data economy has given rise to new forms of geopolitical competition. Countries and businesses can analyse and predict macroeconomic and social trends in other countries based on massive data collection and collation. However
column2: with data protectionism on the rise
column3: countries are increasingly opting for data encapsulation
column4: access restrictions
column5: and regulatory policies.

column1: In April 2020
column2: the US Agency for International Development released its first ever Digital Strategy
column3: which seeks to build a US-led international digital ecosystem through digital aid
column4: which adopts ""US values"" as the norm for digital foreign aid and attempts to build a US-centred international digital alliance.

column1: Some of the claims made in the strategy are confusing
column2: such as ""helping partner countries achieve self-reliance""
column3: which is in fact aimed at building an international digital alliance to maintain the interests of the US
column4: based on US technological strength.

column1: On the back of its huge data market and advantages in data economy
column2: the EU seeks to gain a greater say in the international digital rule-making and erect barriers to its data market by introducing the ""gatekeeping"" draft law
column3: increasing its budget allocation for the digital sector
column4: and beginning research into 6G standards
column5: with an aim of laying the foundation for long-term development in the digital area.

column1: The Quadrilateral Security Dialogue tech network
column2: which was launched in Canberra on Feb 9
column3: may lead to new changes in the international digital landscape. Participants include the National Security College of Australian National University; the Centre for a New American Security
column4: a US think tank; Japan's National Graduate Institute for Policy Studies and the Observer Research Foundation
column5: an Indian think tank.

column1: With the establishment of the Quad tech network
column2: the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue is gradually expanding its focus from conventional security to digital
column3: network and other non-conventional security fields
column4: which will also help refine the US' Indo-Pacific strategy by including the digital sector.

column1: Digitally small and medium-sized countries have also signed digital economy agreements and digital currency agreements to build secondary digital alliances away from China
column2: the US and the European Union. The signing of such agreements represents a new phase for global economic alliances. A network of digital economy agreements led by Singapore has been established. There are also constant calls for secondary digital partnerships.

column1: At present
column2: the Asia-Pacific region has become a major arena for digital competition
column3: with South-east Asia in the spotlight for major powers thanks to the huge potential of its digital economy
column4: in which China plays a crucial role. For geopolitical reasons
column5: South-east Asia is indispensable for the Indo-Pacific strategy of the US and the EU
column6: as well as the formation of secondary digital partnerships and the development of the global digital economy
column7: since it will become the fourth largest digital market in the world
column8: behind China
column9: the US and Europe.

column1: As global digital competition intensifies
column2: a good digital governance framework is needed for both global and regional development
column3: which is precisely the point of building the China-Asean Digital Silk Road.

column1: China is strengthening its digital economy cooperation with the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean)
column2: having established a ministerial dialogue mechanism for digital economy cooperation with Thailand
column3: signed Memorandums of Understanding (MOUs) on e-commerce cooperation with Vietnam and Cambodia respectively
column4: and started negotiations on a bilateral memorandum of understanding on cross-border e-commerce cooperation with Malaysia.

column1: China is also actively involved in the construction of digital infrastructure in Asean countries
column2: with the launch of Alibaba Cloud in Indonesia in 2018 and its expansion in 2020. Besides
column3: Chinese businesses partner with local Asean companies mostly through equity investment and mergers and acquisitions. China was the largest source of Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) for Asean tech startups from 2016 to the first half of 2019.

column1: One of the key factors for China-Asean digital economy cooperation is cross-border data cooperation
column2: which may serve as the catalyst for their greater strategic synergy. It is advisable that China and South-east Asian countries negotiate digital trade agreements while China and Asean set up a regional data and digital technology collaboration mechanism to drive digital cooperation in the form of industry- and business-led Asean integration.

column1: In East Asia
column2: China
column3: together with Asean and Singapore
column4: may design a regional digital currency package which includes the digital currencies of the Republic of Korea
column5: Japan and Singapore for a China-Asean digital currency toolbox to facilitate flows of capital and data and build a new digital governance model in the region.

column1: In the future
column2: multilateral diplomacy may also be leveraged via the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and China-EU Comprehensive Agreement on Investment for a China-Asean-EU trilateral cooperation platform to shape a broader area for international cooperation on the digital economy and its governance. Countries such as Japan and the Republic of Korea may also be included in due course to further extend the East Asian cooperation model on the digital economy.";straitstimes.com;1098;news;ID;en;['Zhai Kun'];https://static.straitstimes.com.sg/s3fs-public/styles/x_large/public/articles/2021/07/26/2021-07-20t035725z_2034684618_rc23oo98e8k3_rtrmadp_3_china-regulation-data.jpg?itok=Z2GXuMeO;False;@STCOM;22.52583;823cccb8d6f92e6d6b91021748641c05;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 21;Belt and Road Initiative a public road for public good: China Daily contributor;Xie Laihui;2021-04-21 03:45:00;full;https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/bri-a-public-road-for-public-good-china-daily-contributor;straitstimes.com;The writer says that by helping improve the economic situation in the region
column2: the Belt and Road Initiative will contribute to Asia's development and global recovery.. Read more at straitstimes.com.;"BEIJING (CHINA DAILY/ASIA NEWS NETWORK) - Addressing the Boao Forum for Asia through video link on Tuesday (April 20)
column3: President Xi Jinping said the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is a public road open to all
column4: not a private path owned by one single party.

column2: Belt and Road projects could help lift 7.6 million people from extreme poverty and 32 million people from moderate poverty across the world
column3: Mr Xi said
column4: citing a World Bank report.

column1: We will act in the spirit of openness and inclusiveness as we work with all willing participants to build the BRI into a pathway to poverty alleviation and growth
column2: which will contribute positively to the common prosperity of humankind
column3: he said. Themed ""A World in Change: Join Hands to Strengthen Global Governance and Advance Belt and Road Cooperation""
column4: the ongoing annual conference of the Boao Forum for Asia 2021 is aimed at deepening cooperation among Asian countries and improving global governance in the post-pandemic period.

column1: The theme of the conference being held in Hainan province from Sunday to Wednesday is indicative of how Asia
column2: and the rest of the world
column3: can recover from the pandemic-induced economic recession and boost development through cooperation.

column1: China proposed the Belt and Road Initiative to cope with the anti-globalisation trend in the aftermath of the global financial crisis
column2: and improve connectivity among related countries and regions through infrastructure construction
column3: and free and open trade. Indeed
column4: the initiative has played an important role in boosting the regional and global economies.

column1: For instance
column2: China-Europe freight trains transported anti-pandemic medicines and equipment as well as other products in 2020 even when many countries were under lockdown.

column1: Also
column2: trade between China and the European Union increased amid the global recession
column3: with China replacing the United States to become the EU's largest trade partner.

column1: Besides
column2: China's non-financial direct investment in Belt and Road countries in 2020 reached US$17.79 billion (S$23.5 billion)
column3: up 18.3 per cent year-on-year
column4: which proves the initiative has been facilitating economic and trade development. However
column5: in the post-epidemic period
column6: the Belt and Road cooperation mechanism needs to be further improved in order to promote more balanced economic development.

column1: To begin with
column2: since the 10 Asean member states
column3: and China
column4: Japan
column5: the Republic of Korea
column6: Australia and New Zealand have inked the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership agreement
column7: they should accelerate the process of ratifying the pact to build a high-quality free trade network in the Asia-Pacific region with the aim of helping boost global economic growth.

column1: The digital economy is another sector that has drawn increasing attention since the novel coronavirus pandemic broke out.
The combination of artificial intelligence
column2: 5G technology
column3: big data and cloud computing can give rise to new consumption and economic growth patterns.

column1: And with digital payment and digital currency becoming increasingly popular
column2: countries will discuss how to avoid potential risks and strengthen international coordination on risk management.

column1: And the ""Digital Silk Road""
column2: an important part of the Belt and Road Initiative
column3: can help countries build digital infrastructure and facilitate their digital transformation.

column1: As achieving sustainable development remains a challenge
column2: the major goal of global governance should be to promote ""green recovery"" and realise the 17 goals of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

column1: And since Asia is a densely populated region
column2: Asian approaches should be explored to realise global sustainable development centred on green and circular economy
column3: and focused more on regional development
column4: including poverty reduction
column5: rural sustainable development
column6: using and protecting seas and marine resources

column1: While unilateralism and trade protectionism - along with the pandemic - have pushed the global economy into recession and destabilised the global financial system
column2: it's important for Asia and the rest of the world to help build a consensus among major countries to promote multilateralism in global governance by defending the global trade order with the World Trade Organisation at its core.

column1: The WTO member states
column2: on their part
column3: should help the global trade body to adapt to the changes in the global economy
column4: especially the technology revolution and global trade and investment rules.

column1: And the WTO needs to ensure all its member states can benefit from its organisational reform.
There is also a need to improve the international monetary and financing systems
column2: and increase global coordination to strengthen financial support to emerging markets and developing countries
column3: and establish a sustainable fund-raising system.

column1: And improving connectivity and increasing investment in the Asian and global financial markets will facilitate the development of the financial sector.
In short
column2: by helping improve the economic situation in the region
column3: the Belt and Road Initiative will contribute to Asia's development and global recovery.

column1: The author is executive director of the Department of the BRI Studies at the National Institute of International Strategy
column2: Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. China Daily is a member of The Straits Times media partner Asia News Network
column3: an alliance of 23 news media organisations.";straitstimes.com;1098;news;ID;en;['Xie Laihui'];https://static.straitstimes.com.sg/s3fs-public/styles/x_large/public/articles/2021/04/21/file7f9ipdwo1qd1mofv77aa.jpg?itok=0933PzKu;False;@STCOM;21.632763;c3b5d21ae963323d5ed85c053acc3352;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 23;Activists fear rising surveillance from Asia's 'Digital Silk Road';;2022-09-19 01:25:41;full;https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/activists-fear-rising-surveillance-from-asias-digital-silk-road;straitstimes.com;As China drives adoption of surveillance tech
column2: state AI-based systems target activists
column3: protesters. Read more at straitstimes.com.;"PHNOM PENH - The drones were hard to avoid: They buzzed low over the crowd of protesters holding banners and shouting slogans outside the NagaWorld casino in the Cambodian city of Phnom Penh
column4: then hovered above each of the speakers as they called for justice.

column1: As hundreds of workers went on strike outside the glass and chrome towers of the firm's hotel and casino complex
column2: demanding the reinstatement of nearly 400 employees who were laid off last year
column3: armed riot police and surveillance cameras kept watch.

column1: We knew we were being recorded
column2: but we couldn't do anything
column3: so we would wave at the drones
column4: said Ms Chhim Sithar
column6: a union leader who was arrested at the January protest along with more than a dozen others
column7: and held in jail for nine weeks. Hong Kong-listed NagaCorp said the strike that began in December was illegal
column8: and that the layoffs were a ""mutual separation plan"" to cut costs during the Covid-19 pandemic.

column1: Municipal police have said the workers' strike was illegal and a threat to public order and safety. Police charged some protesters with ""incitement to cause serious chaos to social security"".
Ms Chhim Sithar and other Cambodian rights activists say they are under constant surveillance
column2: their every move online and offline tracked by software
column3: cameras and drones. Much of the technology is supplied by China
column4: which sells extensive digital surveillance packages to governments under its Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) infrastructure project. Chinese President Xi Jinping launched BRI in 2013
column5: aiming to harness China's strengths in financing and infrastructure construction to ""build a broad community of shared interests"" across Asia
column6: Africa and Latin America.

column1: China has installed more than 1
column2: 000 CCTV cameras in Phnom Penh as part of a new nationwide surveillance system
column3: according to local media reports.

column1: Cambodian government spokesman Phay Siphan denied that the technologies are used to target activists and union leaders. ""The CCTVs and other surveillance infrastructure are for security purposes
column2: to fight crime
column3: and traffic violations and other illegal actions
column4: he told Reuters.

column1: China influence
While the authorities justify surveillance on security grounds
column2: human rights groups have raised concerns about privacy violations and the potential for profiling and discrimination
column3: with the technologies often deployed without public consultation
column4: and in the absence of strong data protection laws.

column1: Countries taking part in BRI are using technologies
column2: including artificial intelligence-based facial recognition systems linked to abuse of minority Uighurs in China for smart policing or smart cities programmes
column3: and digital tools for monitoring social media sites.

column1: These tools offer new possibilities for tracking and intimidating dissenters
column2: monitoring political opponents
column3: and preempting challenges to the government
column4: said Mr Steven Feldstein
column5: a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace
column6: a think-tank based in Washington.

column1: In authoritarian settings
column2: these capabilities have obvious potential to deepen repression
column3: said Mr Feldstein
column4: who estimates that Chinese artificial intelligence surveillance technologies are being rolled out in more than 50 BRI countries.

column1: A key part of China's BRI programme is the so-called Digital Silk Road - an initiative that aims to build modern telecom and data infrastructure among nations lying on the ancient Silk Road trade route.
Chinese involvement ranges from its tech firms building submarine internet cables
column2: data centres and mobile towers
column3: to nations copying its cyber laws and Internet gateways to control the flow of data and information
column4: said a recent report by the Alliance to Secure Democracy (ASD)
column5: a US-based think-tank.

column1: There is a risk that the Chinese state may be able to amass data - whether it's genetic surveillance information or more traditional information about political opinions or activity through these systems
column2: said Ms Lindsay Gorman
column3: a senior fellow for emerging technologies at ASD.

column1: There is a real question about where the data that fuels these surveillance systems is stored
column2: who owns it and who benefits from it
column3: she said.

column1: Chinese authorities have said tech monitoring is vital to combat crime and prevent the spread of Covid-19
column2: and has denied reports that it is using tech to enable abuse of Uighurs.

column1: 'We are all afraid'
In Myanmar
column2: where the military overthrew an elected government last year and launched a bloody crackdown on protests and dissent
column3: Chinese firms are deploying 4G and 5G networks
column4: as well as facial recognition systems in several cities.

column1: The junta has adopted cyber laws that echo China's
column2: including limiting Internet access to certain websites and banning social media platforms such as Facebook and Twitter.

column1: A spokesperson for the junta did not respond to a request for comment. Officials earlier said facial recognition systems are needed to maintain security and ""civil peace"".
But reports of the use of CCTV and facial recognition to target protesters have made Hsu
column2: a lawyer who provides legal aid to political prisoners in the city of Mandalay
column3: ""more afraid"".

column1: The police submit CCTV records as evidence in the court
column2: so we know it is dangerous for the activists
column3: said Hsu
column5: using a pseudonym for fear of reprisal. ""When I went to prison to meet with jailed activists
column6: I would wear a mask - not because I was scared of COVID-19
column7: but because I wanted to hide my face. ""We are all afraid of the CCTV.""

column1: Being watched
Worldwide
column2: the rise of AI technologies have led to the proliferation of mass surveillance systems
column3: including face recognition and voice identification for a range of uses
column4: from tracking criminals to marking student attendance.

column1: Technology has changed the nature of how governments carry out surveillance and what they choose to monitor
column2: said Mr Feldstein.

column1: In Cambodia
column2: where the authorities are building a national internet gateway - similar to China's Internet firewall that blocks websites and social media platforms - there is little transparency around these systems
column3: said Ms Chak Sopheap at the Cambodian Centre for Human Rights
column4: a nonprofit.

column1: The government has disclosed no information as to the data gathered
column2: and how they are used by the authorities. This lack of transparency is highly problematic
column3: she said. ""The use of such technologies affects the right to privacy of people
column4: especially those who do not support the government
column5: and provides Cambodian authorities with an additional tool to crack down on critical voices and dissidents.""

column1: In Phnom Penh
column2: labour leader Chhim Sithar and her fellow protesters are adapting: They do more in-person meetings
column3: where they turn off their phones
column4: they use virtual private networks and encrypted chat groups and refrain from posting on social media.

column1: This feeling of being watched and tracked all the time is exhausting
column2: she said. ""We cannot do anything without the police knowing - it's scary."" column1: 24;US aims to raise $280b as part of G-7 rival to China's Belt & Road;;2022-06-26 15:33:42;full;https://www.straitstimes.com/world/us-aims-to-raise-280b-as-part-of-g-7-rival-to-chinas-belt-road;straitstimes.com;Notably absent will be French President Macron who had formally joined the Chinese infrastructure program. Read more at straitstimes.com.;"WASHINGTON (REUTERS) - The United States aims to raise US$200 billion (S$280 billion) in private and public funds over five years to fund needed infrastructure in developing countries under a G-7 initiative aimed at countering China's multitrillion-dollar Belt and Road project
column2: the White House said on Sunday (June 26).

column1: US President Joe Biden will unveil the plans
column2: flanked by other Group of Seven leaders
column3: some of whom have already unveiled their own separate initiatives
column4: at their annual gathering being held this year at Schloss Elmau in southern Germany.

column1: Increasingly worried about China
column2: G-7 leaders first floated plans for the project last year
column3: and are formally launching it now under a fresh title
column4: ""Partnership for Global Infrastructure and Investment"" while dropping the moniker ""Build Back Better World"" first coined by Biden during his presidential campaign. Mr Biden will unveil several specific projects at a G-7 side event
column5: joined by leaders from Britain
column6: Germany
column8: the European Union and Canada
column9: vowing to focus on projects that help tackle climate change as well as improve global health
column10: gender equity and digital infrastructure.

column1: Notably absent will be French President Emmanuel Macron who had formally joined the Chinese infrastructure program.
The president's not thinking that we need to spend dollar for dollar versus China ... though if you add up what the US and the G-7 partners are going to be announcing

column1: Thailand's protests shift gear

A coalition of political and civic groups called ""Re-Solution"" launched a campaign last week to collect a million signatures to amend Thailand's Constitution - a goal broadly similar to that of the youth protests that roiled the country for much of the past year. But it has one key difference from the previous movement.

column1: Hong Kong's silent outsiders
Hong Kong's foreign-born residents describe how they continue to be treated like outsiders after decades of living in the cosmopolitan business hub that calls itself 'Asia's World City'
column2: Hong Kong correspondent Claire Huang reports in the latest instalment of our Invisible Asia series.

column1: On a daily basis
column2: these Hong Kong residents face varying degrees of discrimination and micro-aggressions. People in the ethnic majority aren't spared either
column3: with the lines of segregation shifting as ethnic otherness gets eclipsed by a politicised cultural war driven by anti-mainlandism. Watch the video on YouTube

column2: US correspondent Charissa Yong writes in our weekly Power Play column. Climate change was an oasis of rare agreement at the heated Sino-US talks in Alaska last month
column3: but the path ahead is still lined with potential pitfalls.

Are Asians more prone to looking away from the liberal order as a trade-in for what they interpret as ""order""
column2: Associate editor Ravi Velloor muses in his latest column as he outlines signs of increasingly autocratic leadership around the region. Strongmen are an uneasy fit anywhere
column3: because excessive centralisation of power is dangerous
column4: he says. But when such leaders seem to thrive
column5: questions arise as to what it takes to keep democracy alive.

column1: 27;Seizing Asia's investment moment in an increasingly multipolar world;;2021-11-14 20:00:00;full;https://www.straitstimes.com/business/invest/seizing-asias-investment-moment-in-an-increasingly-multipolar-world;straitstimes.com;Viewing Asia through a fresh framework is the direction international investors and business leaders should consider heading
column2: and South-east Asia is benefiting from previous growth waves and from…;"A new phase of globalisation is unfolding – one that is likely to see Asia as one of the key pillars in a multipolar world. Therefore
column3: PineBridge Investments believes it's time for international investors and business leaders to view Asia through a fresh framework.

column1: After three growth waves spanning many decades – from post-war Japan to the industrialisation of the East Asian Tigers and
column2: more recently
column3: China's rise – Asia is now moving away from supply-chain-based economies. Like never before
column4: its young and growing consumer class is leveraging converging trends as digital technology combines with demographic advantages and policy improvements. The fourth growth wave now building could culminate by pulling the world's economic centre of gravity east
column5: just as the global balance of power is shifting to a multipolar world where technological
column6: economic and geopolitical power is not concentrated in the hands of a single country

column1: For business leaders and investors to effectively position for Asia's long-term opportunities
column2: PineBridge believes it will be key to understand the context and the dynamics of underlying trends in the region and how they impact the rest of the world. Here
column3: the firm shares three consequential developments that investors and business leaders should be watching closely. The fourth wave.

column1: With a nearly 700 million-strong population
column2: South-east Asia is poised to produce 140 million new young consumers
column3: nearly a fifth of the world's total
column4: over the next decade.1 The rise of South-east Asia's economies converging with China's continued economic momentum will power the fourth wave of growth in Asia.

column1: South-east Asia is benefiting from previous growth waves and from Chinese investments. Despite Covid-19-induced challenges
column2: the Beijing-led Belt and Road Initiative continues to provide a platform for upgrading critical infrastructure in the region
column3: with China's priority seemingly evolving towards more green-energy projects and technology-related investments
column4: with talk of a 'green silk road' and 'digital silk road'.2
column5: 3 Asia's Infra King: China

column1: Infrastructure investment as a percentage of GDP (2017)
SOURCE: IMF
column2: Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank/Economist Intelligence Unit
column3: as at 2019. For illustrative purposes only. PineBridge Investments is not soliciting or recommending any action based on this material.

column1: Asian tech leaving the West in its wake?
Once confined to outsourced manufacturing or accused of copying Western technology
column2: Asian companies are increasingly category-definers. China's largest tech companies compete internationally in artificial intelligence
column3: cloud computing and entertainment. While Chinese regulators have recently stepped up scrutiny on some tech business models
column4: causing short-term uncertainty for the sector
column5: the long-term arc still looks to bend in China's economic favour. The world was already in an upcycle of digitalisation and automation pre-Covid-19
column6: and that transition could further benefit Asia. Singapore
column8: for example
column9: already lead the world in robot density in manufacturing.

column1: Governments are also pioneering digital innovation in everything from identification to currencies. A shift to digital currencies could represent a big leap for financial inclusion and consumer spending – again bolstering the region's overall economic clout.
The green energy revolution.
Ninety-nine of the world's 100 most environmentally exposed cities are in Asia
column2: as are 13 of the top 20 cities projected to suffer a major increase in losses from flooding.4
column3: 5 This makes a 'green transition' an urgent priority.

column1: According to Boston Consulting Group (BCG)
column2: Asia-Pacific investment over the next 20 years will bring 2
column3: 673GW of renewable energy online by 2040
column4: more than double Europe's projected installed capacity and over three times that in North America over the same period.6

column1: China
column2: still the largest carbon emitter in the world
column3: 7 also has the world's largest battery electric-vehicle (EV) market and is projected to see the sharpest growth in the years ahead
column4: with 2014-2015 marking a key turning point relative to the US market.

column1: Exponential EVs

column1: An Asia-centric destiny?
That's not to say that Asia's path is fully paved. The US-China tensions
column2: Beijing's own regulatory reforms to promote greater social equality
column3: Covid-19's continued threat and climate change are all sources of uncertainty.

column1: The geopolitical flare-up between the world's two largest economies is having complex repercussions
column2: driving investment into other countries as multinationals de-risk their China operations and forcing technology buyers and sellers to consider separate tech stacks
column3: which could balloon everyone's costs.

column1: China's heightened scrutiny of activities it deems counter to 'common prosperity' may suggest a volatile business environment for investors. However
column2: in the long run
column3: the impact may be positive on the whole.

column1: We can't predict the future. However
column2: PineBridge believes that the weight of evidence tilts towards the age of Asia
column3: with compelling opportunities for discerning investors. This is a long-term story set to play out over a decade or more as China edges into the No. 1 spot on GDP charts and South-east Asia's young workers
column4: consumers and entrepreneurs push the region to become a key source of influence in a multipolar world.

column1: 28;Many opportunities for Singapore-based logistics firms in Cambodia: Roundtable;GRACE HO
column2: Grace Ho;2021-04-20 09:48:37;full;https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/politics/many-opportunities-for-singapore-based-logistics-firms-in-cambodia-roundtable;straitstimes.com;Politics News -It said such opportunities would be enabled by Cambodia's vibrant trade environment and consistent growth.. Read more at straitstimes.com.;"SINGAPORE - Given Cambodia's vibrant trade environment and consistent growth over the last decade
column3: there are many opportunities there for Singapore-based firms and international partners to explore projects to boost regional connectivity.

column1: This was the key theme of a roundtable organised by Infrastructure Asia and Singapore's YCH Group on Tuesday (April 20) to connect local logistics firms with potential partners to develop and finance the Phnom Penh Logistics Complex (PPLC).
Plans for the PPLC
column2: which is estimated to cost US$200 million (S$265 million)
column3: include an integrated port and logistics operations centre
column4: training academy and start-up hub. A framework agreement to develop the project was inked last month between the logistics company and Cambodia's Ministry of Public Works and Transport.

column1: More than 30 representatives from Surbana Jurong
column2: DBS Bank
column3: OCBC Bank
column4: Clifford Capital
column5: China Construction Bank
column6: the International Finance Corporation and Silk Road Fund
column8: attended the roundtable in person and virtually.

column1: Stressing the collaborative nature of the PPLC
column2: Infrastructure Asia executive director Seth Tan said a critical success factor is the Cambodian government's involvement - from earmarking land to develop the port
column3: to setting up meetings between YCH and government agencies to better understand the project details. ""The collaboration between the (Cambodian) government and YCH is quite extensive
column4: and it is this element that gives it a higher chance of success and minimises costs as well
column5: he said.

column1: Infrastructure Asia
column2: a joint initiative by Enterprise Singapore and the Monetary Authority of Singapore
column3: was set up to connect governments with developers
column4: professional service providers and financiers for the region's infrastructure needs.

column1: The PPLC is part of the Smart Growth Connect Initiative by the Asean Business Advisory Council.
It is the second project under the Asean Smart Logistics Network
column2: which supports the Asean Connectivity Master Plan 2025 - a road map to seamlessly connect and integrate the regional bloc. The first project
column3: launched in November and also helmed by YCH
column4: is a joint venture with Vietnam's T&T Group to develop a logistics centre and port in Vietnam.

column1: The PPLC stands to boost Cambodia's economic growth and connectivity
column2: especially with the Mekong region and south-western China.

column1: Contract preparation and groundbreaking for the project are slated to take place in 2022
column2: which is also the year in which Cambodia will assume the rotating chairmanship of Asean.

column1: Singapore firms have been making forays into Cambodia over the years.
In January
column2: local waste management company 800 Super
column3: with its joint venture partner in Cambodia GAEA Waste Management
column4: was awarded a 10-year contract for waste collection and transportation in the country's capital Phnom Penh. YCH Group chairman Robert Yap said that Cambodia has consistently registered high single-digit gross domestic product growth and has the potential to go further.

column1: Cambodia's logistics infrastructure is not that well developed today

column1: 30;Diversity in ink;;2021-05-12 21:00:00;full;https://www.straitstimes.com/life/arts/diversity-in-ink;straitstimes.com;"Say ""Cheong Soo Pieng"" and people will think of the late artist's paintings of almond-eyed Balinese women. Others will recall the 1978 work Drying Salted Fish
column2: which appears on the back of Singapore's…";"Say ""Cheong Soo Pieng"" and people will think of the late artist's paintings of almond-eyed Balinese women. Others will recall the 1978 work Drying Salted Fish
column3: which appears on the back of Singapore's $50 note.

column1: But the pioneer master's practice was more diverse and innovative than casual observers give him credit for.
People always think of Soo Pieng's art as one of two types - the 1950s Nanyang style or the thin-limbed Balinese ladies
column2: says Mr Ho Sou Ping
column4: founder of Artcommune gallery. ""That's only like 5 per cent of his practice. People have a superficial view of Soo Pieng
column5: but his work is so rich
column6: so diverse."" To encourage the public to learn more about this pioneer Singapore artist
column7: Mr Ho's gallery is mounting a retrospective of more than 100 of Cheong's ink works.

column1: Tonalities: The Ink Works Of Cheong Soo Pieng opens at Artspace@Helutrans in Tanjong Pagar Distripark tomorrow and runs till June 13.
In recent years
column2: a number of the master's classicist ink paintings from 1978 to 1982 - on paper
column3: silk
column4: cloth and canvas - have surfaced
column5: Mr Ho says. This allowed the gallery to do more research on this understudied phase and ""flesh out a comprehensive narrative arc"". The exhibition features ink works from the early 1950s to 1983 and covering four themes - portraiture
column6: landscape
column7: Europe and ""Nanyang scrolls"". They are on loan from more than 20 collectors and nearly half are being exhibited for the first time.

column1: Tonalities is curated by Mr Tan Yong Jun
column2: 28. The independent researcher and curator
column3: who recently wrote a book about the artist
column4: says: ""Cheong Soo Pieng's ink works are often overshadowed by his oil and canvas works. There's a variety of reasons for this
column5: not least the fine arts' prejudice against paper works.""

column1: Cheong also did a lot of innovative work in oil and mixed media
column2: metal and cloisonne in the late 1960s and early 1970s
column3: so it is ""understandable that these would define that period of Soo Pieng's career""
column4: says Mr Tan.

column1: But the ink works from that period are ""very interesting""
column2: he says. ""His kampungs became in the style of - if you want to peg it to an art movement - lyrical abstraction."" Cheong had left for Europe in 1961 under the patronage of Cathay cinema magnate Loke Wan Tho. He continued making art there
column3: including a series of ink and oil works shown in a breakthrough solo show at London's Redfern Gallery in 1963.

column1: WHERE Artspace@Helutrans
column2: 01-05 Tanjong Pagar Distripark
column3: 39 Keppel Road

column1: WHEN Tomorrow to June 13
column2: noon to 7pm daily. The venue is closed this Saturday for a private event. Public tours will run on May 22
column4: 29 and 30 at 2 to 3pm. To register
column5: e-mail valerie@artcommune.com.sg

column1: ADMISSION Free
INFO Go to artcommune.com.sg. The hardcover publication Tonalities: The Ink Works Of Cheong Soo Pieng ($100) by Tan Yong Jun is available for purchase at Artcommune gallery at Carlton Hotel Singapore
column2: as well as at Artspace@Helutrans
column3: during the exhibition

column1: Artist Cheong Soo Pieng
column2: in a picture taken in 1969. PHOTO: ST FILE

column1: The Europe works are also known as the ""Zao Wou-Ki series"" - given their similarities with works by the Chinese-French artist - and are shown alongside old sketches
column2: news articles and other contemporary material in the Artcommune show.

column1: Before this
column2: Soo Pieng's works were more strict in formalism and adhered to received ideas about modern painting
column3: says Mr Tan. ""After that
column4: his vision was broadened and he became comfortable seeking his own painterly road to modernity.""

column1: Back in Singapore in 1963
column2: he moved away from his Cubist styles of the 1950s and painted kampungs that were atmospheric rather than realistic.

column1: Mr Tan calls them ""surrealist-inspired mindscapes"". The artist
column2: he adds
column3: could have been hinting that such scenes
column4: amid the rapid urbanisation of Singapore
column5: were present only in his mind.

column1: Cheong has long been hailed as one of Singapore's greatest artists.
He was born in Amoy
column2: China
column3: in 1917. He migrated to Singapore in 1946 at the age of 29 and taught at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts.

column1: Like other pioneer artists
column2: he often painted in the Nanyang style
column3: an East-meets-West aesthetic associated with artists from South-east Asia.

column1: He was inspired by his travels
column2: not just by the Europe trip
column3: but also a seminal 1952 journey to Bali with fellow artists Liu Kang
column4: Chen Wen Hsi and Chen Chong Swee
column5: as well as a stay in a Borneo longhouse in 1959 that sparked a lifelong interest in the indigenous Dayak people.

column1: His paintings of the Dayak people are shown in the exhibition.
Mr Tan
column2: comparing them with the Balinese figures
column3: thinks they show a deeper understanding of local culture. ""He had a very clear
column4: concise and accurate idea of each Dayak tribe he painted. We could identify whether he was painting the Iban or Kenyah (tribes) based on the patterns they were wearing or the architecture of the long house.""

column1: Cheong received many plaudits in his lifetime
column2: including the Meritorious Service Medal for his contributions to Singapore art.

column1: After embarking on a return trip to China in 1979
column2: he delved deeper into Song Dynasty aesthetics in paintings that reimagined Chinese classicism. He also rolled out a series of Nanyang scrolls
column3: which were often painted on South-east Asian materials such as rattan.

column1: Arts of the 1980s should include applied arts
column2: include the representative arts of the Nanyang
column3: Cheong wrote in a 1980 article in Chinese daily Sin Chew Jit Poh.

column1: He added: ""The only way for a Nanyang style to emerge is to start working from these materials.""
Versatile artist a man of few words

column2: the National Museum Art Gallery organised a retrospective of Cheong's works.

column1: Sadly
column2: he did not live to see it. Four months before the exhibition
column3: he died of heart failure at the age of 66.

column1: In an article several months after his death
column2: his second son Cheong Teng remarked: ""Out of 365 days of the year
column3: he painted 360.""

column1: The late artist was famously reticent - a journalist's nightmare
column2: suggests one 1983 Straits Times article.

column1: He was a man of few words
column2: he didn't talk much
column3: former student Lin Hsin Hsin was quoted in the piece as saying. ""He did visual thinking and only talked when very interested in the subject.""

column1: Lin
column3: is now a veteran digital artist whose works are part of ongoing National Gallery Singapore exhibition Something New Must Turn Up.

column1: One of the challenges scholars face when they study Cheong is a dearth of primary information.
Mr Tan says: ""Until now
column2: we have discovered a grand total of one article by him - as opposed to Liu Kang and Chen Chong Swee's writings
column3: which have been made into books
column4: or Chen Wen Hsi's lengthy oral histories. He was most comfortable explaining himself in his paintings.""

column1: One of the art collectors who contributed to the show is Mr Francis Choo
column3: who lent the 1959 Borneo-inspired Long House.

column1: It struck me as a very typical Cheong Soo Pieng composition - very well-composed
column2: extremely sensitive to the subject matter
column3: says the vice-president of a multinational IT company.

column1: Cheong Soo Pieng is very versatile. He is probably the most well-rounded artist Singapore has produced
column2: he adds.

column1: Prominent architect and art lover Koh Seow Chuan notes the use of negative space in Cheong's 1980s Chinese ink paintings.
He wanted to explore the limits of Song dynasty composition
column2: of positiveness and negativeness
column3: and how they coexist to make a painting you can meditate on
column4: says Mr Koh in a video posted by the gallery. column1: 36;Commentary: Did the world just get a second Belt and Road Initiative?;;2021-06-17 22:30:00;timezone unknown;https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/commentary/build-back-better-world-belt-road-china-g7-how-compares-15031808;channelnewsasia.com;The Build Back Better World plan builds on past US efforts to boost international infrastructure financing and is not necessarily aimed at ...;HONG KONG: There has been much hype around the announcement by the G7 of the Build Back Better World (B3W) initiative as a counter measure to China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI).But a nuanced understanding of the B3W reveals a more complex set of objectives depending on who you ask. For one
column2: the B3W is not new.While hailed as a new initiative under the Joe Biden administration
column3: the idea of an alternative infrastructure programme to China's was initiated under President Donald Trump ‘s administration under the ambit of the bipartisan Better Utilisation of Investments to Development At (BUILD) Act passed by the House and Senate and signed into law by Trump in 2018.READ: Commentary: G7 summit proved the world has shifted after TrumpREAD: Commentary: We need to talk about how Donald Trump's presidency wasn't a complete disaster BUILDING ON THE BUILD ACTCentral to the BUILD programme was less the objective of countering China and more the aim to encourage private sector investment into developing countries that would reduce the need for US foreign aid.The focus was on funding hard infrastructure
column4: such as electricity
column5: that would help less developed countries attract investment to grow their way out of poverty.The BUILD Act also had the mandate to invest up to US$60 billion in private sector investment to fight extreme poverty. The US would do this by converting the US Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) into a new international Development Finance Corporation (USIDFC) with modernised financing capabilities
column6: including the ability to provide equity financing
column7: local currency loans and guarantees. Then US President Donald Trump. (Photo: AFP/CHIP SOMODEVILLA) This new USIDFC
column8: established under the BUILD Act
column9: would make loans
column10: invest in and forge partnerships with those wanting to do business in low- to middle-income countries as a minority investor.MOUDLING INTERNATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE FINANCINGIt was only in 2019 that the USIDFC gained international muscle through the mooting of a Blue Dot Network (BDN) in which the US joined forces with Japan and Australia but remained open to other countries joining the network in supporting high-quality
column11: private sector led investments. Framed in terms of countering Chinese influence under an Indo-Pacific strategy
column12: the BDN would indeed offer an alternative to China's BRI and tap into the US$1.3 trillion dollars in trade volume between China and the countries along the BRI in 2018.It would fill the demand for international infrastructure financing with a US model through mobilising private capital while giving governments skin in the game in mitigating endemic risks including political
column13: legal and social risks.But it was clear the three countries couldn't do it on their own. Enter the B3W.The B3W is an extension of the BDN. At a high level
column14: the B3W and BDN appear to be guided by similar policy and principal guidelines in meeting the development needs of the poorer countries subscribing to agreed standards like the G20 Principles for Quality Infrastructure Investment endorsed in Osaka in 2019.By mobilising private sector capital
column15: the B3W's funding is aimed at addressing four specific areas (i.e.
column16: climate
column19: and gender equity)
column20: enlisting an 'alliance of democracies' to project soft power driven by common values
column21: good governance and established standards.READ: Commentary: The US needs a new China strategyREAD: Commentary: Joe Biden's quietly revolutionary first 100 daysIndeed
column22: the B3W announcement has been positioned as a 'democratic' alternative to the BRI and a foreign policy move by the US to showcase President Biden's foreign relations credentials
column23: signal that the US is back and shore up the US's influence in transatlantic relations
column24: after a dismal four years under Trump.But even amid all that puffery
column25: US allies are wary of isolating China
column26: with UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson at the G7 expressing a desire to frame this as a 'green BRI' granting access to financing for low-carbon projects like clean energy that 'shows who we are

column32: 2021. (Ben Stansall/Pool Photo via AP) ​​​​​​​While planning to offer a US$100 billion a year in alterative loans
column33: the G7 has collectively signalled it is more keen on a path forward less seen as a challenge of China and more a framework in which G7 nations can still engage with China.Even within the US
column34: some politicians rather call this the 'Green Marshall Plan'
column35: to avoid demonising the BRI.THE DRAWBACKS OF THE B3WPerhaps the better question is whether the B3W can credibly rival the BRI. The answer is less certain. The B3W after all is playing catch-up. Being a nascent idea
column36: the B3W naturally lacks a clear pathway forward that helps developing countries access global trade and build their respective economies.  In comparison
column37: the eight-year-old BRI has an integrated
column38: regional infrastructure development plan based on supply chain considerations connecting markets via integrated port-rail-road transport networks.READ: Commentary: Just how much do China's Belt and Road projects benefit recipient countries?READ: Commentary: We sure believe some weird stuff about China's Belt and Road InitiativeNot only has the BRI created employment in local markets in the construction phase
column39: it has also facilitated commercial sustainability by enhancing access to export markets.Another advantage that the BRI has is the Digital Silk Road that overlays the BRI
column40: digitally connecting even the most remote of markets
column41: with BRI countries obliged to use the digital network and standards of China when doing trade. But the B3W does not impose this level of integration.The challenge also is how the B3W will treat projects with significant carbon footprints commonplace in developing countries.Under the B3W investment criteria
column42: there would be no funding given to coal-fired power stations but developing countries might have few credible energy alternatives. Meanwhile
column43: under China's BRI green investment guidelines
column44: funding would be given to high-efficiency low-emissions coal power stations.READ: Commentary: China's foreign loans
column46: is full of ‘Chinese characteristics'It also remains unclear whether the B3W private sector funding model
column47: funded by patient capital including pension funds
column48: insurance companies and other private investors
column49: will be able to catalyse development on the scale of the BRI
column50: which uses China's vast foreign exchange reserves and financing from state banks to back projects.For now
column51: it is difficult to see how the B3W can rival the cooperation agreements with 140 countries and 31 international organisations enjoyed by China's BRI.TIMING IS EVERYTHINGThen again
column52: COVID-19 has exposed a number of shortcomings of the BRI
column53: particularly with 20 per cent of BRI projects being put on hold. China is advancing plans to build the new carbon-belching power stations abroad as part of its trillion-dollar Belt and Road Initiative. (Photo: AFP/Rizwan TABASSUM) These project delays have highlighted the fundamental problem afflicting many BRI projects of a lack of upfront due diligence with the result being that many BRI projects have often simply traded speed early in the project cycle for far more difficult problems later.Tied financing that favour the use of Chinese contractors and opaque practices have also been associated with cost blow-outs and corruption scandals
column54: most infamously in the case of the East Coast Rail Link project in Malaysia.And with several countries now challenging China's claims that BRI had been built on mutual respect
column55: strong people-to-people bonds and non-interference in national sovereignty
column56: there is a window of opportunity for the B3W to make itself more relevant.Andre Wheeler is chief executive of Asia Pacific Connex and has 20 years of international business experience in the US and Asia-Pacific.;channelnewsasia.com;1591;news;SG;en;[];https://cna-sg-res.cloudinary.com/image/upload/q_auto

column1: 38;Commentary: The rise and further rise of Bitcoin;;2021-01-08 22:00:51;full;https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/commentary/bitcoin-stock-price-2020-2021-outlook-exchange-13919858;channelnewsasia.com;Wherever the price goes from here

column3: England: Bitcoin achieved a remarkable rise in 2020 in spite of many things that would normally make investors wary
column4: including US-China tensions
column5: Brexit and
column6: of course
column7: an international pandemic.From a year-low on the daily charts of US$4
column9: 490) in the middle of March as pandemic fears took hold
column10: bitcoin rose to just below US$30
column11: 000 by the end of the year. Since then it has climbed to all-time highs above US$38
column13: making headlines day after day and driving up the prices of other cryptocurrencies at the same time. .So what has driven this huge price appreciation and is it different to the bubble of 2017?One reason for the massive price rise is that there has been a big influx of investors from large-scale institutions such as pension schemes
column14: university endowment funds and investment trusts.This was not the case during the last bull market in 2017
column15: in which the bitcoin price rose about 20-fold to almost US$20
column17: only to slide back to the low US$3
column19: the cryptocurrency ecosystem was dominated by individual retail investors
column20: many of whom were attracted to bitcoin's scarcity and the fact that it stood outside the global financial system.The 2017 bull market had all the signs of a classic financial bubble and investors who were buying in 'fear of missing out' (FOMO).THE MOVE MAINSTREAMThis time
column21: big names such as billionaire investor Paul Tudor Jones and insurance giant MassMutual have invested heavily
column22: while even former naysayers like JP Morgan now say that bitcoin could have a bright future.  This all helps to increase trust in the cryptocurrency and indicates that it is becoming more mainstream. A representation of virtual currency bitcoin is seen in front of a stock graph in this illustration taken Nov 19
column23: 2020. (Photo: REUTERS/Dado Ruvic) Bitcoin has also been backed by a few large consumer-facing payment names. PayPal now allows customers to buy
column24: hold and sell bitcoin directly from their PayPal accounts.Rival digital payment firm Square reported in November that more of its Cash App users are buying the digital currency
column25: and buying more on average than before.The number of vendors accepting bitcoin as a form of payment is growing rapidly.Possibly most importantly
column26: Visa has been warming to bitcoin. In October it announced a handful of bitcoin-related credit and debit cards with leading crypto exchange Coinbase.With more and more ways of using bitcoin
column27: it should mean that more people will want to hold it.Bitcoin has also become much more mature since the days when it was used mainly as a method to purchase drugs on the dark web on Silk Road. Bitcoin digital wallets
column28: keys and exchanges are easier to access and there is a lot more reliable information out there than before.READ: Commentary: US dollar could face turning point soonREAD: Commentary: Cryptocurrency land has become an unregulated casinoThe introduction of financial products such as bitcoin futures and options
column29: as well as blockchain-related funds
column30: has allowed investors who might otherwise have been fearful of volatility to get involved.Bitcoin futures mean that investors can speculate on falling prices by 'going short' on the cryptocurrency.Nobel laureate Robert Shiller has suggested that the 2017 bubble could have been linked to the fact that there were no bitcoin futures at the time.THE INFLATION HEDGEBesides all this mainstream enthusiasm
column31: the carnage brought by COVID-19 has led to huge stimulus packages from governments around the globe and many central banks printing more money. Representations of virtual currency Bitcoin are seen in this picture illustration taken on Mar 13
column32: 2020. (File photo: REUTERS/Dado Ruvic) This could drive up inflation
column33: which in turn lowers people's purchasing power. Indeed the US Federal Reserve last year signalled it would be slightly more tolerant of rising prices when it relaxed its 2 per cent inflation target.In the face of this threat
column34: investments like bitcoin are being consider a store of value. The maximum number of bitcoin that will ever exist is set at 21 million (unless the protocol changes)
column35: and there are already about 18.5 million in circulation.The supply of new coins is also slowing down because the reward that bitcoin miners receive for verifying transactions on the blockchain halves roughly every four years – it fell from BTC12.5 to BTC6.25 last May. This scarcity is comparable to that of precious metals.READ: Commentary: Blockchain has been a lie all this whileREAD: Commentary: Lessons from Estonia
column36: the world's most digitally advanced nationEven central banks are embracing cryptocurrencies. Russia
column37: China
column38: Canada
column39: the EU and many others are either already working on central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) for their countries or publishing white papers detailing their intentions to do so.This is an obvious sign that the powers that be in the old financial world are seeing cryptocurrencies as the future. Meanwhile
column40: the US federal regulator has announced that retail banks can carry out payments with stablecoins
column41: which are cryptocurrencies pegged to traditional currencies.WHERE NEXTIt therefore seems that the recent bitcoin price appreciation may have more substance than in 2017. But not everyone agrees.Chief economist and strategist at Rosenberg Research and Associates
column43: believes bitcoin is in a bubble and investors don't understand how it works.Rosenberg is well placed to comment on bubbles since he is known for identifying the US housing market bubble that led to the global financial crisis of 2008-2009.He believes investors don't understand how bitcoin works and it is in a classic
column44: follow-the-herd bubble (though he has since conceded he is no expert on the cryptocurrency himself). Meanwhile
column45: large volatility in the price is still a major issue
column46: which will still worry some institutional investors.So what to believe? There are plenty of very bullish forecasts for the bitcoin price in 2021. Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss
column47: the founders of leading crypto exchange Gemini
column48: believe bitcoin will eventually hit US$500
column50: while a Citigroup analyst suggests a price of US$318
column51: 000 by December 2021.Obviously these parties have 'skin in the game' and these numbers may be too optimistic. However
column52: in March 2020 the prospect of bitcoin reaching US$30
column53: 000 seemed impossible.Wherever the price goes from here
column54: the fortunes of the leading cryptocurrency are clearly going to be one of the world's biggest financial stories in the year ahead.Andrew Urquhart is Associate Professor of Finance
column57: University of Reading. This commentary first appeared in The Conversation.;channelnewsasia.com;1591;news;SG;en;[];https://cna-sg-res.cloudinary.com/image/upload/q_auto

column1: 41;BRI strengthens Malaysia and China's economic cooperation;Search Scholar Series;2022-09-27 00:49:00;full;https://www.thestar.com.my/opinion/columnists/search-scholar-series/2022/09/27/bri-strengthens-malaysia-and-chinas-economic-cooperation;thestar.com.my;MALAYSIA and China have evolved through many remarkable economic achievements through their relationship
