column1: 79;The Case for a US-South Korea Digital Alliance in Southeast Asia;Lami Kim;2021-05-21 06:27:00;full;https://thediplomat.com/2021/05/the-case-for-a-us-south-korea-digital-alliance-in-southeast-asia;thediplomat.com;South Korea looms as an ideal partner for the U.S. in its efforts to check China's dominance of the digital domain.;"AdvertisementSoutheast Asia is accelerating its digital transformation. During the COVID-19 pandemic
column2: the region has seen an unprecedented use of digital services
column3: such as mobile tracing
column4: telemedicine
column5: video/online chat
column6: and e-commerce. China is seeking dominance in the digital transformation of the region
column7: which will increase Southeast Asian countries' economic and technological dependencies on China
column8: as well as potentially render them vulnerable to Chinese cyber-espionage and surveillance. These sorts of efforts could help Beijing expand its sphere of influence in the Asia-Pacific region
column9: while simultaneously limiting U.S. influence. However
column10: by partnering with South Korea
column11: Washington's longtime ally and an advanced digital technology and equipment provider
column12: the two countries could work together to counter China's digital dominance in Southeast Asia.Fifth generation or 5G mobile networks are at the forefront of Southeast Asia's digital transformation. Such networks provide faster connection speeds
column13: low latency
column14: and more bandwidth
column15: making digital communication more seamless than the previous generation of networks. 5G is also revolutionary because it will enable a wide range of new digital applications
column16: such as the internet of things
column19: and robotic appliances. Combined with the development of artificial intelligence technologies
column20: there is enormous potential for the digital transformation of the economies in the region. Given these prospects
column21: many Southeast Asian telecommunication providers have already developed 5G policies and selected 5G equipment providers. Singapore aims to achieve its nationwide 5G coverage by 2025. Thailand's mobile operator
column22: Advanced Info Service (AIS)
column23: launched its 5G service in hospitals across the country to assist with telemedicine services. Recently
column24: Malaysia initiated a digital masterplan to accelerate its transition toward 5G technology.The leading player in the digital transformation of Southeast Asia is China. China is pursuing exports of its digital technologies and infrastructure
column25: dubbed the 'Digital Silk Road
column26: ' which President Xi Jinping described in 2019 as a priority for the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). Last year
column27: the Chinese Communist Party's leadership called for the expansion of 5G both within China and abroad as an important part of post-pandemic economic recovery
column28: and Southeast Asia is an important part of the Digital Silk Road. China is laying fiber-optic cables in Southeast Asia. It is also exporting its mobile payment services
column29: such as WeChat Pay and Alipay
column30: to Internet users in the region
column31: many of whom do not have full access to financial services.In addition
column32: China is cooperating with Southeast Asian countries to build 'smart cities
column33: ' which employ digital technology and data to improve the quality of life. Finally
column34: China dominates the 5G networks equipment markets in Southeast Asia
column35: as its 5G equipment is much cheaper than its main competitors. Two Chinese firms
column36: Huawei and ZTE
column37: which hold almost half the global 5G equipment market share (followed by Ericsson
column38: Nokia and Samsung)
column39: are expanding their share in Southeast Asia. Many countries in the region
column41: Malaysia
column43: Cambodia
column45: are already using or planning to use Chinese 5G networks.China's increasing global dominance in the 5G equipment market and digital transformation of Southeast Asia will make countries in the region vulnerable to Chinese influence. If its past behavior is any indication
column46: Beijing will try to leverage its dominance in the digital transformation of Southeast Asia to political ends. In smart cities
column48: as digital infrastructure increasingly encroaches upon daily life
column49: controlling everything from traffic lights to self-driving cars and checkouts at stores
column50: China could threaten network shutdowns with disastrous consequences in countries that do not accede to its demands.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.There are numerous recent examples of Beijing wielding its economic clout for geopolitical purposes. In the wake of the deployment of the U.S.' THAAD missile defense system on South Korean soil in 2016
column51: China punished South Korea by shutting down the latter's retail stores located in China
column52: banning tour groups from visiting South Korea
column53: and removing South Korean TV shows from the Chinese internet. Likewise
column54: after Australia called for an independent investigation into the origins of the COVID-19 pandemic
column55: China sanctioned Australia's wine industry. Countries that depend upon Chinese digital infrastructure will be even more vulnerable to China's bullying.In addition
column56: China's digital dominance will make countries in the region vulnerable to China's cyber espionage and surveillance. Experts have warned that Chinese manufacturers have built back door vulnerabilities into network equipment in order to infiltrate foreign companies and enable espionage. China's Cyber Security Law and National Intelligence Law obligate all Chinese organizations and citizens to support China's national intelligence activities
column57: and so there is little distinction between the Chinese government and private industry when it comes to cybersecurity. The head of Huawei previously served as an engineer in the People's Liberation Army
column58: and an employee of the company was arrested in Poland in 2019 on charges of spying
column59: adding to these concerns. Cyberattacks are another worry. Chinese hackers have reportedly planted malicious code in critical foreign infrastructure that can be activated during a potential conflict.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column60: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: As these countries become more dependent on China economically and technologically
column2: as well as more susceptible to China's cyberattacks and surveillance
column3: China's influence over the region will only grow vis-à-vis that of the United States. Over time
column4: Southeast Asian countries will be pressured to refrain from cooperating with Washington in the security realm
column5: undermining U.S. power projection capabilities in the region. This will help China realize its ambition to expand its sphere of influence in the Asia-Pacific free from U.S. interference
column6: endangering U.S. interests and those of its allies and partners in the region.AdvertisementWashington has pressured its partners in Southeast Asia to avoid 5G equipment made by Huawei and ZTE. However
column7: this approach has limitations. Without an alternative for the increasing demand for 5G and other digital infrastructure and technologies
column8: Southeast Asian countries will have little choice but to use Chinese providers. A more constructive approach would be for the U.S. and like-minded countries to incentivize competition in the Southeast Asian market. Although the U.S. is advanced in 5G baseband chips and other digital technologies
column9: it lacks a domestic manufacturer that can rival the Chinese 5G equipment companies.However
column10: the U.S. can partner with foreign firms to challenge China's dominance. South Korea would be an ideal partner for the U.S. in its efforts to check China's dominance in the digital transformation of Southeast Asia. South Korea and the U.S. have been trusted allies for seven decades. They have cooperated in various fields
column11: including sensitive military/security matters. When it comes to 5G equipment
column12: Samsung is well-positioned since its plants are located in South Korea and India. The other major non-Chinese 5G equipment manufacturers
column13: Ericsson and Nokia
column14: have significant manufacturing operations in China
column15: which makes them vulnerable to Beijing's sanctions. Additionally
column16: Samsung long ago won Pentagon clearance for government use of its devices equipped with its proprietary Knox security software
column17: which is trusted by the U.S. military for safeguarding sensitive phone data.Moreover
column18: Southeast Asian consumers generally have favorable views towards South Korean firms in the digital field. South Korea has not entered the Southeast Asian 5G market yet
column19: but a survey report on the 2020 State of Southeast Asia suggests that Samsung was ranked the most preferable partner in building 5G infrastructure in the majority of the ten Southeast Asian countries. Finally
column20: with the rising popularity of Korean pop culture and consumer products in Southeast Asia
column21: South Korea is enjoying a spike in soft power
column22: giving South Korean firms a competitive edge over China.From South Korea's perspective
column23: cooperation with the U.S. in the Southeast Asian 5G market would further South Korea's New Southern Policy
column24: which aims to deepen South Korea's partnerships with Southeast Asian and South Asian countries. The policy aims to diversify its diplomatic relations
column25: which heretofore have been focused on just four major powers (the U.S.
column26: China
column27: Japan and Russia)
column28: as well as to alleviate its own economic dependence on China. Entering the 5G equipment market in Southeast Asia would not only help South Korea enhance its presence in the region
column29: but also diversify its economic interests away from China
column30: leaving it less susceptible to Chinese sanctions.South Korea would benefit from U.S. companies' advanced digital technologies
column31: including microchips
column32: software and operating systems
column33: self-driving vehicle technology
column34: and satellite-based technologies. It would also benefit from Washington's existing partnerships with countries in Southeast Asia
column35: which include decades of economic and military assistance. By combining forces
column36: the U.S. and South Korea can jointly finance projects in Southeast Asia that match China's lavish financing. They have a better chance together to check China's growing digital influence that will eventually pressure Southeast Asian countries to downgrade their relations with the United States.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;['Lami Kim'];https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat-2021-05-21-2.jpg;False;;21.656292;8df556bf96df44be873abe5ff46c9c53;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 80;Cultural Diplomacy as a Key Instrument of China-Central Asia Cooperation;;2023-06-14 15:30:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2023/06/cultural-diplomacy-as-a-key-instrument-of-china-central-asia-cooperation/;thediplomat.com;An interview with Chinese diplomacy researcher Giulia Sciorati.;"Advertisement
The
China-Central Asia summit held in Xi'an
last month marked the opening of the '
Year of Culture and Art of the Peoples of China and Central Asia
.' Besides an important occasion to take stock of
infrastructure and business deals
in the region
column2: the Chinese government has once again focused on cultural exchange
column3: in an effort to combat Sinophobia.

column1: The Diplomat interviewed Giulia Sciorati
column2: a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Trento
column3: where she researches China-Central Asia relations
column4: to better understand the reach of China's cultural diplomacy in Central Asia.

column1: What is the role of cultural diplomacy in China's overall foreign policy?
Sixteen years ago
column2: we could have quickly answered this question by stressing the importance of culture China's vision of soft power. Nowadays
column3: even the notion of soft power is contested. Experts disagree on whether it is still a relevant prism of analysis. The concept of 'narrative power' has gained an increasingly important status in international relations and the 'new' Chinese soft power falls precisely into this category. Xi Jinping's invitation to 'tell the China story well' (讲好中国故事

column1: ) has resonated widely and clearly. Cultural products make it easier to 'tell a good story
column2: ' especially in a visual world like ours. Cultural diplomacy remains therefore very relevant
column3: at least to this particular strategy in Chinese foreign policy.

column1: Get the Newsletter
Has China's cultural diplomacy in Central Asia changed in recent years?
Enjoying this article?
Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.
In Central Asia
column2: China's cultural diplomacy has not particularly changed either region-wise or sector-wise. Indeed
column3: travel restrictions imposed by the  pandemic have forced activities in this sector to move into the digital realm. We have seen that more attention has been paid to visuals such as videos
column4: images
column5: and photographs on traditional and social media. However
column6: I would not say that this hints at a change in the whole cultural diplomacy infrastructure
column7: because the core messaging has remained the same with topics such as the 'Silk Road' and 'Chinese traditional medicine' still under the spotlight. One important aspect to underline here is that these topics are not exclusive to Central Asia but are relatively common to how China uses culture worldwide.

column1: What sort of tools does the Chinese government employ in its cultural diplomacy outreach in Central Asia?

The most important tool that China uses in Central Asia are scholarships for Central Asian students and scholars to travel to China and funds to set up Chinese studies programs around the region. In short
column2: the education sector. This is important because it allows China to brand itself in a very specific way to Central Asian audiences (especially the younger generations). Another aspect that has proven particularly relevant in this domain is media cooperation
column3: including media training for Central Asian journalists and media specialists in China. This is a way to promote the diffusion of a specific 'story' on China that would eventually not exclusively be told by Chinese media but also by other outlets in the region.

column1: Advertisement
Is China's cultural diplomacy in Central Asia working? Is it taming the widespread Sinophobia that exists in the region?
The short answer is that it does not work as well as hoped. Several Chinese academic studies point to the shortcomings of China's public diplomacy in Central Asia. However
column2: in my opinion
column3: the identity value system created by China's discursive constructions of the history and culture shared with Central Asian countries (for instance
column4: the 'Silk Road nations' identity) is too valuable to set aside. Even if it has limited pull with Central Asian audiences
column5: it has proven to work well among political and diplomatic communities
column6: at least as a broad frame to group several activities
column8: and interactions.

column1: How do you distinguish between museum cooperation and cultural diplomacy?
There is a lot of debate among specialists on this point
column2: and there is no one-size-fits-all definition. My analysis shows that international cooperation in the heritage sector (including between museums) is generally aimed at marketizing national or transnational heritage as cultural products to engage foreign audiences. In simpler terms
column3: consider traveling museum exhibitions through which heritage unique to a country or culture is displayed worldwide. Although this results from extensive museum cooperation and does not exclusively serve political aims
column4: it still achieves cultural diplomacy goals.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2023-06-14-125922.jpg;False;;21.415417;81156539e8faef631a9fee2248ca5c26;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column34: and issue that has risen in importance with the COVID-19 pandemic.Second

column37: although the ministers had previously welcomed involvement in the Indo-Pacific

column41: and others have also expressed an interest in the security of this space as they possess territories in the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean.Japanese Prime Minister Suga Yoshihide meanwhile took his first foreign trip in October 2020
column42: visiting Vietnam and Indonesia. On this trip
column43: too

column1: The White House's Vision for B3WEnjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.While there is little information on how the B3W will work in practice

The aim is to present the inaugural B3W projects during a G-7 meeting in December this year.B3W and BRI: Strategic Competition?Since China's President Xi Jinping announced the launch of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) in 2013
column39: G-7 countries have consistently expressed in different international and academic forums their concern about China's political

column50: the BRI keeps the focus of its global development interests on traditional projects such as ports
column56: China has expressed its intentions to develop the Health
column58: and Digital Silk Roads.Another differentiating aspect is financing. The B3W aims to finance its infrastructure investments primarily from the Development Finance Corporation
column62: and the U.S. Trade and Development Agency

column68: and other entities with substantial investments to back the project.AdvertisementThe truth is that both initiatives seem
column70: to be more complementary than competitive.How could the B3W impact Latin America?Latin America's Role in the United States' and China's strategiesChina has a robust presence in the region. A recent study prepared by Boston University and the think-tank Inter-American Dialogue concluded that China lent Latin America about $1.7 billion a year between 2005 and 2015
column71: but has reduced that figure by half since 2016

column77: where direct state-to-state loans were reduced and the purchase of local companies

column82: and Atlantic-Pacific connection. As a result

column89: and on the pressure to maintain political and diplomatic alignment.Indeed

column91: Central America and the Caribbean

Article 32 of the treaty states that each member shall refrain from engaging in relations with non-market economiesCentral America and the Caribbean is a subregion critical to U.S. security. Here
column94: the U.S. and China alike have been implementing soft power tools to secure diplomatic allies in the China-Taiwan dispute. The growing economic and diplomatic presence of the Asian giant is perceived as a threat by Washington.In South America

column96: which oscillates between competition and contention from the great powers

Just $5 a month.The geopolitical reading indicates that the B3W initiative is intended to be the West's return to a more active presence on the global chessboard
column98: modifying its critical stance toward the Chinese BRI and offering a real alternative with concrete options to developing countries.Boosting global multilateralism through economic recovery and global prosperity for low and middle income nations is a smart bet. The initial development of financially
column100: and socially sustainable soft infrastructures provides the basis for a strategic rearticulation between the West and developing nations
column101: boosting global multilateralism.Regardless of their strategic intentions

column103: and a two-way opportunity for Latin America.This piece was originally published in Spanish by ReporteAsia.";;2310;news;ID;en;[];https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2021-12-22-152509.jpg;False;;21.17526;17fb72cd6ae52f4df69cb5dca44a03a2;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column2: China's Digital Silk Road Might Be in Trouble Very Soon;Shannon;2020-09-23 13:09:44;full;https://thediplomat.com/2020/09/in-serbia-chinas-digital-silk-road-might-be-in-trouble-very-soon;thediplomat.com;A breakthrough agreement signed between Serbia and Kosovo could spell the end of Huawei's thriving presence in Serbia.;"AdvertisementOn September 4
column3: Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic and the prime minister of Kosovo
column4: Avdullah Hoti
column5: signed an economic normalization agreement in the presence of U.S. President Donald Trump. No one expected that China would be mentioned
column6: let alone that it would be impacted by an agreement addressing the Balkan dispute.China was not mentioned in the deal by name
column7: but it did not have to be. One of the provisions of the signed agreement states: 'Both parties will prohibit the use of 5G equipment supplied by untrusted vendors in their communications network. Where such an agreement is already present
column8: both parties commit to removal and other mediation efforts in a timely fashion.' The 'untrusted vendors' were not identified. Still
column9: there is no doubt that the phrase referred to the Chinese tech giant
column10: Huawei
column11: and that it targets Serbia
column12: which has a partnership with Huawei. Consequently
column13: the fate of China's digital juggernaut in Serbia is uncertain and dependent on U.S. policy toward Belgrade.In the past decade
column14: the Chinese presence in the Balkans has gradually increased
column15: and partnership with Serbia has been its cornerstone. This partnership has also involved the technological domain. Huawei established a strong presence in Serbia
column16: giving Belgrade a special place on what is called 'the Digital Silk Road.' The foundation for this partnership was set in 2009 when Serbia and China signed an Agreement on Economic and Technical Cooperation in the Field of Infrastructure.More recently
column17: the Serbian Ministry of Interior selected Huawei as its partner for the 'Safe City' project
column19: 000 Huawei-made surveillance cameras equipped with advanced facial and license plate recognition software will be installed across Belgrade. The locations of most of these cameras are undisclosed. The Serbian Ministry of Interior provided to the public a list of some sites in Belgrade where surveillance cameras are placed
column20: but Huawei is not mentioned. In implementing the Safe City project
column21: the Ministry of Interior will also rely on eLTE
column22: an advanced wireless broadband system supplied by Huawei.In 2018
column23: the Serbian Ministry of Finance signed an agreement with the Chinese company on the provision of Huawei traffic surveillance systems
column24: including for Chinese infrastructure projects. Huawei is also Serbia's partner on the 'the Smart City' project planned for the cities of Belgrade
column25: Novi Sad
column26: and the city selected for the pilot project
column27: Niš. In March 2020 Huawei helped another Serbian city
column28: Kragujevac
column29: launch the City Data Center. There are also plans for Huawei to construct in Kragujevac a regional data center for South and Southeast Europe
column30: making it a third regional data center for Huawei in Europe
column31: after the ones in Netherlands and Germany.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.The state-owned telecommunications operator
column32: Telekom Srbija has a 150 million euro ($177 million) project with Huawei on the establishment of high-speed broadband internet
column33: which might be a springboard for future 5G infrastructure in Serbia. Beyond the state-owned firm
column34: a private telecom company
column35: Telenor Serbia
column36: formerly owned by Norwegians and now by a group from the Czech Republic
column37: also has a partnership with Huawei.Based on the above
column38: it's no surprise that Nenad Popovic
column40: said in May 2020 that 'Huawei has arrived in Serbia to stay for a long time.'Now
column41: this elaborate list of cooperation projects is in jeopardy as President Donald Trump and the United States have Huawei and China in their crosshairs again. In May 2019
column43: banning U.S. companies from selling technology to the Chinese company and putting Huawei in the heart of what is usually referred to as a U.S.-China tech war. A reprieve was provided to some technology sales
column44: but now Trump is escalating again. After the U.K.
column45: the United States' primary European ally
column47: Trump is pressuring other European allies to do the same. In August 2020
column48: the Trump administration mandated that manufacturers globally cannot use U.S. technology and software for the production of Huawei semiconductors.AdvertisementAs Trump faces low re-election odds amid the COVID-19 pandemic
column49: Trump sees punishing China for the outbreak as part of his electoral strategy
column50: and Huawei is also on the hit list. But the strategy is not a hard sell politically. According to the Pew Research Center surveys
column51: 73 percent of U.S. adults have an unfavorable view of China and countering China (and Huawei specifically) is one of the rare issues of bipartisan agreement between Republicans and the Democrats.Thus it was only a matter of time before Serbian ties with China would put Serbia on the United States' radar. Trump's reengagement with the Kosovo dispute was motivated by the desire to score a foreign policy win for his re-election campaign. However
column52: resolving what is for most Americans an obscure Balkan dispute is not enough in the world of COVID-19. So Trump's mediation in the Kosovo dispute was directly linked with his China policy.Now
column53: Belgrade is caught between Washington and Beijing. For Serbia and Vucic
column54: Trump might be the best bet to get a less painful settlement to the Kosovo dispute. Indeed
column56: Vucic told the Serbian public that Serbia had finally managed to open the door to the White House. However
column57: it will not be easy or cheap for Serbia to give up on its partnership with Huawei. Indeed
column58: a decision to remove Huawei from its telecommunications system will cost a much larger and wealthier U.K. 2 billion pounds. No similar calculations exist on how much it would cost Serbia to sever its extent cooperation with Huawei. Even without 5G stations
column59: getting rid of Huawei's technology will doubtless be expensive.Serbia is uneasy about its options. One week after the White House meeting
column60: Vucic had a meeting with Chinese Ambassador to Serbia Chen Bo
column61: where the president explained that the agreement signed in Washington would not impact Serbia's partnership with China
column62: including in telecommunications. Three days later Chen
column63: alongside Serbian Prime Minister Ana Brnabic
column64: opened Huawei's Innovations and Development Center. On that occasion
column65: Brnabic said: 'Serbia is not interested in unreliable technologies either; on the contrary
column66: it is in the interest of the tender for the introduction of the 5G network to be open and transparent
column68: which includes the agreement from Washington.'NGet first-read access to major articles yet to be released
column69: as well as links to thought-provoking commentaries and in-depth articles from our Asia-Pacific correspondents.Subscribe Newsletter For the time being
column70: Serbia will continue being evasive about Huawei as none of the current collaboration projects relates to the construction of 5G infrastructure. But this reprieve is only temporary. The public auction for the 5G spectrum in Serbia will be held during the first quarter of 2021. Moreover
column71: while the formal date has not yet been set
column72: Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to visit Serbia back in April.Meanwhile
column73: the Serbian economy is expected to experience a sharp contraction as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Serbian Fiscal Council predicts a 6.5 percent drop in Serbia's GDP as well as job losses
column74: and that same body believes that Serbia will have to ask for 6.5 billion euros in international loan. Serbia has already shown uneasiness with loans and aid from institutions like the European Union and International Monetary Fund because of their liquidity and transparency criteria. China
column75: with its more secretive way of doing things
column77: what happens if the potential bailout loan from China gets negotiated during Xi's visit to Serbia and Beijing conditions the loan on the construction of the 5G network in Serbia by Huawei? Serbia and Vucic would truly be in a tough spot.The document signed in the White House is not legally binding. Still
column78: Vucic knows the political and strategic weight of signing a document in the Oval Office next to the U.S. president. The United States will undoubtedly be in the mind of Vucic while he talks about 5G projects with Xi
column79: regardless of whether Trump is still in the White House in 2021. The one thing that Belgrade cannot afford under any circumstances is the prospect of U.S. financial sanctions. This became obvious in December 2019 when Serbia stopped military purchases from Moscow to avoid U.S. sanctions. For now
column81: but if Washington decides to lash out against Huawei with economic sanctions

column1: 84;Malaysia in China's Belt and Road;Shannon;2020-11-23 16:38:31;full;https://thediplomat.com/2020/11/malaysia-in-chinas-belt-and-road;thediplomat.com;Insights from Chow Bing Ngeow.;In this Sept. 8
column3: photo
column4: visitors view a scale model of the East Coast Rail Link during the launching of the train project in Kuantan
column5: east coast of peninsula Malaysia. Credit: AP PhotoAdvertisementThe Diplomat author Mercy Kuo regularly engages subject-matter experts
column6: policy practitioners
column7: and strategic thinkers across the globe for their diverse insights into Asia affairs  This conversation with Dr. Chow Bing Ngeow – director of the Institute of China Studies and deputy vice chancellor at the University of Malaya in Kuala Lumpur
column8: Malaysia – explores the past
column9: present
column10: and future of China's Belt and Road in Malaysia.Explain Malaysia's challenge and opportunities in China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). The BRI is a flexible and adaptable concept
column11: although its key mantle remains traditional infrastructure such as rail and port. When the BRI was launched in late 2013
column12: Malaysia was one of the most supportive countries. The then Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition government of Najib Abdul Razak signed a mega-infrastructure deal with China called the East Coast Rail Link (ECRL)
column13: which became the flagship BRI project in Malaysia.When a new coalition
column14: Pakatan Harapan (PH)
column15: came into power after the 2018 elections
column16: it raised a lot of questions about ECRL
column19: and even possible involvement in corruption. But the PH government never repudiated the whole concept of the BRI. It continued to see the BRI as providing good opportunities for countries like Malaysia to upgrade and improve their infrastructure. The adaptable BRI
column20: which now expands to policy areas such as digital connectivity (Digital BRI)
column21: green development (Green BRI)
column22: and public health (Health Silk Road) provide various kinds of opportunities for Malaysia to improve in these different policy sectors.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column23: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter The PH government also saw Chinese advances in future-oriented industries such as AI
column24: robotics
column25: e-commerce
column26: and the Internet of Things as opportunities for Malaysia to tap into. The challenges lie in the implementation of the BRI vision
column27: namely how the individual projects were negotiated and executed. Here
column28: countries
column29: including Malaysia
column30: need to be well prepared in negotiating these projects so that the projects have a high chance to be a net positive for their economic development.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.What are Kuala Lumpur's strategic objectives in the BRI? Diplomatically Malaysia understands China sees support for the BRI as an important indicator of how countries assess their relationship with China. Kuala Lumpur wants to preserve a stable and positive relationship with Beijing and is willing to give strong rhetorical support to the BRI. But beyond that
column31: there is also a genuine belief among many politicians and policymakers in Malaysia
column32: across the political divide
column33: that Chinese investment into the infrastructure sector in Malaysia potentially could bridge the gap of regional economic balances in Malaysia. Moreover
column34: Chinese capital
column35: technology
column36: and talent can be well harnessed to support Malaysia's next phase of economic development and upgrade its industrial chain to a more technologically advanced stage. From 1970s and 1990s
column37: Malaysia relied a lot on Western and Japanese capital and technology during its early phase of industrialization. China is now a major economy (though not the only one)
column38: that is able to replicate that role for Malaysia's economic and technological development.How is Malaysia preserving its national interests amid U.S.-China rivalry in Southeast Asia?AdvertisementThe U.S.-China rivalry provides some immediate
column39: short-term benefits in the sense that both major powers are offering benefits to Malaysia in a competitive context. But overall speaking
column41: and the destabilizing implications of such a rivalry in the region
column42: is not something Malaysia welcomes. It prefers that the big powers settle and manage their differences. Malaysia continues to adhere to a non-aligned foreign policy. Its behavior is often described as 'hedging' rather than balancing or bandwagoning. Although Malaysia is a party to the South China Sea dispute and is wary about the increasing assertiveness of China
column43: it does not want the dispute to affect its overall ties with China
column44: nor does it want to be drawn into the U.S.-China rivalry because of the dispute.Analyze domestic factors in Kuala Lumpur's decision-making to advance Malaysia's foreign policy priorities.Malaysia's foreign policy is less determined by public opinion. Traditionally foreign policy has been very much an elite-driven process
column45: with the prime minister as the center. Given the political distractions in the country right now
column46: there is even less attention being given to foreign policy. By and large the country's foreign policy has to serve
column47: or at least not contradict significantly
column48: the need for national economic development
column49: which is crucial for ensuring political support for the government of the day.Assess Malaysia's expectations for U.S. leadership in Southeast Asia.Malaysia definitely continues to welcome the U.S. to be a constructive actor in the region
column51: and to be a reliable partner in improving the region's economic development
column54: and so forth. It will also welcome the U.S. to provide a stabilizing balance in the context of the rising influence of China. But the U.S. should not cast its relationship with Beijing in overly ideological and confrontational terms and expect countries in the region to choose sides. Instead
column55: Malaysia expects and wishes that for the U.S. to show leadership
column56: it should contribute to public goods
column58: be less ideological and more pragmatic
column59: and respect how the countries in the region pursue their own national interests.;thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;Shannon;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat-2020-11-23-12.jpg;False;;19.973793;c114ad359bc38360ae1c1aab794cadd8;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 85;Does the Belt and Road Have a Future in Taliban-ruled Afghanistan?;;2021-08-21 12:15:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2021/08/does-the-belt-and-road-have-a-future-in-taliban-ruled-afghanistan;thediplomat.com;The Taliban will welcome the hard infrastructure elements of the BRI. The 'soft' components are a different story.;"Advertisement
When the United States and its allies began evacuating from Kabul on August 15
column2: as the Taliban entered the Afghan capital
column3: China decided to keep its embassy open and claimed it was ready for friendly relations with the Taliban. State Councillor and Foreign Minister Wang Yi had already met with Taliban representatives in late July in Tianjin to discuss the reconciliation and reconstruction process in Afghanistan. During that meeting
column4: the Taliban also agreed not to support Uyghur separatists who might threaten stability in Xinjiang. China has a principle of not intervening in internal affairs abroad and expects other parties to have the same policy. On this basis
column5: China and the Taliban's Afghanistan may develop new ties.

column1: China's policy toward the Taliban is sometimes misunderstood in Western countries
column2: but it reflects China's Realpolitik and ambitions for the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) in Central Asia and South Asia. The new relations between Beijing and Kabul may accelerate the development of China's flagship connectivity program in the region with the construction of new infrastructure facilities
column3: but without deep evolutions
column4: the Taliban regime may not be able to implement the 'soft' BRI
column5: which involves programs ranging from education to health. However
column6: the huge opportunities offered by China's BRI may soften the Taliban's fundamentalism.

column1: The Taliban and the 'Hard' BRI
The first Memorandum of Understanding on the BRI between Afghanistan and China was signed in 2016
column2: and then several initiatives were agreed between the two countries. However
column3: because of terrorism
column4: few projects were actually conducted within the framework of the BRI. In addition
column5: Afghanistan's climatic and geographic conditions also make the construction of routes difficult.

column1: Due to the lack of proper networks and pervasive insecurity
column2: untapped Afghan mineral resources have hardly been exploited. If the Taliban succeed in bringing stability back to Afghanistan
column3: China may invest in several sectors
column4: including mining.

column1: Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.
But for China
column2: stability in Afghanistan is also a prerequisite for the development and success of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
column3: a major segment of the BRI. In Pakistan
column4: China has been investing billions of U.S. dollars in the construction of roads
column5: special economic zones
column6: and ports. But due to geographic conditions and tensions with India in Kashmir
column7: the Chinese city of Kashgar is still hardly connected with the corridor
column8: and projects face delays.

column1: In southern Pakistan
column2: China is developing the port of Gwadar
column3: which is to become a major hub for energy. However
column4: to be profitable
column5: the new port needs to serve as a terminal for natural gas from Central Asia
column6: through Afghanistan. But transportation by routes or pipelines could not be planned in this war-torn country. With a 'Pax Talibana' in Afghanistan
column7: both China and Pakistan can envisage new infrastructure facilities that may connect Gwadar to Central Asia. Once those networks are built
column8: Gwadar will also become much more attractive to foreign investors
column9: especially from the Gulf region
column10: as they have
column11: until now
column12: shown some reluctance to invest in Gwadar because of a lack of prospects.

column1: Diplomat Brief Weekly Newsletter N Get briefed on the story of the week
column2: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific. Get the Newsletter

column1: The new regime in Kabul may also prevent the development of troubles in Pakistan where Chinese-constructed projects have been targeted. Pakistan claims that Indian and Afghan intelligence agencies were involved in the Dasu terror attack on July 14
column2: where several Chinese citizens were killed by the Pakistani Taliban. Good relations between Pakistan and the Taliban may improve the security environment for Chinese construction projects in the CPEC.

column1: Advertisement
The Challenging 'Soft' BRI
These 'hard' BRI projects may successfully be implemented under the Taliban. However
column2: the BRI is much more than just a few railroads or ports; it is about facilitating trade and exchanges between China and the world. The Belt and Road Initiative includes many 'soft' components from the Health Silk Road to the Digital Silk Road
column3: and these initiatives rely on innovation. Participation in the BRI demands that the Taliban be more open to changes and conduct reforms that are in line with China's interests.

column1: Countries that are active in the BRI tend to replicate
column2: with more or less success
column3: a Chinese model based on special incentives offered to companies as well as specific reforms where the priority is given to education. One of the most important achievements made by China over the last 30 years is in regard to education. In 1990
column4: the gross school enrollment rate in tertiary education was only 3 percent
column5: but it rose to more than 53 percent in 2019
column6: and China now tops the PISA ranking. China has also become a top destination for foreign students from developing countries
column7: especially from Africa. To gain long-term benefits from the BRI
column8: the Taliban will need to change their views on education and adopt a Chinese model where science is a priority.

column1: China will also want to see the Taliban change their stance on women. China's unprecedented growth since 1978 is partly due to the participation of women
column2: who are said to 'hold up half the sky.' Some of China's most successful companies have been led by businesswomen
column3: like Sun Yang
column4: who served as chairwomen of Huawei from 1999 to 2018
column5: or Jane Jie Sun
column6: CEO of Trip.com since 2016. This is due again to education: In 2009
column8: female students outnumbered male students in Chinese colleges.

column1: China also expects the Taliban to soften their tone toward ethnic and religious minorities in Afghanistan if they want to join the BRI. In the past
column2: the Taliban were accused of ethnic cleansing against minorities such as Hazaras. But the continuation of this abuse will elevate the risk of terror attacks against the infrastructure facilities that are to be constructed by Chinese companies in Afghanistan. Segregation and harassment against Shias or Uzbeks would also threaten relations with neighboring countries like Iran or Uzbekistan and challenge the roll-out of regional multilateral projects financed and constructed by China. Similarly
column3: the Taliban should not transform Afghanistan into a destination for terrorists who would plan attacks in Xinjiang or other countries in Central Asia that support the BRI
column4: as China would never tolerate this.

column1: The rule of law and the fight against corruption are other targets that the Taliban will need to address. Although large-scale investment projects will be agreed between governments and will involve Chinese state-owned companies
column2: for Afghanistan to attract investment from smaller private Chinese companies
column3: some consistent legal reforms will be required in accordance with Islamic law
column4: but also
column5: more importantly
column6: with Chinese laws. Without the insurance that the Taliban will secure Chinese investment in Afghanistan
column7: Beijing will be quite cautious about developing major projects in this country.

column1: If China does not intervene directly in Afghan internal affairs to implement these changes
column2: it is very likely that other countries that enjoy close relations with the Taliban
column3: such as Pakistan or some Gulf states
column4: which are all very supportive of the BRI
column5: will pressure new authorities in Kabul to follow more pro-China policies. Continuing chaos in Afghanistan would jeopardize CPEC projects in Pakistan
column6: something that Islamabad cannot afford.

column1: Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.
The soft and hard elements of the BRI are two sides of the same coin. Whereas the Taliban's regime can ease the construction of infrastructure by China in Afghanistan
column2: it is still doubtful that the Taliban would manage to develop the 'soft BRI' as it requires the transformation of the Taliban regime. However
column3: in the end
column4: if the BRI is properly implemented
column5: China may succeed in normalizing Afghanistan where years of wars
column6: occupation
column7: and foreign intervention have failed.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;[];https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2021-08-05-8.jpg;False;;19.425297;7b855f6be9635a132fbaa2da77e2e61a;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

But their summit is being preceded by a series of ministerial meetings in various picturesque cities in Japan to lay the groundwork on a number of important topical issues. column1: 87;China's Switch From the Belt and Road to the Global Development Initiative;;2023-07-11 16:15:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2023/07/chinas-switch-from-the-belt-and-road-to-the-global-development-initiative;thediplomat.com;China is transitioning from one major global project to another. How are they different?;"Advertisement
Even as China's Belt and Road Initiative gears up to celebrate its 10th anniversary
column2: it is fading from prominence. In its place is the new Global Development Initiative (GDI).

column1: Chinese leader Xi Jinping announced the concept at the United Nations General Assembly in September 2021. By September 2022
column2: over 60 nations had joined the Group of Friends of the GDI. The World Economic Forum hailed China's GDI as a 'timely call-for-action to address the immediate challenges that threaten our collective ability to deliver on the Sustainable Development Goals.'

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the waning BRI is being eclipsed
column3: if not replaced
column4: by the GDI. What are the differences between the two
column5: and why has China decided to push forward this new development initiative?

column1: Distinct Contexts
Diplomat Brief Weekly Newsletter N Get briefed on the story of the week
column2: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific. Get the Newsletter

column1: Contextualizing and comparing the separate launches of the BRI and GDI can shed important light on the differing scopes and objectives of these two initiatives.
First
column2: the international economic backgrounds at the time when these two initiatives were launched were quite different. The BRI arose at the end of the commodity boom
column3: where trade with developing countries reached its peak whilst the rest of the world was struggling to recover from the Global Financial Crisis. The subsequent decline of commodity prices weakened the economic leverage China had been using to gain access to raw materials and to develop markets for its manufactured products. Therefore
column4: the BRI was a vehicle for Beijing to cultivate linkages with the Global South beyond trade.

column1: By contrast
column2: the GDI was launched at the apex of the  pandemic
column3: which not only disrupted global supply chains but also put many BRI-related infrastructure projects on hold. According to a survey in mid-2020
column4: 20 percent of BRI projects were reported to be 'seriously affected' by the pandemic. In 2021
column5: BRI-related investments fell to $56.5 billion from $60.5 billion in 2020. With the BRI losing momentum
column6: it's no coincidence that China decided to launch a new development initiative taking a different approach – one less reliant on heavy infrastructure construction.

column1: The geopolitical context also changed markedly between the BRI's launch and the GDI's. The BRI was launched amidst the United States' 'pivot to Asia' strategy
column2: whereby Washington had just started to shift attention from the Middle East to the Asia-Pacific. The GDI was inaugurated against the backdrop of heightened great power competition and after the launch of a dedicated Indo-Pacific Strategy by the United States. Moreover
column3: the United States and its allies began responding to the BRI with their own development arrangements – namely the B3W Initiative and the Global Gateway. Many regard them as rivals of the BRI
column4: with the aim of asserting U.S. and European power in the realm of global infrastructure development.

column1: Advertisement
The BRI and GDI also emerged from different domestic considerations within China itself. The GDI emerged at a time when China's government budget deficit problem has deteriorated
column2: with debt levels rising from 2
column3: 1 percent of GDP in 2013 to 8.6 percent in 2020 before declining slightly to 6.1 percent in 2021. Consequently
column4: the widened fiscal deficit has come to hinder China's capability of financing large-scale infrastructure projects under the BRI.

column1: More broadly
column2: the GDI followed the issuance of the 14th Five-Year Plan
column3: which calls for a shift away from fixed-asset investment in speculative and unsustainable projects to more sustainable and financially profitable ones
column4: including innovative
column5: information
column6: and integrated infrastructure projects. Hence
column7: China's shift toward emphasizing sustainable economic growth at home
column8: and the pursuit of higher domestic consumption
column9: coupled with its exacerbating fiscal problems
column10: created different incentives for China's development initiatives than the conditions seen in 2013
column11: when China was leading the global recovery from the Global Financial Crisis.

column1: Lastly
column2: the venues for launching the two initiatives are symbolically different. The Silk Road Economic Belt was proposed in Kazakhstan
column3: and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road was raised for the first time in Indonesia
column4: both of which are large developing countries. The GDI
column5: by contrast
column6: was launched during the United Nations General Assembly. Having the U.N. as the inaugural setting for the GDI conveys Beijing's appetite – at least at its face value– to make this a multilateral arrangement. This is especially notable as the original BRI has been criticized for being a Sino-centric deal that prioritizes opaque bilateralism over inclusive multilateralism.

column1: Different Operationalization
The GDI differs from the BRI not only in terms of background but also regarding its operationalization. To begin with
column2: the main authorship of the policy documents explaining the two initiatives differs. While the National Development and Reform Commission is involved in most BRI-related policies
column3: the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is taking the lead in formulating GDI-related documents. In the case of the BRI
column4: although the secretariat for the BRI coordination is within the National Development and Reform Commission
column5: the plethora of participating institutions and the failure of different Chinese state actors – i.e. party leadership
column6: functional bureaucracies
column7: and economic arms – to coordinate a unified strategy for the BRI led to fragmented motives and policies.

column1: According to the List of First-batch Projects of GDI Project Pool
column2: the China International Development Cooperation Agency will play an important role in implementing GDI-related projects on poverty reduction
column3: pandemic response
column4: food security
column5: climate actions
column6: and digital economy. Although this development agency was instituted in 2018 to help promote the BRI
column8: largely because it remains a coordinating body of China's foreign aid policy. Now
column9: its salience in implementing GDI projects would be a key factor to watch. Will the CIDCA play a more prominent role in China's foreign aid policy and can it overcome a much criticized project management style?

column1: Moreover
column2: multilateralism and engagement with civil society feature higher in the GDI-related projects. This can be reflected in either extensive cooperation with international organizations (e.g. the U.N. Development Program) in implementing the projects or the establishment of multilateral platforms for development (e.g. the International NGOs Network for Poverty Reduction Cooperation).

column1: Further
column2: the GDI and the BRI focus on distinct issue areas. Beijing has become more prudent about infrastructure financing 'due to its own economic woes
column3: repayment problems and the low economic returns on its foreign loans
column4: and accumulative complaints about the BRI adding to socio-environmental risks
column5: unsustainable debts and governance and corruption issues in partner countries.' In contrast to the BRI
column6: the GDI lays more emphasis on promoting software for development
column8: food security
column9: pandemic responses
column10: financing for development
column11: climate change and green development
column12: industrialization
column13: digital economy
column14: and connectivity.

column1: Finally
column2: the financing scheme for both initiatives varies. While the BRI is financed by a range of actors consisting of China policy banks
column3: commercial banks
column4: multinational development banks
column5: and sovereign wealth funds
column6: the GDI seems to rely primarily on the Global Development and South-South Cooperation Fund (GDSSCF)
column7: which is an upgraded version of the erstwhile SSC Assistance Fund in partnership with the UNDP. According to the 2023 Progress Report on GDI
column8: the GDSSCF amounts to $4 billion. Also
column9: financing for the BRI involved a mix of grants
column10: interest-free and/or concessional loans

column1: 88;Containing China's Maritime Power: A Question of Capability and Intent;;2022-09-28 14:00:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2022/09/containing-chinas-maritime-power-a-question-of-capability-and-intent/;thediplomat.com;China's foreign policy assertiveness and the posturing of 'wolf warrior diplomacy' have generated serious concerns about Beijing's intentions – especially at sea.;"Ships from the Theodore Roosevelt Carrier Strike Group and the America Expeditionary Strike Group transit the South China Sea

column1: Credit: U.S. NavyAdvertisementCapability and intent are the two fundamental lenses that can best predict risk and conflict. While there is ample space for misjudgment on the part of two adversaries
column2: capability is much easier to evaluate than intent. In foreign policy
column3: China's rise has gone through a number of iterations
column4: each marked by a rhetoric of intent and suggestions about its capability.The 12-character Chinese aphorism quoted by Deng Xiaoping – 'Hide your brightness
column5: bide your time' – is long dead. The late Chinese leader was fond of quoting the famous military strategist Sun Tzu
column6: who advocated keeping one's strengths and capabilities a secret until the appropriate moment. Deng prioritized boosting national incomes and progressing Chinese economic policy first. In 2003
column8: a senior Chinese official
column9: introduced a new concept in Beijing's foreign policy: the 'peaceful rise' (later modified to 'peaceful development.') Finally
column10: Xi Jinping in 2013 expressed the intent for China to become a great power
column11: in part by establishing its maritime dominance in the East and South China Seas. This has already had profound strategic ramifications and put China on a collision course with other regional powers.The big question is whether China truly intends to realize these ambitions
column12: and whether it has the capability to do so. In this regard
column13: an examination of these two issues in the context of merchant shipping
column14: ports
column15: and seabed cable communications is particularly instructive.First
column16: China now controls a merchant fleet of more than 5
column17: 600 vessels with a capacity of 270 million dead-weight tonnage (dwt)
column18: making it the second-largest ship-owning country in the world. According to the Institute of  Shipping Economics and Logistics
column19: China COSCO Shipping is the largest shipping company in the world
column20: and controls over 800 merchant vessels with a combined 74.5 million dwt. By comparison
column21: the numbers for the United States are weak when factoring the restrictions imposed by the Jones Act
column22: a protectionist law passed in 1920
column23: which requires that all goods that are transported by water between U.S. ports be carried by vessels constructed in the United States
column24: flying the U.S. flag
column25: and that are owned and crewed by U.S. citizens and permanent residents. Consequently
column26: this lessens the number of ships available for the U.S. to use in international commerce.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column27: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: China on the other hand
column2: has undertaken a large merchant shipbuilding program through the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). Chinese shipbuilding companies are the largest in the world
column3: which include the Jiangnan Shipbuilding Group
column4: a subsidiary of the China State Shipbuilding Corporation (CSSC)
column5: a state owned company with $120 billion in assets.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Second
column6: and more worrisome
column8: maintains
column9: and operates dozens of ports globally
column10: which give it a dominating advantage. In South Asia
column11: for example

column13: to help the Sri Lankan government meet rising foreign debt repayments. Critical ports are a part of China's 'string of pearls' strategy that seeks to create a maritime link between eastern China and the African continent. Worse
column14: Lonnie Henley of the China Maritime Studies Institute argued in May that merchant ships can be weaponized
column15: giving China a logistical advantage in any attempt to invade Taiwan.Third
column16: a 2021 report by the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies warns that the U.S. position as the world's leading hub in subsea networks can no longer be taken for granted. Subsea networks are vital as they carry nearly all voice and internet traffic between continents
column17: and while more of the world is becoming digitally connected
column18: China has emerged a leading subsea cable provider. For example
column19: between 2004 and 2019
column20: the U.S. went from handling half of all internet traffic to less than 25 percent
column21: while Xi Jinping has laid plans for a 'Digital Silk Road' to place China at the very center of global digital networks.A newly released report from the French Institute for International Studies on the geopolitics of submarine cables in Oceania
column22: mainly the Pacific Islands nations
column23: noted the growing politicization of the technology internationally. The author
column24: Camille Morel
column25: an associate researcher at the Institute for Strategy and Defense Studies at the University of Lyon
column26: noted that by 2022
column27: the 450 fiber-optic cables that stretch across the world carry as much as 98 percent of international data and are critical to digitally-connected societies. The report highlights China's use of seabed cables as an instrument of policy and to assert its sovereignty at sea. It uses seabed surveys to identify the best possible route for a cable
column28: allowing China to occupy the space. In June
column29: China reportedly carried out seabed surveys in Japan's Exclusive Economic Zone
column30: close to the disputed Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands
column31: without Tokyo's permission.AdvertisementTo counter China's dominance in the digital sphere
column32: Pacific and international powers need to invest heavily in digital infrastructure. Early efforts include the Trilateral Partnership for Infrastructure Investment in the Indo-Pacific
column33: which was launched in 2018
column34: which called for a fund to counter China's Chinese East Micronesia Cable project.Investment came to life in an MoU between Pacific Island states
column35: Japan
column36: the United States
column37: and Australia. The U.S. warned that major telecom providers have been labeled a national security risk
column38: as Article 7 of China's 2017 National Intelligence Law of the People's Republic of China states: 'All organizations and citizens shall support
column40: and cooperate with national intelligence efforts in accordance with law
column41: and shall protect national intelligence work secrets they are aware of.'This erases the line between public and private sectors and places controls on tech companies to report material to Chinese security agencies. The threat posed by any tampering with undersea cables is serious
column42: and China's commitment to expanding its submarine cable network leaves the issue of its intent in a troubling gray area.The legacy of Deng Xiaoping is certainly mixed. While many would suggest that Mao unified the country (minus Taiwan)
column43: Deng made it rich. However
column44: the most problematic and challenging aspect is that meaningful political reform within the CCP was always severely limited. This total failure to undertake a long called-for Fifth Modernization of the country's politics opened the space for increased authoritarianism and the rise of hegemonic power projection.China has demonstrated tremendous capability in building economic and military power. There is no dispute that it has risen. But China's foreign policy assertiveness and the posturing of 'wolf warrior diplomacy' have generated serious concerns about China's intentions – especially at sea. The current international system
column45: constructed by the dominant Western powers

These powers therefore have no choice but to either contain or confront China's extension of power at sea – whatever its ultimate intentions.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2022-09-28-071258.jpg;False;;18.476143;dd07146b5b72127500d31d9d90d1b8b0;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 89;What AUKUS and Afghanistan Tell Us About the US Asia Strategy;;2021-09-21 14:30:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2021/09/what-aukus-and-afghanistan-tell-us-about-the-us-asia-strategy/;thediplomat.com;Put together
column2: these two seemingly unrelated developments signal a new U.S. strategy in the competition with China.;"AdvertisementThe Taliban's rapid takeover of Afghanistan made headlines around the world. Few could have predicted that the predominantly Pashtun
column3: Islamic fundamentalist group would resuscitate their power in summer 2021
column4: after waging a 20-year insurgency against the U.S.-backed government in Kabul.In the aftermath of the U.S.-led invasion of 2001
column5: the Taliban began challenging NATO and taking back vast territories in the southwest of Afghanistan after heavy regrouping in Pakistan. The signing of a withdrawal agreement with the U.S. in Doha emboldened the Taliban to press their advantage and end the 20-year-old war. Backed by the Pakistani Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI)
column6: the Taliban notched swift successes as the U.S. withdrew its remaining troops from Afghanistan. By August 2021
column7: the Taliban had conquered all of Afghanistan's major cities and ultimately Kabul. By September
column8: they controlled the entire country after taking the mountainous Panjshir Valley
column9: where the National Resistance Front
column10: led by Ahmad Masoud
column11: had vowed to continue fighting the Taliban.Less than a month later after the fall of Kabul
column12: U.S. President Joe Biden
column13: U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson
column14: and Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison launched a trilateral security partnership
column15: called AUKUS
column16: to counter China. The AUKUS pact will enable Australia to deploy nuclear-powered submarines
column17: which are supposed to be built in Adelaide
column18: making Canberra the seventh country in the world to have submarines propelled by nuclear reactors. The core goal of this trilateral pact is to contain the threat emanating from China's increased leverage in the Indo-Pacific and its worldwide ambitions. Not surprisingly
column19: the formation of AUKUS spilled over into intensified Indo-Pacific tensions
column20: especially over Taiwan
column21: the South China Sea
column22: and the East Indian Ocean.At the first glance
column23: it seems that the developments in Afghanistan and Australia are unrelated events. One centered in the Hindukush Mountains; the other echoed 9
column24: 500 kilometers away
column25: in the middle of the Indo-Pacific waters. Nevertheless
column26: within a broader context
column27: these two events are interconnected at the heart of the China-U.S. competition
column28: forming the bookends of a new strategy I dub 'leave the Belt
column29: press the Road.' By this
column30: I mean that the U.S. will increasingly target China's Maritime Silk Road
column31: while largely abandoning the land-based Silk Road Economic Belt. Succinctly put
column32: the major front of the Sino-American infrastructure war is the Indo-Pacific rim
column33: while the heart of Eurasia will be left to the destabilizing forces of the region.The establishment of AUKUS reaffirms the fact that the cornerstone of Washington's China containment strategy is pitched in the Indo-Pacific zone. Therefore
column34: U.S. attention to the geographical locations at the heart of Eurasia will be degraded – but this is part of the plan. The U.S. lack of will or capability to keep up its presence in Eurasia may intentionally disrupt the stability of the Belt by generating a threatening power vacuum. The U.S. swift withdrawal from Afghanistan and the following empowerment of Taliban have the potential to destabilize Chinese land-based projects in Central Asia
column35: Pakistan
column36: and even Xinjiang. Although the chaotic drawdown of the war in Afghanistan has taken a toll on Biden's standing back home
column37: the geopolitical vacuum in Afghanistan following the U.S. withdrawal could be utilized to counterbalance Moscow
column38: Beijing
column40: who will now have to contend with the empowerment of Islamic extremists in Central and West Asia.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Despite the seemingly sudden developments of the last two months
column41: this trend in the global competition is not new. After almost a ten-year hiatus
column43: also known as the Quad
column44: was formally resumed in August 2017 to contain Beijing's maritime power projection in the South China Sea and the Indian Ocean. Initially founded in 2007
column49: heralding the possible formation of an Asian NATO to counter the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO). There were even rumblings about a 'Quad Plus' when South Korea
column51: and Vietnam joined the meetings in March 2020. The Malabar exercises hosted annually by India are a major manifestation of its military component.In a 2021 joint statement on 'The Spirit of the Quad
column55: and the United States highlighted 'a shared vision for a Free and Open Indo-Pacific (FOIP)
column56: ' and a 'rules-based maritime order in the East and South China Seas' to counter China's maritime threat. This progress was concomitant with the EU's increasingly strategic attention toward the Indo-Pacific zone as France

column59: the AUKUS pact would supplement the Quad in counterbalancing China's increasing influence in the Indo-Pacific.NGet briefed on the story of the week

column1: Although AUKUS and the Quad both show muscle and military technology firepower
column2: they lack a foundational proportionality. The Belt and Road Initiative is Beijing's major geoeconomic strategy for challenging the U.S. hegemony around the globe
column3: while the Quad and AUKUS are geostrategic and military tools in countering China in the Indo-Pacific zone. Phrased differently
column4: there is a strategic gap between the threatening force and the deterring counterforce. It was this proportionality gap that pushed the Biden administration to launch a specific geoeconomic counterforce against the Belt and Road: Build Back Better World
column5: or B3W
column6: announced in June at the G-7 summit in Cornwall
column8: B3W aims at countering Chinese global leverage through massive investment in the infrastructural development of the developing countries by 2035. The plan is supposed to provide around $40 trillion
column9: mainly from the private sector
column10: to low- and middle- income countries
column11: from Latin America and the Caribbean to Africa and Asia. Guided by the standards and principles of the Blue Dot Network (BDN)
column12: the B3W projects vow to focus on several domains
column13: particularly climate
column14: health and health security
column15: digital technology
column16: and gender equity and equality. The global scope of the B3W would equip its G-7 partners with different geographic orientations to target specific low- and middle-income countries across the world. While the U.S. focuses on the Indo-Pacific
column17: Japan and the EU will concentrate on Southeast Asia and the Balkans
column19: all with the aim of countering Chinese global influence.The upcoming competition between B3W
column20: now backed by the Quad and AUKUS
column21: and the Chinese BRI is a prelude to the China-U.S. infrastructure war. The B3W is not just a U.S. financial response to China's economic ambitions; rather it is a strategic effort to transform the rising geopolitical arrangement of Greater Eurasia and its coastal waters by establishing a new model of development. In other words
column22: the United States is unleashing a geoeconomic counterforce against China's BRI to achieve its grand geopolitical goals by mobilizing its private companies and those of its allies in massive infrastructure investment to control the BRI corridors. The new infrastructure war will determine the trajectory and path of the geopolitical battle between China and the U.S. for world domination in the 21st century.On the other side of the global power equation
column23: China has successfully controlled Central Asian markets while pursuing its 'positive balance' doctrine among all parties in West Asia
column24: wherein expanding cooperation with Beijing may be the only point all the regional powers can agree on. China's dramatic economic growth and internal stability have enticed non-democratic political systems in the region. Beijing has established close economic relations with the Persian Gulf sheikhdoms
column25: Israel
column26: Iran
column27: and Turkey at the same time. However
column28: Beijing's successful policy in cementing its connection with West Asia through Central Asia may be disrupted by threats emanating from Afghanistan. The U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan will destabilize the land-based Belt while heavy pressure by the Quad and now AUKUS will counter the maritime Road.The world is on the verge of China-U.S. international competition. Regional developments
column29: like AUKUS
column30: and domestic transformations
column31: like the Taliban takeover of Kabul
column32: will both be crucial elements in the grand chessboard between the U.S. and China. Now that the dust has settled in Kabul
column33: one could see how the Taliban's rising power is concomitant with the trilateral AUKUS pact. Both are milestones for a new phase in the Sino-American competition: leave the Belt

column1: 90;What Happened To China's BRI Projects in Malaysia?;;2021-10-05 12:30:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2021/10/what-happened-to-chinas-bri-projects-in-malaysia/;thediplomat.com;Of the slew of BRI megaproject deals signed over the first five years of the initiative
column2: most have either been canceled or come to a standstill.;"AdvertisementIt has been nearly a decade since China's first Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) project gained a foothold in Malaysia
column3: and despite the slew of megaproject deals signed in the initial five years
column4: many have either come to a standstill or were cancelled.Among the few BRI projects left standing is the East Coast Rail Link (ECRL)
column5: which Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob
column6: the country's third premier since Najib Razak was voted out of office in May 2018
column7: vowed to resume and complete under the 12th Malaysia Plan.The 50 billion Malaysian ringgit ($11.9 billion) rail project linking the east and west coast of the Malaysian peninsula was subjected to multiple renegotiations and realignments following its suspension in 2018 by then Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.The ECRL was one of many BRI projects put on ice amid allegations that Najib's administration intentionally agreed to lopsided deals with China at inflated prices to bail out debt-laden state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). Both China and Najib have denied the bailout claim.The suspicions
column8: however
column9: were later confirmed after Mahathir's Pakatan Harapan government gained access to classified documents
column10: known as the 'red files
column11: ' which indicated that a number of China's BRI projects
column12: such as the ECRL and two pipeline projects
column13: contained dubious terms.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Mahathir made it clear that the ECRL was inflated by up to 30 billion ringgit to pay down 1MDB's debts
column14: and that only 15 percent of the project's construction had been completed while 20 billion ringgit or 33 percent of the railway link's initial 60 billion ringgit price tag had been paid.It was the same with the multi-product petroleum and gas pipeline project in Sabah where only an average of 13 percent of the pipelines' construction had been completed even though 8.3 billion ringgit or 88 percent of the projects' value had been paid to the contractors.NGet briefed on the story of the week

column4: other BRI projects continue to remain in limbo.An attempt to restart the multi-billion ringgit Bandar Malaysia fell through earlier in July after the parties involved could not agree on terms to proceed with the project. A source told local daily The Star
column5: however
column6: there is still hope that the project will resume once the epidemic subsides.Bandar Malaysia was due to house the terminal for the now-terminated high-speed rail (HSR) link between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. While the HSR was not directly a BRI project
column7: the railway would have been in line with China's plans for rail links running from Kunming to Singapore.Meanwhile

column9: the local developer of the BRI coastal reclamation project
column10: after years of inactivity.The project had long been described as a white elephant
column11: as it included the construction of a mega deepwater port in a nation that already has plenty of existing facilities
column12: as well as hotels
column13: luxury housing
column14: and various tourist attractions.China expert Ngeow Chow Bing of the University of Malaya told South China Morning Post that the termination will unlikely impact Belt and Road cooperation as problems linked to the Melaka Gateway project were unrelated to Malaysia's foreign policy stance. 'It is just a failed project
column15: ' he said.At Country Garden Holdings' Forest City
column16: dubbed as the biggest overseas project by a Chinese developer
column17: the company cut its Malaysia staff to 500 as of June this year following three rounds of retrenchments over the last 18 months
column19: 700 in 2019.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Sales of Forest City's property ground to a halt amid COVID-19 travel bans
column20: with the company reportedly selling fewer than 10 home units over the same period.Malaysia is not the only country to have pushed back against China's BRI vision out of fear of being overly indebted for projects that are neither feasible nor necessary.Dr. Agatha Kratz
column21: an associate director at Rhodium Group
column22: in a podcast by the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) on COVID-19's impact on China's BRI projects

column24: international media started picking up on those setbacks and you know
column25: the attention on the initiative turned pretty sour
column26: ' Kratz said.Kratz said her dissertation work covering 24 Chinese overseas projects saw two-thirds of the projects being cancelled or shelved
column27: though she did not elaborate. Other recipient countries have opted to either delay or renegotiate some BRI terms amid growing criticism around their sustainability.The COVID-19 pandemic led to further deterioration of fiscal conditions in recipient countries as trade and tourism flows were disrupted by protracted lockdowns
column28: which could lead to a starker slowdown for China's BRI

column31: everyone likes to you know get a ribbon on a new project
column32: everyone likes to have five years of grace period to be able to get an infrastructure project to work

column34: and no one likes to run into trouble
column35: ' Kratz said.An AidData study that looked at 13

column41: and public protests.AidData said $11.58 billion in projects in Malaysia have been cancelled over 2013-2021
column42: with nearly $1.5 billion cancelled in Kazakhstan and more than $1 billion in Bolivia.China has since taken steps to rebrand the BRI as 'green and clean' through its Digital Silk Road and Health Silk Road. As of October 20 last year
column43: China has provided assistance to 150 countries and seven international organizations and exported over 179 billion masks

column48: the country doesn't seem inclined to return the favor by aligning with or being more favorable toward China – at least not yet.The BRI

column51: the relationship 'has grown cooler and perhaps more realistic.'With Malaysia too busy dealing with the COVID-19 pandemic and stabilizing the domestic political situation
