column1: 91;TikTok and Beyond: How China's Ascendancy in Digital Technology Challenges the Global Order;;2023-06-02 17:24:00;full;https://thediplomat.com/2023/06/tiktok-and-beyond-how-chinas-ascendancy-in-digital-technology-challenges-the-global-order/;thediplomat.com;"This isn't just a feud between two great powers; it's a competition for a new world order in cyberspace.";"Advertisement
When social media users create and share viral dances and awe-inspiring stunts
column2: they may not be aware that these same digital platforms are at the epicenter of a geopolitical power contest. In particular
column3: the rise of TikTok
column4: a platform owned by Chinese tech giant ByteDance
column5: has added a new dimension to the complexity of the 'world order.'

column1: The saga of TikTok
column2: which underwent a security review in the United States and made it onto the list of apps banned from government devices in Canada and Australia
column3: underscores developing lines of conflict being drawn around data sovereignty and the necessity for data governance. This isn't just a feud between two great powers; it's a competition for a new world order in cyberspace.

column1: Why TikTok?
TikTok is essentially a sibling version of Douyin
column2: a video-sharing platform developed by ByteDance. ByteDance started its journey through content aggregation across various internet portals and platforms within China. The company has perfected its AI algorithms to optimally match content with its intended audience
column3: continuously improving the algorithms based on the feedback of almost 1 billion users. On the various ByteDance platforms
column4: content is 'intelligently' pushed toward the audience most likely to appreciate it
column5: creating a potential addiction to the content being presented. Similar algorithms have been implemented on the Douyin platform.

column1: N
Get briefed on the story of the week
column2: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.

column1: Get the Newsletter
TikTok was established as an independent entity to distance itself from its parent company. It was tested and found successful in Asia
column2: including

column1: Japan

column2: a market typically challenging for foreign internet businesses to penetrate and survive. ByteDance's algorithms have revolutionized the traditional social media business model. It has shifted from the model of 'audiences searching for the right content' to 'content searching for the right audiences.' This paradigm shift disrupts the established hierarchy
column3: where content created by more well-known creators is more likely to be found by audiences in their searches.

column1: Enjoying this article?
Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.
When TikTok launched in the United States in 2017
column2: it became an immediate market success. In October 2018

column1: TikTok
became the most downloaded app in the United States. Globally
column2: as of 2022
column3: it had achieved 3 billion downloads
column4: and boasted over 1 billion active users each month.

column1: This success story of TikTok hasn't been entirely smooth and its future is still unknown. Under both the Trump and Biden administrations
column2: TikTok and its parent company
column3: ByteDance
column4: have been scrutinized for potential national security risks
column5: as critics worry that user data could be accessed by the Chinese government when deemed necessary under Chinese law.

column1: In the context of the larger narrative of great power competition
column2: TikTok exemplifies the dynamics at play. It signifies China's technological prowess and the global impact of its digital innovations. TikTok's saga is more than just a business narrative; it symbolizes the ongoing struggle for a new world order in cyberspace.

column1: Advertisement
A New Territory for Geopolitical Competition
The  pandemic catalyzed a surge in online activities
column2: accelerating the process of

column1: digital transformation
as billions of users and devices interconnected online
column2: generating an astronomical amount of data. Increasingly
column3: such data is shared and exchanged across national borders
column4: as global trade moves toward digitized services.

column1: Data has indeed become a crucial resource in the digital economy
column2: with cyberspace quickly emerging as a new arena for human activities
column3: becoming a geopolitical domain akin to land
column4: sea
column5: air
column6: and outer space. However
column7: unlike resources in other geopolitical territories
column8: data can be shared and reused

of global netizens use U.S.-based internet browsers

of online data is in English

column1: Value Clashes

The internet has been built and developed based on network effects – the larger the network

approach

. China has been exporting its digital infrastructure

column9: payment

column1: Emerging Digital Order?
History illustrates that rivalries between great powers over establishing a new world order can have substantial ramifications. In the realm of cyberspace
column2: unlike physical resources such as oil or critical minerals
column3: data
column4: as a virtual entity

column1: The internet

column4: transport networks

As the Kazakhstani regime seeks economic growth and may tighten repression
column3: Beijing's importance could grow.;"AdvertisementAfter a tumultuous week across Kazakhstan in early January
column4: the situation has stabilized. Kazakhstani security forces
column5: with the help of troops from Collective Security Treaty Organization (CSTO) allies
column6: put an end to both the peaceful protests and the violent riots that followed them. The political elite around President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev strengthened its hand in an accelerated intra-elite struggle that was intertwined with the unrest
column7: forcing several loyalists around former president Nursultan Nazarbayev out of their posts.While events were confined to Kazakhstan and stemmed from domestic issues
column8: they also had an international dimension. Russia received predominant attention
column9: which focused on the dispatch of around 2
column10: 500 CSTO troops. Even after their withdrawal
column11: the Kremlin is said to have proved its effectiveness and gained considerable leverage over Kazakhstan.This has left considerations about Kazakhstan's other powerful neighbor – China – at the sidelines. The absence of the China factor is all the more striking as the increasing Chinese stakes and leverage in Central Asia
column12: and particularly Kazakhstan
column13: have taken center stage in debates ever since its Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) was announced in the capital of Kazakhstan in 2013. Kazakhstan has since been a linchpin in the megaproject. As unrest has shaken Kazakhstan and political power within the country is shifting
column14: some effects on China-Kazakhstan relations are inevitable.Ties between the two states have focused on the economy. A first wave of Chinese investments
column15: prior to around 2014
column16: was overwhelmingly dedicated to the energy sector. Today
column17: around 20 percent of China's gas imports come from and through Kazakhstan. Another major area has been transport. Volumes of rail cargo – mostly transiting Kazakhstan between China and Europe – have increased impressively each year. An often overlooked but increasingly central pillar of the BRI in Kazakhstan
column18: representing a second wave of investments picking up from 2016
column19: is manufacturing and heavy industry. Kazakhstan and China concluded agreements to shift production capacity out of China and help Kazakhstan diversify its economy. Fifty-five joint projects worth $28 billion are foreseen and have been partially implemented in metallurgy
column20: engineering
column21: chemicals
column22: and other sectors.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column23: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: Neither pipelines nor railways have been affected by the unrest
column2: the Kazakhstani ambassador to China has declared
column3: citing their remoteness from major population centers. The Chengdu-based New Silk Road Intermodal (NSRI) confirmed that operations in Dostyk and Altynkol/Khorgos – the two major cargo terminals at the China-Kazakhstan border – were running smoothly. Air traffic
column4: for which Almaty airport is a major hub
column5: suffered temporary delays and disruptions
column6: and some oil companies were temporarily forced to cut production. To date
column8: there have been no reports about potential harm or disruptions to Chinese businesses or citizens in Kazakhstan.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.As the period of unrest was short
column9: did not entail long strikes
column10: and was focused on (but not limited to) the country's west and Almaty
column11: economic effects were temporary and minimal. It pushed up prices for oil and uranium
column12: though. In the long run and depending on further political and economic events in Kazakhstan
column13: including reform efforts
column14: the events of January 2022 are likely to affect the investment climate.The major reason why Chinese projects were unharmed lies in the fact that the protests did not have a xenophobic or explicitly Sinophobic dimension. This is remarkable since China-skepticism in Kazakhstan is widespread
column15: building on China's potential economic domination and treatment of Muslims – including ethnic Kazakhs – in its Xinjiang region. Kazakh nationalist sentiment is generally considered on the rise. In 2020
column16: southern Kazakhstan witnessed deadly clashes between Kazakhs and members of the Dungan minority
column17: which is of Chinese origin. However
column18: slogans in that vein did not appear in January 2022 and protesters appear not to have been mobilized by such considerations.At the political and inter-governmental level
column19: Chinese officials have voiced concerns about the unrest in Kazakhstan
column20: but to a limited extent and in line with Beijing's official policy of non-interference. As a first official reaction
column21: on January 6
column22: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi declared the protests an internal Kazakhstani affair. On 7 January
column23: Xi Jinping sent a verbal message to Tokayev. Xi praised Tokayev for his reaction
column24: and offered assistance against 'color revolutions
column25: ' echoing the Kazakhstani government's framing of the unrest as having been instigated by external powers.AdvertisementAs such
column26: China did not get involved
column27: particularly not with troops. Igor Denisov
column28: writing for The Diplomat
column29: raised another important factor in this regard: China may lack in-depth understanding of intra-elite dynamics and intelligence on events in Kazakhstan
column30: particularly compared to Russia. Chinese isolationism during the pandemic – including among its diplomats abroad – has only contributed to this gap. Accordingly
column31: Beijing is likely to have been taken by surprise both by the unrest and the elite reshuffling in Kazakhstan
column32: adding inability to its unwillingness to get involved. Had border security been compromised
column33: though
column34: China may have militarized and closed its border with Kazakhstan
column35: possibly also citing strict COVID-19 rules.CSTO troops' role in helping to stabilize the situation was likely in line with Beijing's interests
column36: and Chinese officials may have been informed prior. Russia's involvement in Kazakhstan came at the request of its government and not a result of the Kremlin's adventurism and unpredictability
column37: which are not viewed favorably in Beijing. While its intervention strengthened Russia's standing as a security guarantor in the region
column38: lasting and one-sided Kazakhstani dependence on its northern neighbor is unlikely to be a result of it.Stability is Beijing's key interest in Kazakhstan
column39: in order to maintain supply chains
column40: uphold uninterrupted trade flows and cargo transit
column41: and to secure China's western border. Further support for Kazakhstan's regime is likely to occur in the framework of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO)
column43: in the form of joint exercises
column45: and law enforcement cooperation. The member states of the CSTO and the SCO are largely united in their authoritarian style of rule and in their definition of and opposition to terrorism
column47: and violent extremism.The growing influence of Tokayev and his loyalists at the expense of the old elite around Nazarbayev is unlikely to be opposed by Beijing
column48: if this power struggle is not overtly disruptive
column49: which would threaten stability and Chinese investments. As such
column50: Beijing is unlikely to have a strong preference for a particular Kazakhstani leader
column51: and may lack the necessary intelligence to be a factor in these shifts to begin with. To Beijing
column52: it does not matter too much who is in charge
column53: as long as someone is in charge. Given his international experience and Chinese language skills
column54: Tokayev is likely to be a welcome interlocutor for Beijing.Some (albeit unlikely) alternative governments may pose risks for Chinese interests if they were to build on China-skepticism and Kazakh nationalism. However
column56: any Kazakhstani government is set to maintain good relations with China. Trade ties with all neighbors
column58: and attracting investments are key to economic growth and to satisfying popular demands in Kazakhstan
column59: which is key to mitigating the risk of further unrest. In this
column60: the regime only succeeds if reforms are genuine
column61: and serious address the issue of inequality.China is poised to maintain and may even increase its crucial position in Kazakhstan in order to foster the country's economic development. The Chinese development model – and Chinese investments – offer the biggest promise for Kazakhstan's economic modernization. Russia or an increasingly reluctant and distant West offer little in that regard. Chinese commentators have indicated the prospect of Chinese economic assistance to Kazakhstan following the unrest. In that
column62: Beijing would pursue its logic of 'stability through development.' While immediate assistance through loans or investments is unlikely and not warranted
column63: the Kazakhstani government may refer to Beijing's offer of support at a later point in time.Were the Tokayev regime to increase repression to quell the potential for further dissent and protests
column64: Russia and China would be obvious partners. Surveillance technology developed and applied in China could be tempting and an element of the diffusion of authoritarian norms and tools. A Chinese commentator with the Global Times has even explicitly suggested applying Beijing's experience in Xinjiang to Kazakhstan. Boosting the use of technological tools would build on their already-rising use in recent years
column65: particularly through the pandemic. As early as 2019
column66: Tokayev instructed the government to follow the Chinese model of digitalization. This has included the use of facial recognition
column69: and video surveillance in cooperation with Chinese tech companies. Through such technologies
column70: China's 'Digital Silk Road' entails a significant political component.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.To sum up
column71: unrest in Kazakhstan has appeared to mostly lack a China-related dimension
column72: as political and economic ties between the two governments were maintained and the old order restored. As a nationalist turn in Kazakhstan or a reorientation of its foreign and economic policy are currently unlikely
column73: China will remain an important – and as Western states and companies may become more hesitant to engage with Nur-Sultan even an inevitable – partner for the Kazakhstani government. Accordingly
column74: even though Kazakhstan will remain adamant about not being overly dependent on its neighbor to the east
column75: China's importance may only grow.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2022-01-20-202958.jpg;False;;17.936935;eba0ab52266466141f382ee4458239f8;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

Assessing the China-Georgia Strategic Partnership;;2023-08-04 13:30:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2023/08/building-bridges-or-shifting-course-assessing-the-china-georgia-strategic-partnership/;thediplomat.com;Despite longstanding diplomatic flirtation
column2: the announcement of a strategic partnership between the two countries still came as a significant surprise.;"Advertisement

column1: From July 27-31
column2: a delegation from Georgia
column3: led by Irakli Garibashvili
column4: paid an official visit to China. The visit began with a notably warm welcome at the airport
column5: followed by meetings between Garibashvili and Chinese President Xi Jinping
column6: as well as Premier Li Qiang. Subsequently
column7: China and Georgia jointly announced the elevation of their bilateral ties to a strategic partnership
column8: pledging to bolster policy coordination and alignment in development plans under the framework of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and promote two-way trade and investment.

column1: In a joint statement issued by China and Georgia
column2: the two states expressed their intentions to intensify cooperation in various sectors
column3: including transport
column4: telecommunications
column5: infrastructure modernization
column6: digital technologies
column8: railway networks' upgrading and expansion
column9: and environmental protection.

column1: While hosting his Georgian counterpart
column2: Li expressed China's willingness to work closely with Georgia to carry forward their long-standing friendship and enhance strategic communication. Both countries see the establishment of the bilateral strategic partnership as an opportunity to deepen pragmatic cooperation
column3: benefiting their respective nations and peoples.

column1: Additionally
column2: besides the strategic partnership
column3: the countries also signed a bilateral cooperation plan between the governments of China and Georgia within the BRI framework.

column1: Get briefed on the story of the week
column2: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.

column1: Get the Newsletter
Over the years
column2: I have closely observed the developments in China-Georgia relations. In a 2016

column1: article
for The Diplomat
column2: I boldly asserted that Georgia had the potential to play a significant role in China's Belt and Road Initiative. Three years later
column3: in another

column1: article

column2: I maintained that Georgia could still serve as a hub for China
column3: but only if the BRI survived.

column1: Enjoying this article?
Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.
Georgia's unique position as a connector state between the Eurasian interior and Europe has attracted Chinese interest for some time now. Moreover
column2: the ruling Georgian Dream party has shown a favorable attitude toward Chinese leadership. Garibashvili himself expressed warm sentiments in a speech at Peking University in 2015

column1: emphasizing that
'there is no country in the region that is more open to Chinese business and investment
column2: Chinese people and culture or Chinese innovation and ideas than Georgia.'

column1: Despite this diplomatic flirtation and openness
column2: the recent announcement of a strategic partnership between the two countries still came as a significant surprise. It marks a notable milestone in the bilateral relationship and signals a deepening commitment to enhance cooperation and coordination in various sectors
column3: especially within the framework of the BRI.

column1: China-Georgia Relations: The Background
Advertisement
China and Georgia established diplomatic relations in 1992
column2: with China being among the first countries to recognize Georgia's independence. However
column3: at that time
column4: Beijing had limited interests in the region. Trade between the two countries amounted to a mere $3.7 million at the end of the 20th century.

column1: Throughout the 2010s
column2: cooperation between Georgia and China mostly revolved around economic matters. Despite the originally modest trade figures
column3: significant growth occurred in this domain. Initially
column4: Chinese involvement in Georgia was mainly limited to individual projects and credit lines. However
column5: over time
column6: China's presence expanded substantially
column7: establishing itself as a major player in Georgia's economic landscape.

column1: Notable Chinese investments in Georgia include the construction of the Khadori Hydro Power Plant by Sichuan Electric Power Corp China (SEPC). The China Xinjiang Hualing Group became the largest Chinese investor in Georgian mining and timber production. Furthermore
column2: an ambitious 51.6-kilometer section of a Chinese-built highway
column3: featuring 96 bridges and 53 tunnels
column4: is cutting through Georgia's rugged and mountainous terrain
column5: with costs rising to nearly $1 billion.

column2: Georgia took significant steps to enhance its economic cooperation with China by signing a Free Trade Agreement
column3: making it the only country in the region with such an agreement with China. This move opened Georgia's market for 96.5 percent of Chinese goods
column4: while China reciprocated by providing duty-free access for Georgian export products
column5: including wine
column6: mineral water
column8: fruits
column9: and more
column10: accounting for 94 percent of goods.

column1: As noted by
Michael Cecire

column2: growing Chinese economic influence around the world often goes hand in hand with deepening political engagement. While it may seem puzzling that a country with a population of 4 million and a GDP of just $24.6 billion could become a major interest for the world's second-largest economy
column3: there are other factors driving the Sino-Georgian strategic partnership.

column1: The Middle Corridor in the Spotlight
While Georgia brings some assets to the table
column2: such as its economic potential and natural resources
column3: I believe that the primary aspect that has captured China's attention – and led to the establishment of the Sino-Georgian strategic partnership – is Georgia's strategic location
column4: particularly its significance for the Middle Corridor of the Belt and Road Initiative. The Middle Corridor is a critical component of the BRI
column5: aiming to establish efficient trade routes and transportation links between China
column6: Central Asia
column8: and Europe. As a connector state situated in the South Caucasus region
column9: Georgia serves as a crucial gateway and transit point for goods moving between these regions.

column1: Enjoying this article?
Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.
During the meeting between Garibashvili and Li Qiang
column2: they assessed Georgia's transit potential and emphasized the significance of developing the Middle Corridor. They acknowledged that this corridor's importance had grown even more crucial in light of the current global challenges.

column1: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has resulted in a redirection of trade routes to the Middle Corridor
column2: which encompasses Georgia
column3: Azerbaijan
column4: the Caspian Sea
column5: and Kazakhstan. However
column6: Georgia has yet to fully capitalize on this opportunity.

column1: Following Garibashvili's China visit
column2: discussions surrounding the Middle Corridor have intensified. 'The importance of the Middle Corridor has been talked about for a long time
column3: but today this topic is extremely important for everyone – both for East and West – and the connection of these two markets cannot happen without the Middle Corridor
column4: ' Parliament Vice Speaker

column1: George Volski said
Advertisement
'Georgia's geopolitical position corresponds to the standard necessary for the development of the historical Silk Road
column2: and a lot of things will happen through Georgia
column3: ' he added.

column1: The Anaklia Port Saga
A critical focal point within the Middle Corridor is Georgia's Anaklia Port
column2: strategically located on the eastern edge of the Black Sea
column3: serving as the shortest route from China to Europe.

column1: Back in 2016
column2: when the Georgian government announced the conclusion of the tender for the construction of the Anaklia deep-water port
column3: the outcome surprised many experts. The contract was not awarded to the most viable bid involving two Chinese companies
column4: Power China–Hubei Hongyuan Power Engineering Company
column5: Ltd
column6: and China Harbour Engineering Company
column8: despite the Chinese government's backing. Instead
column9: the winner was the Anaklia Development Consortium
column10: a joint venture between Georgian Group TBC Holding and U.S.-based Conti International.

column1: China was initially seen as the preferred partner
column2: as the construction of the port in Anaklia was explicitly aligned with Beijing's new Silk Road trans-Eurasian transit development policy. However
column3: rumors circulated that the U.S. government played a role in the final decision.

column1: These speculations gained further weight when then-Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited Georgia in 2019 and offered strong support for the Anaklia Project
column2: while also bashing China. 'I communicated our hope that Georgia completes the [Anaklia] port project

column1: Pompeo said

. 'The project and others will enhance Georgia's relationship with free economies and prevent Georgia from falling prey to Russian or Chinese economic influence. Those pretend friends do not have Georgia's best interests at heart.'
However
column2: just a few months following Pompeo's visit
column3: the United States' Conti International withdrew from the Anaklia Development Consortium
column4: and subsequent political controversies and arbitration actions between the government and consortium members led to the abandonment of the project. As a result
column5: no construction progress has been made over the past seven years
column6: leaving the future of the Anaklia port uncertain.

column1: Despite the previous obstacles
column2: some developments have taken place just now. On February 20 of this year
column3: the Ministry of  and Sustainable Development of Georgia made an announcement indicating a new approach to revive the project. They initiated a call for expressions of interest to attract a private partner for a 49 percent stake in the Anaklia Deep Sea Port project
column4: while the state will retain ownership of 51 percent of the shares.

column1: 'It should be our task to start the construction of the Anaklia port this year. The construction of roads and highways is underway; we are working on the expansion of the airport and other concepts. So
column2: we have positive developments in all directions

column1: Garibashvili said
With the U.S. investor no longer involved
column2: does that mean that China will be awarded the contract this time? And would that mean something more than just an economic partnership?

column1: The Future of China-Georgia Relations
As an absolute majority of Georgians remain supportive of the country's Euro-Atlantic aspirations
column2: it is crucial that Georgia's partnership with China does not engender a shift away from its foreign policy goals. Rather
column3: it should rather serve as a potential solution to certain domestic challenges. However
column4: some concerns arise due to the current foreign policy approach of Georgia's ruling party
column5: which appears to involve criticism of the West while engaging in closer relations with Russia and now China. Additionally
column6: China's position regarding the conflict in Ukraine is not entirely aligned with the international community's stance.

column1: Advertisement

Given these circumstances
column2: the China-Georgia partnership may prompt questions about its broader implications for the country in the South Caucasus. As Georgia seeks economic benefits from cooperation with China
column3: it must carefully navigate potential political ramifications and ensure that its domestic and foreign policies remain aligned with its long-term goals and values.

column1: The Georgian government must strike a delicate balance between leveraging economic opportunities with China while upholding its Euro-Atlantic aspirations and adhering to internationally recognized principles. By doing so
column2: Georgia can harness the potential benefits of the partnership while maintaining its commitment to its broader geopolitical positioning and aspirations. But will Georgia's government be able – and
column3: more importantly
column4: willing – to do that?";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/08/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2023-08-04-124244.jpeg;False;;17.924654;49e984b70274f1a31e188005c74885d9;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 94;China's Digital Inroads in the Global South;;2022-08-19 15:15:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2022/08/chinas-digital-inroads-in-the-global-south/;thediplomat.com;China's party-state is deepening its hold on the digital information ecosystems of developing countries.;"AdvertisementEarlier this month
column2: U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman announced while on a tour of the Pacific Island states that U.S. President Joe Biden 'is looking forward to welcoming' Pacific Leaders in September 2022. Although the exact date of this unofficial Pacific Islands summit has not been announced
column3: the summit appears to be part of the larger U.S. response to an April 2022 framework agreement on security cooperation between China and Solomon Islands.The vaguely worded draft agreement
column4: leaked on social media in March – the final text has not been made public – discussed a deepening of relations between China and Solomon Islands to include the deployment of 'police
column5: armed police
column6: military personnel and other law enforcement and armed forces' at the request of the Solomon Islander government. The security agreement was met with surprise and concern from officials across the Indo-Pacific
column8: New Zealand
column9: and the United States.China's security ambitions
column10: not only in the traditional military realm but also in the digital world
column11: are growing across the Global South. Recently
column12: China tried to deepen security ties
column13: including network governance and cybersecurity
column14: through the failed bid to get Pacific Island states to sign its China-Pacific Island Countries Common Development Vision.To prevent China's party-state from deepening its hold on the digital information ecosystems of the Global South
column15: the U.S. and like-minded democracies need to offer viable digital democratic alternatives. Recent developments in the Pacific Island countries illustrate both China's vision for governance throughout the digital stack and how the party-state cultivates critical points of leverage through digital infrastructure development.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column16: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: The German Marshall Fund of the United States' Alliance for Securing Democracy
column2: in conjunction with the International Republican Institute
column3: has released a report titled 'China and the Digital Information Stack in the Global South.' Through five country case studies – Thailand
column4: Myanmar
column5: Uganda
column6: Nigeria
column7: and Jamaica – this report defines the digital information 'stack' and explores how China's party-state exports the digital information stack globally. Through our research
column8: we found that China's party-state works with industry to advance digital information operations related to geostrategic goals far beyond China's shores.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Global South countries need to be more aware of the tradeoffs of China's involvement in their digital information stacks. This involvement ranges from Chinese tech companies in the submarine internet cables and 4G and 5G mobile networks of Thailand and Myanmar
column9: to Beijing helping shape ideas on data and cyber sovereignty in Nigeria. Chinese technology companies' equipment is used to spy on domestic political opposition in Uganda. And
column10: lastly
column11: even far more resilient Jamaica has had its leaders express openness to Chinese technology companies' assistance in improving government efficiency and maintaining public safety.We found that even among these diverse countries
column12: facing disparate forms of Chinese involvement
column13: the level of awareness and caution about future Chinese leverage is too low. Regardless of whether a country is a strong democracy like Jamaica or ruled by a repressive military junta like Myanmar
column14: more scrutiny of China's involvement across the digital information stack is necessary.The digital information stack consists of five layers – network infrastructure
column15: devices
column16: applications
column18: and governance – and each layer of the stack includes several components. The network infrastructure layer includes physical infrastructure components like submarine and terrestrial cables
column19: telecommunications equipment
column20: and initiatives like the Digital Silk Road. The device layer includes mobile electronics like phones
column21: laptops
column22: and others
column23: as well as Internet of Things devices. The applications layer consists of software
column24: cloud services
column25: social media
column26: and digital payment services. The components of the content layer are the Chinese party-state's messages and narratives
column27: especially Chinese news programming on television and 'Wolf Warrior diplomacy' online. Lastly and most relevant for the Pacific Island countries
column28: the governance layer includes the proliferation of rules
column29: regulations
column30: policies
column31: and standards intended to govern digital spaces and tools.AdvertisementChina's efforts at influencing the governance layer in Global South countries are of particular concern because they frequently involve shaping policy and elite opinion in favor of a state-centric model of cyber governance
column32: in which regimes have broad latitude to control the flow of data and information within their territory. In countries like Thailand and Myanmar
column33: authoritarian governments seek to replicate China's 'Great Firewall
column34: ' a system of laws and technological measures that allows the Chinese party-state to shape 1.4 billion people's information space to suit its political preferences. Both Southeast Asian states have passed deliberately all-encompassing cybersecurity laws that emulate the ague and broad nature of China's 2017 Cybersecurity Law. And while the Thai government seems to have backed down from plans to control all digital traffic in and out of the country
column35: Voice of America reported in February 2021 that Chinese technicians were helping the junta set up such a system in Myanmar.In Uganda
column36: Chinese efforts at shaping the governance layer have focused on human capital development
column37: with China deploying extensive training programs at both the popular and elite levels aimed at fostering dependence on
column38: and brand loyalty to
column39: Chinese telecommunications firms like Huawei and ZTE. The programs target not only the technology sector
column41: intelligence
column43: and other spheres with profound influence over the future of Ugandan technology
column45: and censorship policies. Nigeria established the Nigeria Data Protection Regulation
column46: the name of which evokes the EU's GDPR
column47: but the substance of which hews closer to Chinese data policy regulations that focus on state sovereignty over personal data
column48: even when couched in the language of protecting privacy.Jamaica remains an outlier in many ways compared to the other case study countries. Jamaican government officials are wary of allowing Chinese technology companies due to their proximity to the U.S. and fear that Jamaican companies could violate U.S. sanctions and blacklisting laws that target companies like Huawei. Additionally
column49: Jamaica reformed its laws on libel
column52: giving it the most freedom of speech and expression out of the five countries examined in this report. However
column53: Jamaica shows that China can continue to make inroads with countries that have robust democratic institutions. Jamaican Prime Minister Andrew Holness expressed on a trip in 2019 to China that learning how to develop Jamaica's ICT infrastructure is a priority of the Jamaican government
column54: and that equipment from Chinese technology companies like Huawei could play a role in maintaining public order
column56: and improving government efficiency.Looking at these five countries
column57: we found several ways that the U.S. and like-minded democracies could assist Global South countries like those in the Pacific Islands when China proposes agreements like the China-Pacific Island Countries Common Development Vision and bilateral deals like the one with Solomon Islands. The U.S. and partners should bolster the efforts of Global South countries to monitor China's influence
column58: especially agreements and deals tied to ICT companies. Similarly
column59: these efforts could be used to improve legislative oversight of Chinese ICT companies and other entities seeking involvement in a host country's digital information stack. And lastly
column60: the U.S. and like-minded partners should offer support for developing and maintaining protected communication channels through initiatives like the Open Technology Fund.In conclusion
column61: to be viable alternatives to countries across the Global South seeking to improve their digital information stacks
column62: the U.S. and like-minded democracies need to use the full range of tools available to seek more transparency from ICT companies tied to the Chinese party-state. That way
column63: these countries appreciate the full scope of the agreements they enter into and can avoid the privacy
column65: and data security pitfalls they often entail.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2021-07-22-13.jpg;False;;17.862507;db98a341f3961be9d7372e3d27f2ef68;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 95;Big Ideas From Recent Trends in China's Data Governance;;2023-01-09 16:15:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2023/01/big-ideas-from-recent-trends-in-chinas-data-governance/;thediplomat.com;A look at the direction of China's data governance – and
column2: by extension
column3: the future of its digital economy.;"AdvertisementData will define China. Ever since the State Council enshrined data as a factor of production alongside land
column4: labor
column5: capital
column6: and technology in 2020
column7: the importance of regulating digital information has only continued to grow. Three big ideas have emerged in recent years: First
column8: how China intends to leverage data to drive its economy. Second
column9: the nuances behind increasingly intense data protection enforcement and an accountability blind spot in favor of public bodies
column10: including questions over the Cyberspace Administration of China's mandate. Finally
column11: the potential influence Chinese data governance ideals have on foreign governments that have become increasingly reliant on the former.Leveraging Data as a Factor of Economic ProductionChina's 14th Five-Year Plan for National Informatization (the 14th FYP)
column12: likely the world's first industrial policy for the digital era
column13: endeavors to 'activate the factor value of data' to 'shape a strong domestic market that is innovation-driven [and] high-quality.' This should be read together with top leader Xi Jinping's directives on economic development
column14: which espoused the need to 'regulate amidst development and develop amidst regulation.' Accordingly
column15: China's digital economy will rely on data not as a raw resource to be exploited by the free market
column16: but as a regulated commodity subject to close government oversight.There is an underlying belief that data should be directed to economic agents who can maximize the productivity of data. For one
column17: the proactive disclosure of government data for commercial/public use has been gaining traction. China revised its Open Government Information Regulations in 2019 to maximize 'the role of government information in… the people's production and… economic and social activities.'NGet briefed on the story of the week
column18: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: At the provincial level
column2: the Guangdong government has prohibited its offices from preventing the open utilization of public data and instituted the first-of-its-kind Chief Data Officer system to oversee such initiatives.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.But data sharing is a challenging proposition for widespread practice. Data has been likened to a semi-public good – non-rivalrous in that multiple actors can 'consume' data without affecting its stores
column3: but excludable in that some parties
column4: such as incumbent firms with large data reserves
column5: would have limited incentives to share them with competitors.State intervention could be a catalyst in the early stages. One notable effort toward commoditizing and sharing data was the establishment of the Shanghai Data Exchange (SDE) in November 2021. This quasi-government corporation positions itself as China's largest platform for businesses to buy and sell data with one another.Government influence similarly cannot be understated for private firms. Ant
column6: which is enroute to becoming a People's Bank of China-supervised financial holding company
column7: has promised to share all its Huabei consumer credit data with the PBOC
column8: notwithstanding that Ant's billion-user database has been a 'key competitive advantage for the company.'AdvertisementLegal instruments are also important in providing clarity around the implications of data sharing. Whereas the SDE was wary of challenges surrounding the standardization of data formats and data protection compliance (among others)
column9: the Shanghai Data Regulation was passed to provide legal basis and clarity for the SDE's operations. More fundamental regulations were released later – such as the draft National Information Security Technology Network Data Classification and Grading Requirements of September 2022 – to facilitate the standardization of data classification and grading rules across the industry.Enforcement of Data Regulations: The Private/Public DisconnectThe 14th FYP recognizes that China's private tech firms shall drive all aspects of national informatization
column10: with the caveat that the ministries will 'grasp promotion
column11: development
column12: supervision
column13: management… with both hands – and both hands must be strong…' This expressly empowers the government to rein in the tech market
column14: and by extension some of the most influential data handlers.In February 2022
column15: the Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) released an enforcement guidance that reiterated its campaign against illegal internet activity
column16: within which platform companies were mentioned around a dozen times. By July
column17: the Didi case had broken records as the nation's largest-ever data protection penalty
column18: a total of $1 billion shared among the company
column19: CEO
column20: and president.But there is a glaring omission in the CAC's enforcement: Public bodies have not been held to the same standards for data protection as private ones. This is despite the presence of large-scale data breaches that government bodies have been guilty of. In July
column21: more than 1 billion individuals' personal information held by the Ministry of Public Security (MPS) in Shanghai was disclosed and put up for sale. A month later
column22: Shanghai's health QR code system was hacked and 48.5 million individuals' personal information was put up for sale. However
column23: no official explanations were given and discussions on local social media were taken down.Ironically
column24: the MPS is one of the authorities jointly responsible for data protection alongside the CAC – it would be interesting to see how such top regulators regulate themselves.Amid such risks
column25: government-controlled data remain ever-important. Shenzhen's new AI Industry Promotion Regulations require the establishment of a public data system
column26: while Xi has promised to double down on building a digital government. Therefore
column27: the need to hold government bodies accountable for data handling has never been more pronounced.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.That said
column28: it is questionable whether the CAC is up for this task
column29: not least because the very mandate of the administration is mysterious. The CAC has no clear designation regarding whether it is a state (administrative) or Communist Party entity
column30: and how this affects its functions and accountability. Although the CAC has been assigned administrative functions by the State Council (e.g. investigating and penalizing Didi)
column31: it has been formally placed under the CCP Central Committee ever since China's 2018 government reshuffle.As a party entity
column32: the CAC is exempt from administrative law and other agency-regulating rules. As an administrative entity
column33: the CAC's signature moves against Didi and mobile apps have occurred with unprecedented legal authority. It is no easy task to predict what it thinks about enforcement against its sister organs (e.g. the MPS) from the public sector
column34: or if that even is a priority at all.International InfluenceAdvertisement'Building a community with a shared future in cyberspace' has been Xi's overarching internet governance goal since 2015. In November 2022
column35: the State Council published a white paper to propound 'multilateral and multiparty participation and consultation' in global internet governance
column36: and highlight China's role in 'in strengthening international cooperation in protecting critical information infrastructure and data security.'Instead of unilaterally prescribing formal legal standards for other governments
column37: China has made significant strides in building a shared 'community' under a brand of collaboration via
column38: for instance
column39: the China-ASEAN Digital Cooperation Forum and the World Internet Conference (WIC). But beyond branding and outreach
column40: a creeping 'Beijing Effect' portends the growing global influence of Chinese data governance ideals.The Beijing Effect is built upon the Brussels Effect
column41: which posits that law – for example
column42: the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) – may have regulatory effects outside its jurisdiction of origin. Notwithstanding whether a GDPR-esque globalization of Chinese data protection laws would occur
column43: the Beijing Effect is essentially different than the Brussels Effect because it is not about dispersing formal law. In particular
column44: the Chinese version entails a confluence of broader extralegal factors such as the foreign governments' demand for technological standard-setting and digital infrastructure.First
column45: Chinese actors play an increasingly important role in setting international standards for digital technology. The Made in China 2025 plan
column46: which seeks to ensure the country's self-reliance in advanced technology sectors
column47: has seen companies like Huawei rallying the development of global 5G standards across major markets including Africa and Europe. China's Global Data Security Initiative (GDSI)
column48: which seeks calls for governmental consensus on 'standards and rules of the global digital field' including cross-border data transfers
column51: the Arab League and several other countries.Second
column53: Chinese companies provide digital infrastructures for host countries
column54: thereby shaping the conditions under which those countries transition toward their own digital economies. Made in China 2025 proposes for China to command a 60-percent share in the global fiber optics market
column55: also a crucial component of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor
column56: which is in turn the largest component of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). Since 2020
column57: China has been supporting cloud developments in its BRI partner countries – for instance
column58: Alibaba penned a deal with Saudi Arabia's largest telecoms group to build the kingdom's cloud infrastructure in that year.The supply of digital infrastructure depends heavily on Chinese companies
column59: which are effectively overseen by the party-state. State-owned enterprises dominate the majority of BRI projects. Thus
column60: when it comes to the development of domestic legal frameworks to deal with concerns over data privacy in the fiber/cloud business or broader economic goals
column61: Beijing's directives would be implicitly transmitted via their foreign corporate representatives.ConclusionData has already started to define China. Faced with China's stagnating economy
column62: Xi is betting on the data-driven economy for a new lease of life. Regardless of his domestic woes
column63: China's international influence as a director of foreign development cannot be discounted.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat-china-flag-cyber2.jpg;False;;17.579515;41e78d06d5ce5fbdc15af668026154ba;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 97;Serdar Berdimuhamedov and Turkmenistan's Digital Transformation;;2021-07-20 14:00:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2021/07/serdar-berdimuhamedov-and-turkmenistans-digital-transformation/;thediplomat.com;As the Turkmen president's son continues his tour of top government positions
column2: digitalization remains a critical priority for the regime.;"AdvertisementOn February 12
column4: Serdar Berdimuhamedov was given a number of top positions by his father
column5: Turkmenistan's President Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov. The appointments ushered in the penultimate stage of a hereditary power transition that has been underway for several years now. Serdar was appointed the head of the Supreme Control Chamber
column6: a member of the State Security Council
column7: and more importantly the post of deputy chairman of the Cabinet of Ministers (Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov is the chairman)
column8: responsible for the implementation of the country's digitalization policy and integration of innovative technologies in the economy
column9: public governance and social spheres. In the following months
column10: Serdar enjoyed a further expansion of his political influence
column11: becoming a chair of the Turkmen-Japanese as well as (and more importantly) the Turkmen-Russian and Turkmen-Chinese intergovernmental cooperation commissions
column12: and the head of the Ashgabat-based International Association of Akhal-Teke Horse Breeding. Regarding the latter
column13: President Berdimuhamedov's obsession with Akhal-Teke horses is not a mere hobby but a state matter. It has been an important feature of Turkmenistan's nation-building project
column14: and also signifies his native tribe's dominant position in the country's sociopolitical system. Serdar's appointments altogether make him the second-most powerful political figure in the country
column15: in charge of strategically important domestic political projects and foreign policy initiatives
column16: especially in light of the power transition scheme and the country's ambitious digitalization endeavor.Digitalization has been high on President Berdimuhamedov's agenda since late 2018
column17: when he adopted the Concept of the Development of Digital Economy in Turkmenistan for 2019-2025. In February 2021
column18: the document was supplemented by the new State Program on the Development of the Digital Economy of Turkmenistan for 2021-2025. Berdimuhamedov senior presents digitalization as a matter of safeguarding national sovereignty. He has articulated its objectives as the modernization of state governance through rationalization of bureaucratic costs and improvement of the efficiency of state institutions and state-affiliated enterprises
column19: as well as diversification of the country's economic portfolio
column20: currently overly dependent on hydrocarbons as the source of revenue. Given the protracted socioeconomic crisis that Turkmenistan has been experiencing for at least the past five years
column21: which has significantly deteriorated living conditions for the population at large
column22: it certainly appears as a timely and reasonable policy measure. When properly administered
column23: digitalization does yield significant economic and social benefits for the public; however
column24: in Turkmenistan's case
column25: digitalization is as opaque a business as any other matter of the state.This is not to say that the country has not attained some progress in this policy area; the number of state bodies having their own websites is growing
column26: and so is the number of financial institutions that provide online banking services. According to MasterCard
column27: in 2020 the volume of non-cash transactions in Turkmenistan was 2.65 times higher than in the same period of 2019; the number of internet banking subscribers rose to 634
column28: 000 people
column29: while the number of customers using mobile banking reached 28
column30: 400 in 2021. The country's internet penetration rate is also on the rise
column31: according to DataReportal. Between 2020 and 2021
column32: the number of internet users in Turkmenistan increased by 459
column34: bringing the country's internet penetration rate to 33.2 percent. Nevertheless
column35: the current progress has been mainly perfunctory
column36: reflecting the government's prioritization of meeting easily-achievable quantifiable targets as indicators of progress
column37: such as those above
column38: with lesser consideration given to the issues of quality and functionality. State bureaucrats rush to launch websites and platforms to avoid a presidential reprimand
column39: which results in many of these platforms having outdated information and limited functional capacity. They are of little use to the public and business community. To make matters worse
column40: the government neglects the introduction of much-needed
column41: far-reaching reforms aimed at eradicating the underlying problems
column43: the knowledge and skills gap
column44: and the lack of a competitive business environment. For instance
column45: although the government recently slashed the price for internet access from 150 manat ($42.6 at the official rate
column46: roughly $5 at the black market rate) to 100 manat for 256 kbps connections
column47: and from 350 manat to 200 manat for 2 mbps connections
column48: these prices still remain unaffordable to the majority of the population
column49: given the enormous loss in purchasing power due to the economic crisis.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.The absence of meaningful progress is the result of not only low management capacity at the state institutions tasked with implementing the digitalization drive
column50: but also of the different view of digitalization and its utility at the very top
column51: which places the potential positive benefits for the general public at the bottom of policy priorities. For Berdimuhamedov senior
column54: is largely a vanity political project aimed at boosting his and Serdar's image as modernizing and forward-looking technocrats
column55: for both domestic and international audiences
column56: in step with current global trends. In 2019
column60: reportedly became the country's first region to fully integrate e-document workflows in its public governance system. In October 2020
column63: presented his father with a number of electronic and household appliances
column64: such as smart TVs and smartphones
column65: which he claimed had been produced in Turkmenistan. In the capacity of deputy chairman
column66: Serdar has put efforts into strengthening cooperation in high tech fields with Russia and China
column67: inviting them to participate in the country's ambitious 'smart city' project.The other aspect of digital transformation that looks equally appealing to Berdimuhamedov is its potential of generating wealth for his extended family network. Digitalization requires the allocation of significant investments in developing the requisite ICT infrastructure and procurement of hardware and services. In Turkmenistan
column68: such projects almost always have inflated costs for the purpose of siphoning off state funds and are carried out by companies connected to the president's close relatives and confidants
column69: as is the case with the companies building the Ashgabat-Turkmenabat highway at a cost of $2.3 billion. NGet briefed on the story of the week
column70: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: Last
column2: but not least
column3: the digitalization drive seeks to enhance state surveillance capabilities and thus government control of the population. Ashgabat is particularly committed to improving these capabilities and strengthening cooperation with Russia and China in that pursuit. Though always a priority for Turkmen leadership
column4: this area has gained utmost importance in light of rising Turkmen activism online in recent years. An increasing number of activists
column5: both at home and abroad
column6: have been posting content critical of the government
column8: the negligence of worsening socioeconomic conditions
column9: and inadequate responses to emergency situations. The spread of the coronavirus pandemic in the country in 2020 and the fumbled response to a hurricane that hit the eastern province
column10: inflicting severe damage
column11: are two key examples. These developments fueled a wave of anti-government protests staged by Turkmen studying and living abroad
column12: and even some smaller-scale protests inside the country. AdvertisementTo keep political discontent from gaining ground and jeopardizing the power status quo
column13: the government has responded by establishing a network of 'digital security departments' in almost every state and state-affiliated body; intensifying attacks on VPN applications and their users; intimidating activists and their families through a bundle of online and offline measures; improving the state's capacity to keep the population in an 'information vacuum'; and disrupting internet services
column14: especially during emergency situations
column15: to prevent seepage of information about the government's mismanagement.Realizing its limitations in technology and skills
column16: Ashgabat has intensified cooperation with Russia to satisfy its growing requirements. The two countries signed an agreement on cooperation in information security back in 2019
column18: ' which grants the state  excessive oversight powers under the pretext of securing public order. Serdar
column19: in the capacity of chair of the Turkmen-Russian commission
column20: has arguably taken this partnership a step further. In his meetings with Russian officials
column21: namely with Russia's Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin and the Deputy Chairman of Russia's Security Council Dmitriy Medvedev
column22: among others
column23: cooperation in security and high tech fields received great attention. These fields were reflected as priorities in a new program on Russian-Turkmen intergovernmental economic cooperation for 2021-2023 that Serdar presented to his father in May
column24: and which he approved and ordered Serdar to supervise.Although cooperation with China in this area is currently less pronounced
column25: it is likely to intensify in the years to come. Turkmenistan undoubtedly keeps a close eye on how such cooperation benefits the ruling regimes in neighboring countries. Chinese companies
column26: namely Huawei
column27: engaged in such projects have also been recurring guests in Ashgabat's innovative technologies-focused exhibition Turkmentel.At the time of writing of this article
column28: Serdar Berdimuhamedov was relieved of his duties heading the Supreme Control Chamber and being a member of the State Security Council. He was
column29: instead
column30: appointed deputy chairman overseeing economy
column31: banking
column32: and liaising with international financial institutions. He additionally became Turkmenistan's representative to the Economic Council of the Commonwealth of Independent States
column33: and was put in charge of overseeing the Balkan region. These appointments do not necessarily mean that Serdar's engagement with the country's digitalization endeavor has come to a halt. With succession looming on the horizon and him retaining core positions for cooperation with Russia and China
column34: with which partnership in high-tech issues will most likely continue to intensify
column35: his engagement with this policy area may be taking a different turn but not ceasing. The extent to which he is genuinely interested in and committed to this policy area
column36: if at all
column37: is another question with no clear answer as of now. Despite this
column38: it is most likely that Serdar
column40: will continue to make it to the headlines of local newspapers with digitalization-related success stories. After all
column41: if to take the state propaganda's messaging at face value
column42: digitalization projects suit him so well
column43: the same way Alabay sheepdogs
column46: his father's 'throne' do. This article is loosely based on the author's article on Turkmenistan's digitalization strategy written for the 'Digital Silk Road in Central Asia: Present and Future' report prepared by Davis Center (Harvard University) and the Sustainable Kazakhstan Research Institute (Narxoz University).";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;[];https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2021-07-20-6.jpg;False;;15.399194;6155842ef1f40d5b2734a17dab21f322;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 98;Geoffrey Cain on Xinjiang's ‘Perfect Police State';Sebastian Strangio;2021-08-24 02:05:00;full;https://thediplomat.com/2021/08/geoffrey-cain-on-xinjiangs-perfect-police-state/;thediplomat.com;'Every person in Xinjiang is documented down to their genetic makeup
column2: the sound of their voice
column3: and whether they enter their homes through the front door or the back.';"AdvertisementIn 'The Perfect Police State: An Undercover Odyssey Into China's Terrifying Surveillance Dystopia of the Future' (Public Affairs
column5: American journalist Geoffrey Cain examines the reality of daily life in China's Xinjiang region. Based on dozens of interviews with Uyghur exiles
column6: the book illuminates how the Chinese government has pioneered a series of law enforcement and surveillance techniques
column8: ' which have funneled hundreds of thousands into 're-education camps' and brought the region close to the reality depicted in George Orwell's '1984.'Cain spoke with The Diplomat's Sebastian Strangio about the genesis of the Chinese government's 'slow
column9: sinister erasure' of Uyghur culture
column10: the complicity of Western tech firms
column11: and the texture of daily life under the Party's unblinking eye.As your book reveals
column12: the ethnic minorities of Xinjiang refer to the region's regime of pervasive surveillance as 'the situation.' What does 'the situation' mean in practical terms for the average Uyghur or Kazakh? How and where does this system intersect with people's everyday routines?When Uyghurs and Kazakhs say 'the situation
column13: ' they're using a euphemism and codeword for all the surveillance that envelopes their daily lives. You can live your entire life in Xinjiang under the watch of the state.Of course
column14: other regimes have attempted this before. But what makes life in Xinjiang so foreboding is that the police have seized on new advances in artificial intelligence
column15: deep neural networks
column16: facial and voice recognition
column17: and biometric data collection to establish the all-seeing eye. Every person in Xinjiang is documented down to their genetic makeup
column19: and whether they enter their homes through the front door or the back.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.I wrote 'The Perfect Police State' because I wanted to show readers just how bad things can get. We live in an age where the unprecedented pace of technological advance has collided with the rise of authoritarians
column20: strongmen
column21: and major technology corporations with the muscle to overpower
column22: or the cash piles to buy off
column23: sovereign states. It's a dangerous mix
column24: and not one we should rule out coming to stable democracies in the West
column25: too.What was the genesis of the 'perfect police state' in China? Why did the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) embark on this far-reaching project
column26: and what is its ultimate goal?NGet briefed on the story of the week
column27: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: Under the CCP
column2: Xinjiang was always a far-off and restive region
column3: with its own identity
column4: language and culture distinct from the Han Chinese majority. And so Xinjiang was always the site of repression at the hands of the CCP
column5: fearful that the region could break off and form its own nation. It's what happened in the Soviet Union after its own collapse
column6: with the creation of the states of Central Asia
column7: such as Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan.AdvertisementChina was also concerned about terrorism in the region of Xinjiang – a small
column8: radical segment of the population was bent on launching terrorist attacks against China. In 1996
column9: China set up the Shanghai Cooperation Organization and signed up Central Asian nations for its mission to deter terrorist attacks and maintain security in the oil-rich regions of Eurasia. But it wasn't until September 11
column10: 2001 that China had a new impetus
column11: a shield of 'counterterrorism' with which to cover its repression of Xinjiang from criticism.Ultimately
column12: China's goal was to create a total security state. It wanted to monitor
column13: document
column14: and surveil every square meter and every person in Xinjiang
column15: buying its own propaganda that the region was teeming with terrorists. As one Chinese official in Xinjiang put it: 'You can't uproot all the weeds hidden among the crops in the field one by one – you need to spray chemicals to kill them all.' It sums up the CCP's approach the region.One strategy for creating a total security state is the absolute assimilation of Uyghurs
column16: Kazakhs
column17: and other Muslim minorities – about 12 million people – into the ways of life of the Han Chinese majority.This isn't a genocide in the sense of the twentieth century
column18: when fascist bureaucracies marched 'unwanted' populations to death camps and forced them into gas chambers. This is the slow
column19: sinister erasure of an entire culture
column20: through psychological and physical torture at concentration camps
column21: and never-ending surveillance that forces them to internalize the state's thinking and deny their own realities.It's also the generational erasure of the population through forced sterilizations of women. By that token
column22: under international law
column23: China has committed genocide against the people of Xinjiang.In your book
column24: you describe the sheer pervasiveness of the surveillance state in Xinjiang
column25: from the ubiquitous CCTV cameras to the use of data and algorithms in 'preventive policing
column26: ' which have collectively brought the region into the realm of that described in Orwell's '1984.' Can you give us a summary of what tools the Chinese government is using to police the minority populations of Xinjiang?In addition to '1984
column27: ' life in Xinjiang reminds me of the Tom Cruise film 'Minority Report
column28: ' based on the short story by the sci-fi writer Philip K. Dick
column29: who also wrote the classic book that inspired 'Bladerunner.'Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Xinjiang runs a 'predictive policing' program that uses AI
column30: camera technologies
column31: big data
column32: and algorithms to crack down on its people. If the system believes you will commit a crime in the future
column33: for whatever arbitrary reason
column34: you're in danger of getting a visit from the police and being taken to one of hundreds of known concentration camps. Without being charged with a crime
column35: you'll be brainwashed into 'cleansing' your mind of 'ideological viruses' and 'cancers.' That's literally the language that the Xinjiang authorities use.For China to build its all-seeing surveillance state
column36: it needed new advances in technology that converged around the same time period. The first was the hardware switch from the old analog CCTV cameras of the 1990s and early 2000s
column37: and the shift to digital
column38: where China led the way with state-run firms like Hikvision
column39: the world's largest maker of surveillance cameras.The second breakthrough covered the interconnected fields of deep neural nets
column41: and voice recognition in the early 2010s. New AI software had abandoned old algorithms and could now learn and train its own algorithms from vast amounts of data
column43: clicks and purchases. Microsoft
column44: Amazon and Chinese firms Megvii and SenseTime led the way
column45: eager to monitor customers under the profit motive.AdvertisementDo you think the CCP's anathematization of Islam is a product of its ideology and history
column46: or does it also reflect older patterns of interaction between the Chinese state and the empire's Muslim populations?I think the approach to Islam within its own borders
column47: comes from ideology and recent history under the Chinese Communist Party. When we go back before the communist takeover
column48: China had structured a different and more open set of relationships with Muslim populations in Central Asia and along the Silk Road.Party apparatchiks will say differently. But China was not a dominant hegemon over Eurasia for much of its history. Its imperial court didn't hand down edicts to a ragged and impoverished 'Muslim world.' The silk roads were replete with cosmopolitan and prosperous empires
column51: and made enemies with others.Eurasia would have looked more like Europe
column52: with scattered identities and languages and people
column53: that traded and fought. Claiming that China has an ancient
column54: imperial lineage over Central Asia would be like arguing ancient Rome
column55: the Renaissance and Mussolini are all a line of continuity to Italy now
column56: or the 19th century German Romantics inspired the rise of the Nazis.Mulan
column60: with a heritage closer to the Uyghurs and Kazakhs of today. Zheng He
column64: and was key to connecting China with Muslim nations. The Qing dynasty
column66: wasn't all that interested in Xinjiang
column67: finding control too costly.  The fact is that what we envision today as 'China' is really just a collection of disparate peoples
column69: who happen to be blanketed under the aggressive
column70: colonizing force of the CCP.In recent years
column71: the Uyghur human rights issue has become wrapped up with broader strategic tensions between China and the United States
column72: which makes it even less likely that the Chinese government will take U.S. concerns on board. What
column74: can concerned foreign governments and individuals do to address the situation in Xinjiang?Because of sanctions
column75: Chinese officials are terrified of the possibility that their assets in the U.S. and in the European Union could be exposed. But corporate transparency hasn't been a strong point in the U.S. system
column76: and in the Caribbean where tax havens are typically under British control. We're more than happy to host the dirty money of foreign kleptocrats as long as we can take a cut.Many abuses come down to forced labor in global supply chains. Reforming the global offshoring system would be a strong way of pulling out the rug from underneath the CCP's human rights abusers.The U.S. and U.K.
column78: need stronger laws that require real-name registration on corporations that would open the door to exposing and freezing the holdings of CCP kleptocrats. The sanctions so far haven't been enough. By going after individual companies and people
column80: not the problem. The CCP's human rights abusers get away with a lot
column81: stashing their dirty money in the West
column82: because Western law enforcement authorities are hamstrung from seeing who owns what in a transparent way.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;['Sebastian Strangio'];https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2021-08-24-1.jpg;False;;15.269742;1b9fd642640b6255f0ce52fd9aa1a22a;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'
