column1: 99;Israeli Semiconductors and the US-China Tech War;Shannon;2020-11-13 16:29:19;full;https://thediplomat.com/2020/11/israeli-semiconductors-and-the-us-china-tech-war;thediplomat.com;With its strong tech industry
column2: Israel has emerged as a rare beneficiary of the U.S.-China rivalry – for now.;"AdvertisementAs the United States and China find themselves locked in a battle for technological superiority
column3: Israel's semiconductor industry could become the next 'chip' on Washington's shoulder.Semiconductors
column4: the building blocks of modern digital technologies
column5: hold the key to achieving breakthroughs in everything from artificial intelligence (AI) and big data to robotics and virtual reality. Concerned that advances in Chinese semiconductor technology benefit the People's Liberation Army
column6: and seeking to maintain America's technological edge over the People's Republic of China
column7: Washington has gone on the offensive.Chinese telecom giant ZTE was among the first to be hit with crippling sanctions in early 2018
column8: after violating U.S. embargoes on Iran and North Korea. The move prevented ZTE from acquiring critical components from American semiconductor manufacturer Qualcomm. A year later
column9: the Trump administration slapped export controls on Huawei
column10: banning the sale of U.S.-made chips without prior license approval. In September 2020
column11: the United States expanded its 'Entity List
column12: ' imposing restrictions on China's largest state-funded chipmaker
column13: Semiconductor Manufacturing Industrial Corp (SMIC). Washington believes these companies are aiding the Chinese Communist Party in conducting espionage and supporting China's civil-military integration efforts.U.S. pressure has forced Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co to turn its back on its biggest customer
column14: halting sales to Huawei. Japanese chipmakers have suffered a similar fate and have found themselves scrambling to find new clients. Meanwhile
column15: in Europe
column16: the United States has effectively blocked Dutch company ASML from selling its most advanced lithography machine to SMIC. As shockwaves ripple through the semiconductor industry
column17: Israel has seemingly emerged unscathed. In fact
column18: 'Silicon Wadi' has found itself among the few benefactors of the fallout from the Sino-American tech-rivalry
column19: for now.NGet briefed on the story of the week
column20: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter 2018 saw Israel's semiconductor exports to China rise by 80 percent. Much of this growth has been attributed to Intel's increasing sales to China from its recently upgraded Israeli plant
column21: which some have argued served as a way around U.S. trade tariffs. But Gu Wenjun
column22: chief analyst at Shanghai-based semiconductor consultancy ICWise
column23: suggests that in the face of U.S. export restrictions
column24: Beijing has been looking to Israel to acquire these advanced technologies. Gu told the press that 'because of the trade war
column25: China and Israel's cooperation is closer than it has been before.'Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.China has indeed emerged as Israel's second-largest trading partner country
column26: and semiconductors have become an important component of their economic relationship. According to Israel's Export Institute
column27: the start-up nation sold $2.6 billion worth of semiconductors to China by the close of 2018
column28: accounting for 56 percent of Israel's exports to the eastern giant. That same year
column29: Chinese purchases of inspection equipment for semiconductor manufacturing from Israel climbed 64 percent
column30: reaching $450 million. Eli Assoolin
column31: CEO and co-founder of Israel start-up Newsight Imaging
column32: told the media his company has 'sold hundreds of thousands of chips to Chinese companies
column33: and the future looks very promising.'Chinese interest in Israel's semiconductor industry is driven by Xi Jinping's conviction that semiconductors are 'essential in China's plan to dominate the world's core technologies.' However
column34: China's domestic semiconductor production lags far behind other countries in terms of design and manufacture of advanced microchips
column35: which are technologically sophisticated and very difficult to produce. With local chipmakers only satisfying 16 percent of China's domestic semiconductor demand
column36: China has become the world's largest buyer of chips – spending roughly $300 billion annually since 2018.China seeks to address this vulnerability by becoming more self-sufficient regarding chip design and technology production. As it happens
column37: the strength of the Israeli semiconductor industry lies in the very things China wishes to acquire: superior design
column38: cutting edge R&D
column39: and the ability to integrate chips that interact smoothly between technologies. Many of the world's most advanced chips in the semiconductor industry were and are being developed in Israel. These include the Pentium MMX
column41: and Sandy Bridge from Intel
column43: Texas Instruments' Bluetooth chip
column44: and Motorola chips for cellular phones.AdvertisementChinese multinationals have noted these achievements and have set out to acquire their share of Israeli know-how. Huawei has been running an R&D center in Israel since 2016
column45: when it bought Toga Networks. Xiaomi followed suit
column46: establishing a presence in the Israeli market around the same time it started manufacturing its own semiconductors in 2017. Chinese funds have since joined in on the action
column47: with Neng Yang spending $35 million in 2019 to acquire Advanced Dicing Technologies (ADT); an Israeli company that develops specialized machinery for cutting silicon-based chips and microelectronic components. Chinese entities
column53: have all invested in Israeli venture capital firms that fund Israeli semiconductor companies.China's growing presence in Israel has not gone unnoticed. Since labeling China a 'strategic competitor' in its 2017 National Security Strategy
column54: the United States has been increasingly pressuring Jerusalem to curb its ties with Beijing
column55: especially regarding critical infrastructure and advanced technologies. Israel established a mechanism to vet foreign investment into potentially sensitive industries in 2019. Still
column56: this has not allayed U.S. concerns. In May 2020
column57: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told Israeli media that America does not 'want the Chinese Communist Party to have access to Israeli infrastructure
column59: all of the things that put Israeli citizens at risk.' He warned that engaging with China in sensitive areas could threaten intelligence sharing with the United States.Semiconductors are particularly sensitive in this context due to their dual-use nature. At the same time
column60: not all chips are created equal. Military technologies require custom chips
column61: different from those of consumer electronics and more difficult to produce. This is why not all Chinese semiconductor companies have been placed on the U.S. Entity List and why chipmakers like Intel have been granted licenses to continue selling certain chips to those that are. This disparity suggests that Israel has some room to maneuver provided it maintains well thought out controls to prevent dual-use transfers to China. Still
column62: as relations between the two great powers become increasingly adversarial
column63: even with these controls in place
column64: Israel risks finding its U.S. ally less forgiving of its delicate balancing act.Dale Aluf is a political psychologist and the director of research and strategy at SIGNAL
column65: Sino Israel Global Network & Academic Leadership
column66: a member of China's Silk Road Think Tank Association SRTA.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;Shannon;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat-2020-11-13-10.jpg;False;;15.115935;f1c662bb357f65714ba773c9b41069f6;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 100;Decoding Xi Jinping's ‘Asia Pacific Community With a Shared Future';;2022-12-09 14:15:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2022/12/decoding-xi-jinpings-asia-pacific-community-with-a-shared-future/;thediplomat.com;Against the U.S. decoupling push
column2: Xi envisions a hub-and-spokes model of a distributed supply chain network – with China as the 'hub.';"AdvertisementAddressing APEC business leaders in Bangkok
column3: Thailand last month
column4: China's President Xi Jinping commented on the East Asia miracle – the export-oriented growth model centered on Japan 40 years ago
column5: and proposed building an 'Asia-Pacific Community with a shared future.'The conception of an East Asian Community is hardly new. It was first raised by Prime Minister Koizumi Junichiro in the early 2000s
column6: and became the guiding ideology of Japan's Asian diplomatic and economic policy during Hatoyama Yukio's administration
column7: at a time when Japan was the largest economy in Asia. In a speech delivered to the Shangri-la Dialogue in May 2009
column8: Australia's Prime Minister Kevin Rudd
column9: too
column10: advanced a proposal for an Asia Pacific Community aimed at building integrated regional institutions to counter China's rise; it did not significantly affect Asia-Pacific regionalism.Most discourse about China's regional influence – and thus Xi's concept of an Asia-Pacific Community – is preoccupied with the hard question of how to tame China's rise
column11: as the question itself offers an academically puzzling and politically intriguing case. This essay aims to decode Xi's concept
column12: explain how it is different from those proposed before
column13: and draw implications for the Asian community.NGet briefed on the story of the week

column1: A Power Balance Shift in AsiaEnjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.As Henry Kissinger has noted
column2: great power competition is full of uncertainty and unpredictability and subject to potentially significant shifts in the balance of power. Since the end of the Cold War
column3: the United States has been the only superpower in the world
column4: and the U.S.-led world order has been grounded in core U.S. values of liberty and democracy
column5: which are shared by many Asian countries. The U.S.-led world order has been possible because of its economic and military power
column6: and because of its role as a provider of global public goods
column7: including defending its allies in war. AdvertisementWith China's rise as the world's second-largest economy
column8: what Xi wants is to promote an alternative order in which sovereign nations' unique values should be respected. Xi has emphasized the importance of all humankind's equal rights to develop and grow in prosperity
column9: whatever their ideology or political values. China has been actively increasing its contribution to global public goods by
column10: for example
column11: providing free COVID-19 vaccines to poor countries
column12: and by investing in infrastructure along the Digital Silk Road.  In the dynamic power balance between the United States and China
column13: competition between the two manifests at three layers: on the surface
column14: it is a trade war; in the middle
column15: it is a competition for technological leadership; and at its core
column16: it is the competition for a world order. Unlike other great powers in history that challenged incumbents
column19: has benefited greatly from the economic interdependence of the two countries. While a new world order is not on the horizon
column20: the U.S.-led attempt at decoupling China from the global supply chains
column21: especially the supply chains of critical technologies and strategic minerals
column22: is significantly influencing the geopolitical landscape
column23: especially in Asia
column24: including Australia. In Asia
column25: the shift of power balance has particularly significant geopolitical consequences. Japan's GDP was nine times China's in 1991 but had declined to about one-fifth of China's by 2021. China today accounts for more than half of Asia's economy and is the largest trading partner for most countries in Asia. With such a shift of economic power
column26: the U.S.-supported Asian model centered around Japan is broken
column27: and a new order of governance in trade
column28: finance
column29: and digital sphere that matches the rebalancing of power in Asia is urgently needed. The great power competition has caused many Asian countries to feel they have been caught in the middle. Lee Hsien Loong
column30: the prime minister of Singapore
column31: summed up this conundrum
column32: saying
column33: 'It will not be possible for Singapore to choose between the United States and China
column34: given the extensive ties the Republic has with both superpowers.' That sentiment is shared by countries such as South Korea and Japan
column35: the leaders of which both met with Xi during the recent summits. In Xi's vision of an Asia-Pacific Community with a shared future
column36: China is the 'hub
column37: ' connecting with each individual nation in a hub-and-spokes model of a distributed supply chain network. Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.To a large extent
column38: this is already happening. Amid the trade tensions between the United States and China
column39: some of China's manufacturing facilities were relocated to its Asian neighbors
column40: especially ASEAN countries. Contrary to a commonly-held view that these relocations have 'hollowed out' China's manufacturing power
column41: rather
column42: assembly and final production in those countries have become an extension of China's mega supply chain
column43: relying on the supply of intermediate goods from China and the export of the final goods from those countries
column44: to avoid increased tariffs on goods exported directly from China. The fact that China and ASEAN are now each other's largest trading partner is a manifestation of this change. According to China's customs data
column46: the volume of trade between China and ASEAN increased 13.8 percent
column47: reaching $798.4 billion. Intermediate goods account for over 60 percent of this trade
column48: suggesting the two parties are highly interdependent and embedded in each other's production networks. China's mega supply chain is built upon its industrialization in many backbone heavy industries
column51: which will take its Asian neighbors a long time to catch up with.If Xi's vision can be realized
column52: even if the United States were able to pursue a de-Sinicized strategy in supply chains
column53: an interdependent Asia-Pacific Community with China as a 'hub' might help Xi secure China's position in the world or
column55: deter the U.S.-led effort to decouple. AdvertisementImplications for the Asian CommunityThere are several reasons that
column57: it will not be feasible for Xi to realize his vision of building an Asia-Pacific Community
column58: at least at the governance level. First
column59: most of China's Asian neighbors have accepted the U.S.-led world order of freedom and democracy. A rising China with an authoritarian regime is perceived as a security challenge to those countries. Second
column60: for a country to take a global/regional leadership role
column61: it needs to have four dimensions in its structural power: (1) the capacity for the provision of security for itself and for other countries; (2) dominance in the production of goods and services; (3) being a key part of the finance and payment system in global trade; (4) significant contributions to global knowledge. While China is a dominant power in the production of goods
column62: it misses all the other elements. Third
column63: despite technological advancement over the past three decades
column64: China still faces some critical technology bottlenecks
column65: and it needs collaboration in science and technology with the West. Can Xi achieve his goal? Besides being a pragmatist
column66: he is also a realist. According to Sun Tzu's 'Art of War
column67: ' when you can't beat an army of allied adversaries
column68: you conquer them one by one. This is perhaps precisely what Xi was busy doing at one-on-one meetings with his Asian counterparts during last month's summits. As a first step
column69: Xi needs to make sure that China's market will be open to its Asian partners
column70: and every nation will benefit from this intra-Asia production network. Implications for AustraliaAustralia
column71: as a resource provider in the China-centered production network
column72: has benefited greatly in the past 20 years. Fifty years ago
column73: the then-opposition leader Gough Whitlam led a delegation to China
column75: subsequent to his party's election to government
column76: secured Australia's diplomatic relationship with the PRC
column77: even before the United States did. Whitlam managed to not just show Australia's loyalty to its strategic ally – the U.S. – but achieve Australia's own goal as a middle-power nation in the South Pacific. Thus
column78: Whitlam has been remembered not just for his courageous action of reaching out to break the power balance during the Cold War
column79: but also his move to reposition the country in alignment with Asia by leading to the ending of the country's 'White Australia' policy.The geopolitical landscape Australia is facing today is vastly different from Whitlam's time. Fifty years ago
column80: China was a political lever on a grand chessboard between the United States and the Soviet Union
column83: siding with China was risky but not damaging to its alliance with Washington. Today
column84: China's rise is challenging the dominance of the U.S. in trade
column87: and siding with China carries serious risks and possibly heavy consequences for Australia. However
column88: the reality that Australia needs to face is
column89: in the case of bifurcation in supply chains
column90: Australia's endowment will make it less attractive if it is part of the 'friend-shoring' solution that the U.S. is aiming to build to exclude China. Australia will find it hard to replace China as a downstream partner and will face more competition in resources and agricultural products in the new supply chain. One might wonder what Whitlam's decision would be were he alive today.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2022-12-08-203610.jpg;False;;14.49905;24ac3c46405b7fe8ebbe6a50717dd8c1;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 101;The Philippine-US Alliance Has a Major Blind Spot: Cybersecurity;;2022-08-04 12:15:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2022/08/the-philippine-us-alliance-has-a-major-blind-spot-cybersecurity/;thediplomat.com;Other U.S. alliances have undertaken significant measures to enhance collective defense in cyberspace. It's time for the Philippine-U.S. alliance to catch up.;"AdvertisementFrom imperial Japan to Communist insurgents and Islamic terrorists
column2: the Philippine-U.S. defense relationship has effectively evolved over its 70-year lifespan to meet the changing regional and global threat environment. However
column3: over the past 20 years
column4: this adaptation has faltered. During this period
column5: cyber operations have become an increasingly prominent tool of international conflict. Whereas other security partnerships like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the Japan-U.S. alliance have undertaken significant measures to enhance collective defense in cyberspace
column6: cyber cooperation has lagged within the Philippines-U.S. alliance.This is not merely a question of keeping pace with its collective security peers
column7: as the inability to effectively counter cyber threats has resulted in new vulnerabilities that can undermine the alliance and hamstring its operations. A functional alliance should be capable of not only preempting large-scale disruptive attacks
column8: but also rebuffing sustained cyber campaigns that degrade institutional trust and shape strategic outcomes.When U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken travels to the Philippines on August 6
column9: he will have an opportunity to remedy this lapse and formally extend the Philippine-U.S. alliance into the digital domain.Cyber Conflict in World AffairsNGet briefed on the story of the week
column10: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: Article IV of the Mutual Defense Treaty (MDT) commits the United States and the Philippines to aid one another in the event of an 'armed attack' on either party. When the treaty was signed
column2: amid the Korean War and less than a decade after World War II
column3: the definition of an 'armed attack' was obvious and seemingly unambiguous. Nevertheless
column4: in recent decades
column5: world affairs have seen the proliferation of gray zone operations like hybrid warfare and maritime militias that allow countries to reshape security conditions and advance their interests through actions below the threshold of armed attack.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.This is particularly pronounced with the use of cyber means in the pursuit of strategic interests.Cyber operations have been employed by governments to sabotage critical infrastructure
column6: degrade military capabilities
column8: and artificially sow dissent
column9: all whilst eschewing traditional notions of an 'armed attack.' More than 'cyber Pearl Harbors
column10: ' cyber operations have been employed like termites. Sustained cyberattacks with individually minimal impacts have significant cumulative effects that can reshape security conditions and yield significant strategic advantages. Recognition of the dangers posed by cyber operations has seen cybersecurity's inclusion as a national security issue and the proliferation of cyber military capabilities.However
column11: the growth of cyber conflict poses an acute challenge to international alliances. While existing defense treaties commit parties to respond to an armed attack
column12: what does this mean for cybersecurity
column13: where the attacker's identity may be uncertain and harm can be inflicted without producing human casualties? Moreover
column14: how are these institutions expected to respond when the actions do not necessarily violate established international norms and laws?AdvertisementThis dilemma became apparent in 2007
column15: when Estonia experienced a massive Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack that crippled the country. The attack is believed to have been orchestrated by Russia
column16: and Estonia sought to trigger NATO's collective response commitments under Article V of the North Atlantic Treaty. NATO declined. Individual members and NATO itself were quick to dispatch assistance to Estonia
column17: but Article V was not invoked because of the ambiguity over whether a cyberattack with no loss of life constituted an 'armed attack.'The inadequacies of this response and the continued growth of cyber conflict necessitate a significant reexamination of how alliances respond to offensive cyber operations. Notably
column18: NATO as well as the U.S. alliances with Japan and South Korea have taken significant steps to extend alliance capabilities and commitments into cyberspace
column19: including indications that a cyberattack can constitute an 'armed attack.' Unfortunately
column20: the Philippine-U.S. alliance has not kept pace with this development
column21: and cybersecurity remains a blind spot within the alliance.Cybersecurity in the Philippine-U.S. AllianceCyber cooperation has not been wholly absent from the Philippine-U.S. alliance. Following a series of retaliatory cyberattacks by patriotic hackers in China and the Philippines during the 2012 Scarborough Shoal standoff
column22: both the United States and Philippines vowed to work together on cybersecurity. Moreover
column23: from some of the earliest days of the internet
column24: preexisting points of bilateral cooperation have provided mechanisms for cyber cooperation and incident response. This was particularly prominent in 2016 when the Philippines was struck by a series of significant cyberattacks
column25: and U.S. agencies like the Department of Justice provided assistance. These episodes
column26: and the subsequent inclusion of a cybersecurity event as part of the 2017 Balikatan Exercises
column27: seemingly heralded substantive growth of cyber cooperation within the alliance. Yet
column28: over subsequent years cyber cooperation has stalled.The elections of Rodrigo Duterte and Donald Trump in 2016 posed challenges to the alliance that were uniquely detrimental to digital affairs. Along with direct attacks on the alliance
column29: Duterte's rapprochement toward China included significant cooperation in information and communication technology (ICT) development as part of China's digital silk road. The inclusion of Chinese ICT in Philippine critical infrastructure increased U.S. concerns about Chinese espionage activities in the Philippines and brought Manila into direct conflict with the Trump administration and its global campaign against Chinese ICT companies like Huawei.Beyond this elite discord
column30: underlying divergence also became apparent within the alliance in how each government pursued national cybersecurity. While both governments made cybersecurity a national priority after 2016
column31: the United States focused on foreign governments as the primary threat. Philippine national security and cyber policies do note the threat posed by foreign governments but emphasized cybercrime and non-state actors. This divergent threat perception not only led to differing cyber strategies but also different institutional preferences that may have unintentionally sidelined preexisting points of cooperation. As a result
column32: while cybersecurity remains a topic of discussion within the bilateral dialogue
column33: but joint statements and short-term programs have failed fail to advance the alliance's ability to counter cyber threats.The stagnating of bilateral cooperation in cybersecurity constitutes a vulnerability within the alliance. The Philippines ranks among the most cyber insecure countries globally
column34: with its critical infrastructure identified as being especially vulnerable to a foreign cyberattack. Within alliance operations
column35: a partner's vulnerabilities are your own vulnerabilities
column36: and successful cyberattacks on the Philippines could hamper the United States' ability to use locations in the Philippines to respond to regional crises. So significant is this concern that the U.S. has been encouraged to consider standalone power facilities to support critical locations in the archipelago.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Nor is critical infrastructure the sole vulnerability. The prominent use of disinformation campaigns during this year's national elections points to the Philippine population's susceptibility to such operations. This is significant as China in particular has previously attempted to use disinformation campaigns to target support for the Philippine-U.S. alliance.Consequently
column37: while Blinken will not lack for topics of conversation when he meets with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. this week
column38: digital affairs must be on the agenda. There are key steps that can be taken to substantively advance cybersecurity within the Philippine-U.S. alliance.At a recent conference
column40: the assistant secretary of defense for Indo-Pacific Security Affairs
column41: stated that Washington was working with Manila 'to develop new bilateral defense guidelines that will clarify our respective roles
column43: and capabilities within the framework of our alliance.' It is essential that these guidelines formally recognize cyber operations as a type of 'armed attack' that leads to invocation of the Mutual Defense Treaty. Such a declaration would extend the Philippine-U.S. alliance into cyberspace and bring the partnership in line with other U.S. alliances. Furthermore
column44: while it is not advisable to detail the specific conditions that could trigger Article IV
column45: including cyber operations under the MDT's security umbrella closes a gap within the alliance that could otherwise be exploited by adversaries.AdvertisementHowever
column46: extending alliance commitments to cybersecurity is irrelevant if not paired with corresponding capabilities
column48: and institutional development. The lifeblood of the Philippine-U.S. alliance is its schedule of regularized defense diplomacy activities and the more than 300 defense exercises held annually. Cybersecurity must be integrated into these activities and regularized to promote sustained growth in bilateral cyber cooperation. Including cyber events as part of the bilateral activities illustrates this possibility
column49: and existing mechanisms like the State Partnership Program offer established means to expand bilateral cyber engagement. Likewise
column50: as the Philippines and the United States develop new institutions and agencies to enhance national cybersecurity
column51: these new entities must also be included in cooperative undertakings. Activities like U.S. Cyber Command's 'Hunt Forward' missions offer an immediate means to both improve bilateral cybersecurity and cultivate links between U.S. and Philippine cyber forces that bolster operational effectiveness within the alliance.Finally
column52: it is essential to recognize that cybersecurity is a whole-of-nation problem that cannot be resolved independently of economic development
column55: the Philippines' desire for economic development and the need to keep pace in a digitized world led to its embrace of Chinese ICT. Just as cybersecurity should not be ignored for economic expedience
column56: partners should not be expected to sacrifice their economic well-being without aid or assistance. Whereas developments like supply chain diversification present a chance to address these dilemmas in mutually beneficial ways
column57: but these will require significant investments and sustained political support.Blinken is unlikely to remedy such problems during one short visit
column58: but is time for the alliance to realize that cybersecurity is a liability that neither government can continue to overlook.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat_2022-08-03-192218.jpg;False;;13.946614;ffa05232c7b6c0d9e680ac012857cb1a;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 102;Andrew Small on the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor's Return to the Shadows;Catherine Putz;2020-10-06 15:23:21;full;https://thediplomat.com/2020/10/andrew-small-on-the-china-pakistan-economic-corridors-return-to-the-shadows;thediplomat.com;'CPEC has been a chastening experience for China in the context of the BRI.';"AdvertisementIn the five years since the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) was launched
column2: it's been beset by the winds of local politics and the waves of geopolitics alike. In a new report
column3: titled 'Returning to the Shadows: China
column4: Pakistan
column5: and the Fate of CPEC
column6: ' Andrew Small catalogues the grand promises and countless pitfalls of CPEC. In an interview with The Diplomat
column8: a senior transatlantic fellow with the German Marshall Fund's Asia Program
column9: explains the significance of CPEC to the China-Pakistan relationship
column10: the contours of its highs and lows
column11: and what the fate of the grand scheme means for China's broader Belt and Road Initiative.What's the significance of the China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) to the China and Pakistan bilateral relationship? CPEC was supposed to act as a vehicle to upgrade the China-Pakistan partnership. Some Chinese analysts used to describe the relationship as a 'stool with two legs': While security and political ties have been strong for decades
column12: economic ties had always been extremely weak. Even this characterization somewhat overstates the breadth of the relationship — it was almost entirely confined to military and intelligence matters
column13: and managed by a very small cast of individuals on the two sides. China was never a factor in day-to-day economic or political life in Pakistan
column14: and its strong approval ratings in opinion polls reflected its unimpeachable reputation as the 'all-weather friend' rather than any deeper affinity among the Pakistani public. That narrowness of relations also made it difficult for China to embrace Pakistan too openly — despite being arguably Beijing's closest partner
column15: virtually anything the two sides did together was always viewed through a security prism
column16: and China had to tread carefully to avoid eliciting alarmed reactions in New Delhi or further afield. CPEC was a way of changing that narrative. China could make a big public push to enhance the relationship while selling it as an economic and development matter. There was also a gamble involved: CPEC was dubbed the 'flagship' of the BRI
column17: which tied its fate closely to the reputation of the entire initiative
column18: and even to Xi Jinping himself. This was a risk that Beijing was willing to take. China wanted its relationship with Pakistan to be a 'model to follow': Close
column19: trusted military ties that nonetheless fell short of the commitments of a formal alliance
column20: underpinned by a comprehensive Chinese immersion in the country's economic life. If CPEC succeeded
column21: other countries would look to replicate it.  NGet briefed on the story of the week
column22: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter For Pakistan
column23: the logic was even more compelling. CPEC was an opportunity to draw China into a deeper level of political
column24: security
column25: commercial
column26: and financial commitment to the country
column27: in a highly visible way
column28: at a juncture where U.S. support was being tapered back on all fronts
column29: and international investors were very wary of the security situation. For both sides
column30: the optics are therefore almost as important as the substance. China and Pakistan have a strong incentive to put a good face on CPEC whatever is actually happening in practice.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.The Khan administration's interest in modifying CPEC made headlines back in 2018. Since then
column31: as you note in the report
column32: CPEC first slowed then gradually sped up again. But in the interim
column33: did the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) government have any success in pushing for its desired changes?CPEC was already slowing down even before the PTI took power — by late 2017 Pakistan's economic situation was weakening and political uncertainties were growing as Nawaz Sharif and the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N)'s struggles with the army intensified. Imran Khan was known to be skeptical about CPEC — seeing it as too closely tied to the PML-N's agenda
column34: a poor fit for his own priorities
column35: and almost certainly corrupt too. Prominent figures in the PTI
column36: such as the commerce minister and leading industrialist
column37: Abdul Razak Dawood
column38: were also public critics of CPEC
column39: representing sections of the Pakistani business community that saw the benefits as too tilted to Chinese firms
column40: and had themselves missed out on the explosion of CPEC contracts.  Beijing was ready to be accommodating to the new government's priorities. Its position had always been that the PTI just didn't understand that they could be beneficiaries too if they spelled out clearly enough what they wanted. In practice though
column41: the model that Imran Khan was proposing was precisely the kind of economic relationship that China had always sought to avoid with Pakistan: In his first trip to Beijing after taking office
column42: he asked for a bailout to address the country's weak financial position
column43: and support for socio-economic projects
column46: China tried to figure out some way to rebalance CPEC around the PTI's priorities. As one Chinese official put it to me in the early months after the elections: 'We can do peanut projects instead of mega projects
column47: if that's what they want.' They looked at making Pakistan a test country for China's new aid agency
column48: as well as some agriculture and green energy projects
column49: and they talked about renegotiating the terms of existing investments. But Beijing quickly grew fed up with the new government — particularly after the open criticism that CPEC received early in its tenure — and decided that they needed to go straight to the army instead
column50: which they increasingly believed was running the show anyway. The result of that has been a slowed down and slimmed down CPEC but not necessarily a CPEC that bears the imprimatur of the PTI the way that its conception reflected the PML-N's infrastructure and energy-centered agenda.    What factors contributed to the more recent downgrading of ambitions for CPEC by both Pakistan and China? Did one drive the dampening of enthusiasm more than the other? It's important to mention that CPEC is seeing a mini-resurgence at the moment. What should be the single largest project under CPEC
column51: the ML-1 railway line upgrade from Karachi to Peshawar
column52: is supposed to be moving ahead
column53: and there are a couple of new hydro-electric dams. Officials on both sides will publicly dispute that there has been any downgrading of ambitions. But the really transformative plan that was originally envisaged — a multi-stage transformative agenda for the Pakistani economy — is not really there anymore
column54: and the overall scale is no longer on a par with the kinds of figures that were being talked about a few years back. This reflects a confluence of factors. Pakistan's economy has struggled in recent years
column55: which has affected the government's financing capacity. The BRI is no longer characterized by such an overriding focus on speed and scale as it was when CPEC launched. China found the political obstacles to be a real headache
column56: and essentially decided to hold back until it was clear that they had partners on the Pakistani side that actually wanted to deliver on CPEC. But in Pakistan
column58: there were questions from a number of corners about whether the full-scale version made sense — the debt levels
column59: the implications for Pakistani businesses of an influx of Chinese firms in the special economic zones
column60: the degree of dependence on China that was building
column61: and many other factors besides. For its part
column62: the army was not so comfortable about such a vast civilian-led economic agenda for the country either; it represented a potential rebalancing of power in Pakistan
column63: and indeed China even sold it as that: A move toward a less military-centric view of national strength. Some of the frictions around these issues were not entirely helpful for the broader relationship either — so if anything there is a mutual sense that a slimmed-down version of CPEC may be preferable
column64: as long as the public reputation is carefully managed.  With the PTI government less interested in CPEC than the previous Sharif administration
column65: the military has taken over more control. What are the implications of the renewed emphasis on China-Rawalpindi relations for Pakistan's always tenuous civil-military balance?The army was unhappy about the level of control it exercised over CPEC
column66: and the role the PML-N occupied in running it. That has now been 'fixed.' Even if China has certain preferences and views about how Pakistan should think about its national strategy
column67: Beijing is ultimately indifferent about who is in charge in Pakistan as long as they deliver on Chinese objectives. I think there is a recognition on the Chinese side that CPEC ended up on the wrong side of the civil-military struggle and there will be even greater care to ensure that doesn't happen again. Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.There has always been a question of whether CPEC ends up reinforcing existing power dynamics in Pakistan or mitigating them. There was a genuine case to be made for the latter in CPEC's first couple of years
column68: but that's clearly no longer true — instead CPEC is now likely to help the army entrench its role in an even wider range of economic decision-making and execution than its usual prerogatives. To be fair to China
column69: this is not what they intended. They were not happy with how the Pakistani army treated Nawaz Sharif. But they have accommodated themselves to what happened and would rather work through a GHQ-centered set of structures if it means that some credible version of CPEC happens. I expect
column71: that it will be difficult to get back to a civilian-led model for CPEC again. Given that it represents such an important part of Pakistan's economic life
column72: even on its more modest scale
column73: that has some obvious long-term implications.  At a recent All Parties Conference
column74: Pakistan's opposition issued a series of demands
column75: mostly relating to allegations of election rigging and military interference in Pakistan's government. But one of their demands was that CPEC be 'expedited
column76: ' with the opposition accusing the PTI of endangering the initiative. In most countries (Sri Lanka
column80: we've seen the opposite: pro-democracy forces aligned against Chinese investments and development projects
column81: citing increased corruption risks and lack of transparency. Can you explain the role of CPEC in Pakistan's domestic politics?The routine with CPEC in Pakistani domestic politics is that everyone expresses their profound support for it in principle and then the opposition criticizes the form that it is taking in practice with the government in power
column82: and the way it is being executed. This reflects China's sanctified status in Pakistan. It is still the 'all-weather friend
column83: ' and its importance as a security partner and financial backer has only grown.AdvertisementBeijing also has a radioactive reaction to any hint of public criticism. As we saw early in the PTI's term in office
column84: Chinese officials would routinely call on the army to get any critical ministers to shut up. So although there are many of the same concerns about CPEC in Pakistan as elsewhere — corruption
column87: advantageous terms for Chinese companies and so on — these tend to be expressed in private
column88: and generally not to the Chinese. But we also have a situation at the moment where some of CPEC's biggest critics are in government. For the PML-N and the PPP
column89: which also claimed credit for aspects of CPEC — such as China's decision to take Gwadar on again — the line has been that the PTI is squandering the economic opportunity that it represents. BRI politics also reflect electoral cycles. The skeptical opposition takes power and figures out its own accommodation with China
column90: while the former governing parties then either take a more critical position itself or attack their successors for failing to handle relations with Beijing effectively. Of course
column91: China doesn't like this and wants to stay above the fray
column92: but the scale of the BRI in some of these countries is on too large a scale for that to be possible. In Pakistan
column94: Beijing still has the means to shut some of these voices down.What can the fate of CPEC tell us about China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) more broadly?CPEC has been a chastening experience for China in the context of the BRI. Given its special relationship with Pakistan
column95: this was supposed to be a politically easier experience than elsewhere
column96: for all the security and economic challenges they knew they would face. It has been a demonstration that the grand-scale version of its plans may just be too difficult to execute — too exposing and contentious in countries where it simply doesn't have the depth of relationships or expertise to pull it off
column97: however close its top-level ties are. China cannot expect to replicate its own model outside its borders in very different political
column98: cultural and economic contexts.  One response could have been to come up with a new model — a BRI 2.0 and a CPEC 2.0 — that put things on a more sustainable footing
column103: and tailored plans even more closely to countries' needs. The alternative is just to slow things down
column105: but basically plow ahead with the same approach as before
column106: with a tighter focus on some of China's own higher priorities
column107: such as the Digital Silk Road projects or
column109: getting Gwadar wrapped up. I think that's generally what we're seeing: more of the same
column111: and with some modest re-prioritization. The big unknown now

But there is still a reckoning to come. This is one area where Pakistan is in a sui generis position — given its importance to China

column1: 103;What Explains Growing European Engagement in Central Asia?;;2022-11-21 18:25:00;full;https://thediplomat.com/2022/11/what-explains-growing-european-engagement-in-central-asia/;thediplomat.com;In recent years
column2: the EU has shifted how it views Central Asia. That effort culminated recently with the first EU-Central Asia leaders summit.;"AdvertisementAt the end of October 2022
column3: President of the European Council Charles Michel paid his first official visit to Astana and held a summit with the leaders of all five Central Asian states — Kazakhstan
column4: Kyrgyzstan
column5: Tajikistan
column6: Turkmenistan
column7: and Uzbekistan. The EU-Central Asia leaders' summit took place for the first time as Russia's influence in Central Asia has been showing early signs of dwindling amid its unprovoked war with Ukraine. Michel called the summit 'more than just a dialogue between two regions' and stressed that the two regions are 'coming closer together and becoming more and more connected.' While in the Kazakh capital
column8: Michel also called for greater cooperation between the EU and Central Asia
column9: adding he was looking ahead to the Samarkand EU Central Asian Connectivity Conference planned for November 18
column10: which his colleague
column11: EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy Josep Borrell
column12: attended.What is the rationale for the EU's latest engagement with the five Central Asian countries and its call for boosting cross-border cooperation between Central Asia and the EU?First
column13: the EU is driven by its geopolitical ambition to adjust its status as a secondary actor in the region that straddles a strategic geographic space at the heart of Eurasia
column14: bordering Russia to the north
column15: China to the east
column16: and Afghanistan and Iran to the south. Until now
column17: the region has been largely seen through the lens of a new 'great game' competition among three great powers — Russia
column19: and the United States. The three have attempted to dominate the region in pursuit of their largely divergent interests by applying classic 'divide and rule' tactics. Russia
column20: with firm persistence
column21: has attempted to maintain a strong presence in the region by forming security and economic alliances – the Collective Security Treaty Organization (CSTO) and Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU). China
column22: in turn
column23: loaned Central Asia billions to build major import-export and energy supply connectivity projects as part of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) that complement its economic and geopolitical ambitions. Meanwhile
column24: the U.S. sought to encourage neoliberal institutions in Central Asian states and develop them on the path toward democracy and market economy. In startling contrast to these powers
column25: the EU did not have significant geopolitical interests in Central Asia and considered the states in the region as 'neighbors of its neighbors.' For that reason
column26: the EU put Central Asia presumably into the fold of its wider European Neighborhood Policy. However
column27: with the continuing Western 'polycrisis' and growing Chinese and Russian assertiveness in Central Asia
column28: the EU has begun to reconsider its foreign policy direction
column29: taking into account the differences of the states in the region. This led to the adoption of the New Strategy on Central Asia in 2019
column30: which shifted EU foreign policy from a Brussels-centric normative power to principled pragmatism and resilience. NGet briefed on the story of the week
column31: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: This is guided by a series of changes in the Global Strategy for the EU's Foreign and Security Policy (EUGS) toward identifying geopolitics as an essential if not definite factor of EU foreign policy in the 21stcentury.  Prior to her visit to Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan on October 30
column2: German Foreign Minister Annabella Baerbock stated that Germany does not want to see Central Asia 'being straitjacketed in Russia's front yard or being dependent on China.' This statement clearly demonstrated the geopolitical aspirations of both Germany and the EU to take part in a new 'great game' to prevent the unhindered growth of Russian and Chinese influence in the region. Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Second
column3: the EU aims to intensify cooperation with Central Asia in order to attain its geoeconomic ambitions to increase Euro-Asian connectivity — physical and non-physical infrastructure via which goods
column4: people
column5: ideas
column6: and services can move freely. Although the EU has not introduced its own BRI in Central Asia
column7: it has been deeply involved in the sphere of connectivity. In the 2007 Central Asia Strategy
column8: the EU set a priority to establish energy and transport connections linking the two regions. However
column9: Brussels has been passive in actualizing the Caspian-Black Sea pipeline and an 'e-silk highway
column10: ' lagging behind the Chinese BRI and Russian-led EAEU. In late 2018
column11: the EU put forward its strategy on connecting Europe and Asia with concrete policy proposals and initiatives to improve energy
column12: transport
column13: digital
column14: and people-to-people connectivity in Eurasia. The strategy states that non-engagement is not a choice for the EU while China is growing its influence in Central Asia.By endorsing the revised strategy on Central Asia
column15: the EU acknowledged the strategic importance of Central Asia in its global efforts to strengthen sustainable
column16: comprehensive
column17: and rule-based connectivity within Eurasia. To that end
column18: the EU intended to bolster relations with the Central Asia states through a bilateral approach based on broad-based and mutually beneficial Enhanced Partnership and Cooperation Agreements (EPCA)
column19: which has been underscored over the regional approach considering the unique characteristics of each and every country in the region. The EU has implemented an EPCA with Kazakhstan
column20: and also signed a Temporary Trade Agreement with Turkmenistan. In July 2022
column21: the EU and Uzbekistan successfully completed three-year talks and signed a new EPCA in Brussels. Furthermore
column22: the EU's revised strategy on Central Asia proclaims that Brussels is also committed to implementing EPCAs with the other interested states of Central Asia — Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan.AdvertisementIn late 2021
column23: European Commission President Ursula Von der Leyen proclaimed that the EU would mobilize up to 300 billion euro of investments for the launch of a new connectivity initiative — Global Gateway for 2021-2027. This ambitious project can be elucidated as a response to China's BRI
column24: which is now affiliated with 139 countries. It also gives signals that in the upcoming years
column25: the EU will push forward networks with various states in different parts of the world and extend up to the Central Asian countries.Third
column26: the EU aims to step up cooperation on security challenges in Central Asian states and Afghanistan. It should be noted that the EU's security interpretation is strikingly broad and entails a larger number of threats and a wider range of actors than traditional definitions. With the foreign policy shift to principled pragmatism/resilience
column27: the EU developed a pragmatic approach to broader issues of global security underlining the impact of neighboring states and their close neighbors on the EU with respect to security
column28: terrorism
column29: migration
column30: and economics. For that reason
column31: the EU gives priority to domestic and border security in line with a pragmatic ad hoc emphasis on external powers close to Europe. In this context
column32: it is to the strategic benefit of the EU to promote the resilience of states and societies in Central Asia. The EU is particularly interested in enhancing cooperation with Central Asian states against such common security issues as radicalization
column33: violent extremism
column34: terrorism
column35: hybrid and cyber threats
column36: and nuclear safety and security. The EU furthermore emphasizes the significance of confronting the socioeconomic roots of radicalization. During Michel's official visit to Astana at the end of October
column37: the EU and Central Asian leaders remarked on the potential of cooperation in border management and security
column38: the joint fight against terrorism
column39: transnational organized crime and drug trafficking
column41: and other new security threats in compliance with universal principles.The sudden withdrawal of U.S. forces from Afghanistan and the subsequent collapse of the Afghan Republic government worried both Central Asia and the EU; both were concerned about Afghanistan turning into a source of threats to regional and international peace and security. Acknowledging the crucial role of Central Asia in global efforts to promote inclusive peace
column42: security and sustainable development in Afghanistan and emphasizing that these efforts should bring advantage to the region
column43: the EU aims to encourage closer connectivity between Central Asia and South Asia via Afghanistan.Overall
column44: the first official summit between the president of the European Council and Central Asia's leaders is a crucial development in the new 'great game.' The EU's engagement is driven by its geopolitical and geoeconomic interests to prevent the unhindered rise of Russian and Chinese influence
column45: and by its domestic concerns to tackle security challenges in Central Asia and beyond. New EU ambitions will give an opportunity to the states in the region to intensify comprehensive partnerships with the EU
column46: which can play a positive part in the region by offering an alternative to Moscow and Beijing and assisting the Central Asian states to diversify their economies
column48: and develop their societies. In this context
column49: the EU's ambition to change its secondary player status seems relatively feasible. However
column50: the EU will have to compete with Russia and China
column51: along with other rising regional powers in the region like Turkey

column1: 104;2 Major Traps on China's Path to Global Leadership;;2022-09-01 06:45:00;timezone unknown;https://thediplomat.com/2022/09/2-major-traps-on-chinas-path-to-global-leadership/;thediplomat.com;There are at least two major obstacles that China will have to get over on its path to global leadership
column2: one domestic and one outward-facing.;"AdvertisementChinese authorities are anything but humble when they set out their long-term vision: making their country a leading economic and technological power by 2049
column3: the 100th anniversary of the creation of the People's Republic of China. The Chinese don't just want to be a superpower – they believe that they deserve to be one
column4: that it's their destiny to lead the world.Chinese leaders are convinced that we're witnessing the end of the post-Cold War Pax Americana and the transition to a new world order
column5: which will ultimately find China in the driver's seat. The vast majority of official pronouncements exude the utter conviction that the U.S. and the Western liberal order are in terminal decline
column6: while there are very few lonely voices that question the precise degree and speed of that decline.China has indeed made spectacular and truly unprecedented progress over the past 40 years or so. But is it likely to achieve the ambitious objective set by the CCP? There are at least two major obstacles – or
column8: sets of obstacles – that China will have to get over on its path to global leadership. The first set of obstacles relates to China's political and economic governance ('the middle-income trap')
column9: and the second to Beijing's capabilities to claim a leading role in the international arena ('the Kindleberger trap').The Middle-Income TrapNGet briefed on the story of the week
column10: and developing stories to watch across the Asia-Pacific.Get the Newsletter

column1: Statistically
column2: China already stands at the doorstep of the high-income club
column3: with an average per capita income at $12
column4: 555 in 2021. Chinese authorities vehemently reject the middle-income trap theory
column5: which posits that the growth potential in the majority of export-driven low-skill economies is exhausted before the countries in question attain the innovative capability they need to compete with developed countries in higher value-chain industries. Yet
column6: the severe headwinds China's economy is increasingly facing show that this discussion is not irrelevant.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.China's slowdown should not be attributed exclusively to the disastrous impact of the zero-COVID strategy as a temporary drag on the economy. The pandemic has merely exacerbated a host of structural deficiencies that were obvious even before the coronavirus outbreak in 2020. China is reeling under the deadweight of excessive debt
column7: caused by massive misallocation of capital and obsession with costly infrastructure that is not always needed. The real estate bubble
column8: with the liabilities of the Evergrande behemoth alone accounting for 3 percent of China's GDP
column9: may be the most serious crisis China has faced in the past 40 years. In fact
column10: unsustainable investment in housing and infrastructure has become the single biggest source of bad growth in China.Add to that a rapidly aging population
column11: which will also sap China's future growth prospects due to a shrinking workforce
column12: coupled with low levels of educational attainment. While China performs well on many measures of innovation
column13: adding quality alongside quantity in this process will be crucial to the CCP's ambitions. As a result of all the above predicaments
column14: China's total factor productivity (TFP) growth has been steadily declining since 2010
column15: when the country bade farewell to double-digit growth rates. Clearly then
column16: most of the fall in GDP growth rates merely mirrors the decline in TFP growth.Chinese authorities have been trying to tackle industrial overcapacity
column17: local debt mountains and shadow banking
column19: and to spur innovation across the board. Key policies of the Chinese government aim to help rebalance China's economy
column20: wean it off its predominantly export-driven model
column21: promote state-of-the-art technologies
column22: tap into the huge domestic market
column23: and make the country more self-sufficient. Yet
column24: many of these efforts are falling flat. The shift from a nation of shippers to a nation of shoppers has turned out to be much more difficult than expected: Domestic consumption remains weak
column25: while Chinese exports have hit record levels thanks to generous state support provided to manufacturing.AdvertisementClearly
column26: noble intentions and lofty pronouncements by China's leaders do not ensure the turn to an entirely new innovation-based paradigm
column27: which would help the country overcome the middle-income trap. While few watchers see a systemic risk in China at this stage
column28: the country's economic 'miracle' seems to be well past its peak and the long-term outlook of its economy is turning dimmer with the passage of time. China is widely expected to overtake the U.S. in terms of its nominal GDP
column29: but there is a universal consensus that this may take longer than was initially thought. In order for China to surpass the United States by 2035
column30: its economy would have to grow at 4 percent a year; however
column31: annual economic growth could well drop to 2-3 percent in the coming years. And there are persistent doubts lingering over the credibility of Chinese statistics
column32: meaning that the much-trumpeted doubling of the country's GDP and per capita income between 2020 and 2035 should not be taken for granted.The Kindleberger TrapAnd
column33: as if these internal challenges weren't enough
column34: China will have to address the even more challenging 'Kindleberger trap' on the international arena. Charles Kindleberger
column35: a prominent American economist
column36: has argued that leading powers have the responsibility to provide global public goods
column37: such as peace
column38: security
column41: a clean environment
column42: and more. China clearly aims to position itself as a leader in 21st-century global governance
column43: but how likely is it to acquire the capabilities to act as a responsible global power? Its prospects are mixed
column44: at best.China has risen to the position of the second largest economy worldwide and can rightfully boast impressive achievements as a testimony to its rising engineering and scientific prowess. There's no doubt it's making advances in the ever-intensifying tech competition with the United States. It is closing on the U.S. in terms of R&D spending as share of its GDP
column45: even though Chinese institutions are still more into applied rather than basic research
column46: i.e. imitation at the expense of genuine innovation. Chinese universities are becoming markedly stronger in Science
column49: and Mathematics (STEM).In the battle for artificial intelligence (AI) supremacy
column50: China now publishes more papers on related topics than any other country
column51: though U.S. and European papers are still cited more often. Research efforts are well underway in the fields of quantum computing and communications. China is clearly dominant across green technologies domains
column52: such as the production of solar panels
column53: and CATL is a world leader in the area of batteries for electric vehicles. China's large deposits of strategically important rare earths or access to related natural resources overseas also give it a comparative advantage over competitors.At the same time
column54: there are areas where China is still lagging behind key competitors
column55: the sector of semiconductors being a case in point. The state-owned Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC) has gobbled subsidies worth tens of billions of dollars
column56: but is still reliant on state-of-the art Western equipment.By the end of 2021
column57: China's share in the global economy had exceeded 18 percent and is set to keep growing. However
column58: recent IMF analysis shows that China's slowdown has become increasingly painful
column59: with major consequences for the global economy. And
column60: while the Chinese renminbi is one of the reserve currencies
column61: it has not been able to challenge the financial hegemony of the U.S. dollar.Enjoying this article? Click here to subscribe for full access. Just $5 a month.Another big challenge to China's prospects as a driving engine of global development is presented by the checkered track record of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)
column62: once hailed by Chinese leader Xi Jinping as the 'project of the century.' Many reports of late have uncovered a mountain of non-performing loans provided by Chinese policy banks to recipient countries and the BRI now risks metastasizing into a series of controversies and debt crises.Mounting problems do not obscure the fact that in many developing countries construction with Chinese finance has yielded some much-needed infrastructure. But a number of 'white elephants' and the debts piling up have dealt a serious blow to China's image as a competent and reliable partner of the Global South. The big question now is whether and to what extent Beijing will participate in multilateral debt relief efforts in BRI recipient countries. Ironically
column63: a multilateral approach is counter-intuitive for Beijing because the BRI has been designed with a strictly bilateral and Sino-centric logic.It may be even more difficult for China to ensure global public goods in the areas of peace and security. China is a major contributor to U.N. peacekeeping operations
column64: second in terms of financial inputs and ninth as to the number of troops. On the face of it
column66: but it doesn't really match the country's size
column68: and ambitions. The Global Security Initiative (GSI) presented by Xi Jinping in April 2022
column69: is a set of generic statements and little content. The GSI may find resonance in some developing countries
column70: where frustration with elements of the U.S.-led order is manifest
column71: but it is highly unlikely to be endorsed by Western allies. In fact
column72: the GSI signals Xi's attempt to create a platform for China's own partnerships.AdvertisementBeijing's credibility is severely undermined by its fence-sitting on Russia's invasion of Ukraine and lip service to the notions of 'sovereignty' and 'territorial integrity
column73: ' as it has essentially endorsed Moscow's narrative about the war. In fact
column75: the new hymnbook of Chinese diplomats is marked by a flexible approach to inconvenient questions
column76: 'based on the merits of the issue.' So far
column77: China appears to shy away from undertaking global responsibilities on a par with its status and pronouncements.Nor is Beijing committed to the stability of the existing global architecture with its vision of a new world order
column78: as laid out in the joint Sino-Russian manifesto released in February 2022. Xi and Putin have embarked on nothing short of an anti-Western illiberal crusade that brings Western nations closer together against Beijing and Moscow alike. While China is making inroads into the Global South
column79: it is antagonizing the West as a broad constellation of allies and like-minded partners
column80: whom Beijing tends to view as 'U.S. poodles.' The Quad formation or the trilateral AUKUS deal largely relate to China's rise over the past few decades and its assertive posture under Xi. The recent show of military force around Taiwan in the wake of U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's controversial visit raises additional questions about China's commitment to the peaceful resolution of complex geopolitical disputes.China's potential leading role on a global scale is even more questionable in the area of public health. In the wake of the 2003 SARS epidemic and above all the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020
column81: Beijing is clearly on the back foot. A raft of anywhere-but-here conspiracy theories have done more harm than good to China's image. The Health Silk Road
column82: heavily promoted by the CCP government as part of its propaganda counteroffensive
column84: despite the sales of Chinese vaccines
column86: and other supplies to a number of countries. Nor does it help that the Chinese vaccines do not match the efficacy of Western mRNA vaccines. And future outbreaks in China cannot be precluded: New pathogens
column87: such as the Langya virus
column88: are already being reported.Just as worryingly
column89: China is an unlikely global leader in the containment of the existential climate crisis. Despite its massive investment in green technologies
column90: China is still the most polluting nation on the Earth in absolute figures
column91: accounting for more than a quarter of world carbon emissions. Beijing's commitment to carbon neutrality by 2060 does not reflect the urgency of the matter
column92: nor is this commitment confirmed by China's decision to suspend climate talks with the U.S. in the wake of Pelosi's visit to Taiwan.Given all the above developments
column93: China's global image has deteriorated markedly over the past few years. This will not negate its ability to wield vast economic and military power in its own neighborhood or further abroad. But Beijing's reputation and overall soft power have bottomed out
column94: despite a wide range of efforts to expand its public diplomacy. Ironically
column95: China's charm offensives are undermined first and foremost by its increasingly pompous rhetoric
column96: confrontational diplomacy (including its notorious 'wolf warrior' tenet)
column97: and the undisguised use of economic coercion applied to countries that are less than infatuated with Beijing leadership ambitions.A Mix of Ambition and AngstMany analysts put a significant weight on past performance when thinking about China's future trajectory. But the golden era of rapid Chinese economic growth is gone and the country's further progress is not guaranteed
column98: as it will require profound structural reforms that may prove politically difficult. Under Xi Jinping
column99: the role of the state in the economy has become ever tighter
column100: and this will further hold back productivity growth.For all that
column101: China's sheer size guarantees that the country will remain a key driver of global growth
column102: though it is less clear to what extent. Despite signs of intensifying diversification
column103: China will retain its pivotal role in global supply chains and strong – if not leading – position in a number of sectors. It will obviously be an economic giant and
column105: will continue to wield enormous market power.China will most probably become the world's largest economy
column106: but it is unlikely to enjoy a meaningful lead over the U.S. and will remain far less prosperous. With long-term average economic growth of 2-3 percent
column107: China will lack the economic heft needed to compete with Western economies as a group; for example
column108: in terms of its ability to devote resources to science and innovation
column110: or financing overseas infrastructure projects.No doubt
column111: Beijing will seek to increase its outreach and global sway through its strong presence in the U.N. or by means of institutions structured around China
column116: the gap between China's rhetoric about multilateralism and its preference for bilateral relations with the vast majority of countries won't vanish.Beijing will continue to act as an agenda-setter
column117: mostly in the name of the Global South
column118: even though a number of developing nations will increasingly ask themselves whether China is a partner or a predator. Beijing's foreign policy to prospective allies will probably remain a cocktail of pledges and pressure
column119: if not veiled coercion. China's weak soft power and negative image in the West will inevitably constrain its international clout and global leadership.A visibly weakened United States
column120: distracted by its own domestic challenges
column122: but China does not seem to be ready to replace it as a global leader. Notably
column123: Beijing seems to be driven by an odd mix of ambition and angst
column124: and this is where the middle-income trap meets the Kindleberger trap. While the ambition is clear
column125: the angst derives from a creeping suspicion in Beijing that China's future may prove to be vastly different from the dominant narrative of its incessant rise. Precisely because things may not pan out as previously expected
column126: the CCP is getting ahead of itself and is increasingly turning to a nationalistic rhetoric. This will render China considerably more dangerous and anything but a responsible global leader.";thediplomat.com;2310;news;ID;en;;https://thediplomat.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/sizes/td-story-s-2/thediplomat-2020-09-28-13.jpg;False;;12.4284525;bf746e112abc4ca61893212f0d85999c;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: China's modern economy was built on the strength of a solid and often low-tech manufacturing sector
column2: making it the world's single largest manufacturer today. As China continues to develop and move up the value chain – toward producing more high-tech manufactures and services and investing in more R&D – it is likely that some of the country's lower-tech
column3: labor intensive manufacturing will be ‘up for grabs.

column1: It is expected that ASEAN will emerge as the third pillar of Asian growth alongside China and India. The changing landscape of China's manufacturing sector will present significant opportunities for ASEAN to capture some of China's manufacturing

column1: The garment and textile industry is the most obvious candidate for moving production out of China to other Asian countries. There are also examples of intermediate-input and other tech manufacturing leaving China with countries like Vietnam
column2: Thailand and Indonesia picking up electronics work.

column1: And as more companies seek geographic diversification and adopt the 'China+1' strategy
column2: Southeast Asia will continue to gain market share – as well as a greater slice of global foreign direct investment as the center of gravity of global manufacturing continues to shift.

column8: 340) per EV (Nikkei Asia

column1: The spreading supply chain across Asia is already resulting in increased capability and production quality in the countries closest to China. Continued investment

column1: ASEAN has the potential to become one of the world's key manufacturing hubs. The region has favorable demographics

column1: Despite the shadows cast by the global pandemic in the last few years and other market uncertainties
column2: we see the coming years as a period of great promise for Southeast Asia
column3: brimming with potentials ranging from sustainability and digital technology to trade and wealth. This also creates unprecedented opportunities for Chinese companies that are seeking continuous growth and global presence in the post-covid era.

column1: The key to unlocking opportunities is not just to understand the dynamics of each market
