column1: 169;Cultivated Art in the Clouds: J Hotel Shanghai Tower Debuts at the Summit of Shanghai on 19th June 2021
column2: Business News;;2021-06-19 06:00:00;full;https://www.asiaone.com/business/cultivated-art-clouds-j-hotel-shanghai-tower-debuts-summit-shanghai-19th-june-2021;asiaone.com;SHANGHAI
column3: June 19
column4: 2021 /PRNewswire/ -- J Hotel has debuted its inaugural property today atop the Shanghai Tower
column5: the tallest skyscraper in China and second-tallest in the world. J Hotel Shanghai…;"SHANGHAI
column6: June 19
column7: 2021 /PRNewswire/ -- J Hotel has debuted its inaugural property today atop the Shanghai Tower
column8: the tallest skyscraper in China and second-tallest in the world. J Hotel Shanghai Tower has reached a new milestone of success among China's homegrown hotels as it occupies the highest point in Shanghai. Jin Jiang International Hotels
column9: China's largest and the world's second-largest hotel group
column10: debuts the premiere luxury hospitality brand after dedicating ten years into its detailed curation
column11: masterful craft
column12: and opulent design. J Hotel weaves together broad influences from different realms of art and culture to bring a unique luxury perspective to Shanghai. It merges artistic touches throughout its design for palatial staterooms and the best in lifestyle
column13: wellbeing
column14: food & beverage
column15: technology
column16: and hospitality services
column17: presenting an exclusive travel experience crafted with authentic Chinese flair. J Hotel Shanghai Tower Exterior A Shanghai View Above It All J Hotel Shanghai Tower is located at the top of the 632-meter Shanghai Tower in the heart of Lujiazui
column18: offering a bird's-eye view across the whole expanse of Shanghai. From this unparalleled location
column19: guests can savor a view above and beyond all else. The horizon stretches clear from Hongqiao Airport in the west to the Yangtze River's powerful entrance into the East China Sea. It also provides a rare perspective on the nearby Oriental Pearl Tower and the Bund
column20: offering a chance to contemplate the city's rich historical evolution. J Hotel Shanghai Tower also carries forward the brand's ambitious ideals
column21: delivering its own interpretation of home and the world as they intersect with Chinese culture. By crafting luxury hotels that combine modern aesthetics and Chinese tradition
column22: the J brand aims to set the benchmark for China's homegrown hospitality industry. The Art of Interior Design The interior design of J Hotel Shanghai Tower was led by Lv Haiyan
column23: Chairman of Jin Jiang Luxury Hotels Management Co.
column24: Ltd
column25: renowned novelist and award-winning screenwriter and crafted by R&O
column26: a respected studio dedicated to the world's top hotels that was founded by Oscar LLinas and the late Robert Bilkey. Both Bilkey and LLinas personally participated in the hotel's design
column27: which is Bilkey's final masterpiece on his life-long journey of designing wonders. Guests are welcomed into the vast interior with six crystal Roman columns leading to an eight-meter-high Shikumen – the stately courtyard gates traditional to Shanghai – in an astonishing design that seamlessly blends the best of the east and west. On the sprawling tower's Floor 101
column28: a sky bridge of laminated glass and metal unfolds before guests. At the end of the bridge
column29: guests are met with graceful ballerinas dancing across the sky in delicately threaded metallics as an installation handcrafted by French artist Pauline Ohrel to invite every visitor into a unique universe of art and culture. At this artistic landmark in the clouds
column30: designers have utilized lacquer
column31: glaze and enamel works as well as metal
column32: crystal and mosaics that give life to a breathtaking space with creativity at every turn. The hotel also invited Chinese and international artists to collaborate on artworks that reflect their individual style while connecting in a cohesive design language
column33: inviting guests to explore the carefully curated art exhibition that spans different floors. The Art of an Elegant Residence J Hotel Shanghai Tower boasts 165 rooms
column34: including 34 suites. The staterooms and suites are located from Floors 86 to 98 and vary from 62 square meters to 380 square meters
column35: making them some of the highest and most spacious options in Shanghai. Nestled into the Shanghai Tower's spiral
column36: every stateroom has unique views. Beginning at the Huangpu River and cutting through the heart of the city below
column37: guests have access to Shanghai's diverse and spectacular urban scenery
column38: from the Bund and the Oriental Pearl Tower to the expanses across Puxi and Pudong. As guests walk along the breathtaking guestroom corridors lined with unique art pieces lit by Chinese carved ""lui li"" crystal frames
column39: they will discover doors of different colors. Behind each colored door lies the intrigue and unrivaled luxury of different guestroom design styles at J Hotel: New Chinese and Contemporary. In the New Chinese staterooms
column40: bespoke embossed wallpaper recalls the Yangtze Delta's ancient pavilions and buildings
column41: giving a sense of the region's historic prosperity and elegance. The leather-trimmed TV cabinet and emerald glazed tea table embody dignified traditional Chinese culture. From the gold trim on the olive-green calfskin wall panel and dragon patterns on the sofa to the hand-blown glass floral bedside decorations and Tang Sancai-style ornaments
column42: this thoughtfully crafted interior melds a touch of opulence with a rejuvenating environment. The bathroom is made of white marble with an exquisite glazed backdrop inlaid with a magnolia pattern in full bloom. A full set of Italian-made crystal faucets engraved with the J logo also reflects Jinjiang's determination to build a homegrown high-end brand. The Contemporary staterooms are boldly constructed
column43: defined by crystal magnolias and laminated glass. Sumptuous natural calfskin wall panels add elegance and spaciousness to the sanctuary. The bedside canopy woven with gold and silver wire
column44: crystal magnolia lamps and a two-meter-wide Italian crystal glass TV cabinet all demonstrate exquisite craftsmanship. Selected furniture and ornaments reflect the sophistication of our guests
column45: who can relax in the magnolia petal-shaped bathtub by the window and take in the breathtaking views across the Huangpu River. All prevailing staterooms incorporate separated spaces including a bedroom
column48: creating personal sanctuaries in different layouts and styles. The mini-bar at the entrance offers various drinks and snacks
column49: as well as a Nespresso™ coffee machine and a Chinese tea set. The bedroom area is equipped with a soft Simmons mattress with high-thread-count bedding and a full set of down products
column51: skin-friendly sleeping experience. Whether it be with the integrated crystal executive desk in the New China stateroom or the natural leather executive desk in the Contemporary stateroom
column52: both room styles offer an intuitive workspace
column54: USB and HDMI ports and audio inputs. Each room's built-in Smart Senor Control System allows digital control of the TV
column57: as well as personal butler services
column58: all with a simple tap on a tablet. The complementary 10 M Internet access not only meets guests' needs for high-speed connectivity
column59: but also allows them to enjoy remote document printing services. Numerous international TV programs are available on the 46-inch LED IPTVs
column60: as well as on-demand viewing and screen projections to meet the demands of a diverse range of guests. The walk-in closet provides ample storage space for clothing and luggage and a large-capacity personal safe
column61: while the butler's closet is specially designed for contactless 24-hour laundry collection
column62: ensuring the privacy of each guest. Spacious bathrooms are equipped with a double vanity
column68: and Hermes or Diptyque toiletries.    In addition to the prevailing staterooms
column71: one Jinjiang suite and one Shanghai suite
column72: each with distinctive design themes. The Grand Suite
column73: with an area of about 100 square meters
column74: is an escape from the hustle and bustle of the city and a serene sanctuary with elegant neutral tones
column75: delicate fabrics and top-notch leather. The J Suite
column77: presents the elegance of old Shanghai
column78: also known as the ""Paris of the East
column79: woven together with the sleekness and modernity of contemporary Shanghai. The burgundy door panels and high crystal chandeliers heighten the sense of glamour
column80: while the finest leathers and rich wood grains add a soothing natural touch. The Jinjiang Suite is a spacious 210 square meters. With an unparalleled 180-degree view
column81: guests can enjoy the beautiful scenery of Shanghai and experience the city's evolution in real time. The suite has a separate living room
column85: study and guest washroom to ensure privacy. The Jinjiang Suite is connected to two prevailing guest rooms
column86: allowing for further expansion of living space based on guest needs. As the highest-end suite at J Hotel Shanghai Tower
column87: the Shanghai Suite is an integrated residence of magnificence in the sky. The astonishing 380 square meters of space on Floor 98 offers a separate parlor
column90: study
column91: kitchen and physiotherapy area. Guests are greeted by a luxurious Chinese phoenix and peony embroidery on the calfskin wall at the entrance
column92: before being led into the curved parlor that boasts an exclusive panoramic view of Shanghai. Enriched with elegant furniture and cutting-edge artwork
column93: the Shanghai Suite perfectly illustrates the art of luxury living above it all. The Art of Global Haute Cuisine J Hotel Shanghai Tower features seven distinctive restaurants and bars that offer the art of fine dining in the clouds. These include Heavenly Jin
column94: one of the world's highest restaurants
column95: Kinnjyou Inaka for a serene Japanese experience
column96: Jin Yan for the best of Chinese cuisine
column97: Centouno for Italian and Mediterranean cuisine
column99: the Yi Lounge and the Café & Patisserie. Each establishment has its own unique design and artistic décor
column100: welcoming guests to enjoy spectacular views of Shanghai while feasting on diverse cuisines
column101: fine wines and imaginative cocktails. Located on Floor 120 of the Shanghai Tower
column103: Heavenly Jin is one of the world's highest restaurants. The restaurant is a fusion of diverse culinary arts
column105: Japanese and fine Chinese cuisines created by top chefs from different countries. Guests are greeted by a 30-meter-long Silk Road-themed Italian mosaic made of dozens of rich materials
column106: manifesting openness and inclusivity. Inside the restaurant
column107: diners are seated beneath a sky of ribbon-like crystal lights as they enjoy delicacies prepared by chefs from all over the world—a heavenly experience in the clouds that is not to be missed. On Floor 104
column108: Kinnjyou Inaka Japanese restaurant evokes a feeling of elegance and eternity with an infinity mirror design integrated in the ceiling and partitions. The entrance blends exoticism and traditional craftsmanship with three Japanese fan installations handmade with 24 K gold
column109: engraved glazed glass and black and gold enamel. The restaurant specializes in Kaiseki and Teppanyaki cuisine and features 10 private rooms
column110: as well as a circular sushi bar and open dining area. Each dining area offers a different view of the city
column111: while the chefs perform live Japanese cooking techniques and present fresh and authentic Japanese cuisine. The Jin Yan restaurant on Floor 103 serves authentic Cantonese cuisine. Featuring classic shades of Chinese red
column112: the restaurant is a proud demonstration of the beauty of traditional Chinese craftsmanship. The entrance corridor is made from red glaze and takes inspiration from traditional Chinese architecture. Inside
column113: a crystal art installation displays a dragon playing with a pearl
column114: which is considered an auspicious symbol in China. The openwork light shades are formed from glaze
column115: and the walls are embellished with jade
column117: while a dragon pattern plays across the marble floor. The restaurant has eight private rooms with decorations that incorporate gold
column120: fire and earth—the five elements considered by ancient Chinese culture to have built the world. It also boasts two special private rooms featuring bespoke artworks from artists in glaze and enamel
column121: each lending their own exceptional touch to the dining experience. Painter Zhou Xikang hand-painted landscapes for the moon doors of each private room
column122: inviting diners into a refreshing environment with a feast for both the eyes and the palate. Centouno on Floor 101 blurs the boundary between reality and the virtual with artwork from Edoardo Tresoldi
column123: the famous Italian artist behind ""Absent Matter."" His ghostly architectural work fuses a large Roman wire-mesh dome within the restaurant environment
column124: casting a dream-like atmosphere over the space. This environment is heightened by the modern
column125: healthy cuisine that defines southern Italian and Mediterranean culture. The open kitchen allows guests to appreciate the chef's performance at any time and features a unique pasta selection
column126: offering authentic Italian pasta dishes made from ancient recipes that have been passed down from generation to generation. The Lobby Lounge
column128: is the place for guests to meet and mingle
column129: while the Yi Lounge on Floor 84 is a new benchmark for Shanghai's bar and nightlife scene
column130: mesmerizing guests with Shanghai's world-famous nightlife and live jazz. Located on the first floor of the hotel
column131: the Café & Patisserie specializes in grab-and-go delicacies including coffee
column133: healthy food options. The Art of Wedding and Banquet Experiences The J Hotel Shanghai Tower boasts a 422-square-meter semi-circular Soirée Ballroom on Floor 105
column134: which can be divided into two smaller fan-shaped spaces. It also offers an 86-square-meter boardroom and two multifunctional rooms at 38 square meters and 24 square meters
column135: making it an ideal venue for high-end banquets

The Soirée Ballroom and conference rooms boast panoramic floor-to-ceiling windows and are equipped with advanced audio-visual systems and integrated multimedia equipment. The two fan-shaped ballrooms are each equipped with 31 square meters of embedded curved LED screens for live screen casting with real-time connectivity. The boardroom has a Maxhub smart screen combining HDTV
column138: a digital whiteboard and audio-visual video conferencing functions. The multifunctional meeting room can be custom-designed according to guests' requirements to meet the different needs of any given event. The hotel's professional wedding

The Art of Wellbeing The Reiki spa and fitness center on Floors 84 and 85 provide a perfect escape for guests to relax and rejuvenate. The spa helps dissolve stress and anxiety while rejuvenating the body through holistic techniques and natural products. The fitness center is fully equipped with a yoga room and 160-meter skyline swimming pool

column145: guests can step out into the clouds and enjoy the city from unparalleled heights. The Art of Butler Service Every guest at J Hotel Shanghai Tower can enjoy the exclusive services of a J Hotel Personal Butler. Highly trained

column1: CARBIS BAY
column2: England - The Group of Seven richest democracies sought on Saturday to counter China's growing influence by offering developing nations an infrastructure plan that could rival President Xi Jinping's multi-trillion-dollar Belt and Road initiative.

column1: The G7
column2: whose leaders are meeting in southwestern England
column3: has been searching for a coherent response to the growing assertiveness of Xi after China's surging economic and military rise over the past 40 years.

column1: U.S. President Joe Biden and other G7 leaders hope their plan
column2: known as the Build Back Better World (B3W) initiative
column3: will provide a transparent infrastructure partnership to help narrow the $40 trillion needed by developing nations by 2035

column1: This is not just about confronting or taking on China
column2: a senior official in Biden's administration said. ""But until now we haven't offered a positive alternative that reflects our values
column3: our standards and our way of doing business.""

column2: health and health security

China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) scheme

column1: Critics say Xi's plan to create a modern version of the ancient Silk Road trade route to link China with Asia

column1: CHINA'S RISE

column2: Canada

column1: The re-emergence of China as a leading global power is considered to be one of the most significant geopolitical events of recent times

column11: June 26 — The United States aims to raise US$200 billion (RM880 billion) in private and public funds over five years to fund needed infrastructure in developing countries under a G7 initiative aimed at countering China's multitrillion-dollar Belt and Road project
column12: the White House said today.US President Joe Biden will unveil the plans
column13: flanked by other Group of Seven leaders
column14: some of whom have already unveiled their own separate initiatives
column15: at their annual gathering being held this year at Schloss Elmau in southern Germany.Increasingly worried about China
column16: G7 leaders first floated plans for the project last year
column17: and are formally launching it now under a fresh title
column18: 'Partnership for Global Infrastructure and Investment' while dropping the moniker 'Build Back Better World' first coined by Biden during his presidential campaign.Biden will unveil several specific projects at a G7 side event
column19: joined by leaders from Britain
column20: Germany
column21: Japan
column22: the European Union and Canada
column23: vowing to focus on projects that help tackle climate change as well as improve global health
column24: gender equity and digital infrastructure. Notably absent will be French President Emmanual Macron who had formally joined the Chinese infrastructure programme.'The president's not thinking that we need to spend dollar for dollar versus China... though if you add up what the US and the G7 partners are going to be announcing
column25: it comes pretty close to the number
column26: ' one senior US official told reporters.The funds would be raised through grants and federal funds
column27: and by leveraging private-sector investments
column28: the White House said
column29: adding that hundreds of billions of additional dollars could come from multilateral development banks
column30: development finance institutions
column31: sovereign wealth funds and others.China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) scheme
column32: which Chinese President Xi Jinping launched in 2013
column33: involves development and investment initiatives in over 100 countries
column34: with a range of projects including railways
column35: ports and highways.White House officials say Xi's plan to create a modern version of the ancient Silk Road trade route has provided little tangible benefit for many developing countries
column36: with top jobs going to Chinese workers
column37: while increasing rates of forced and child labor.Biden will highlight several flagship projects
column38: including a US$2 billion solar development project in Angola with support from the Commerce Department
column41: and US project developer Sun Africa.Together with G7 members and the EU
column42: Washington will also provide US$3.3 million in technical assistance to Institut Pasteur de Dakar in Senegal as it develops an industrial-scale flexible multi-vaccine manufacturing facility in that country that can eventually produce Covid-19 and other vaccines.The US Agency for International Development (USAID) will also commit up to US$50 million over five years to the World Bank's new global Childcare Incentive Fund
column43: a project aimed at address the gap in suitable childcare infrastructure. — Reuters;malaymail.com;5981;finance;MY;en;;https://www.malaymail.com/malaymail/uploads/images/2022/06/26/27788.JPG?v=1656280680;False;;19.158207;091476039b1801c0a48e37920cfd7866;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 197;China's persecution of Uyghurs is preview of wider surveillance scheme
column2: lawmakers say;Roseanne Gerin;2021-11-18 00:30:32;full;https://www.rfa.org/english/news/uyghur/commission-hearing-11172021191538.html;rfa.org;Author tells panel what's happened in Xinjiang amounts to ‘mass psychological torture.';"Members of a bipartisan congressional commission warned Wednesday that China's use of technology to repress Muslim Uyghurs in its far-western Xinjiang is widening and could be exported around the world.

column1: The U.S. Congressional-Executive Commission on China
column2: which Congress established in 2000
column3: held a hearing in Washington to draw attention to human rights abuses and the strategic impact of mass surveillance technology and censorship used by China
column4: including in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region.

column1: Sen. Jeff Merkley
column2: co-chairperson of the 17-member commission
column3: said that without proper guardrails to protect privacy and human rights
column4: technology can be used by authoritarian regimes to control populations
column5: prevent freedom of expression
column6: and undermine democratic institutions.

column1: China has 'the most pervasive surveillance state the world has ever seen' using technologies such as artificial intelligence
column2: blockchain
column3: and cloud computing
column4: said Merkley
column5: a U.S. senator from Oregon.

column1: The government has amassed huge amounts of data from cell phones
column2: personal computers
column3: and security cameras to impose political and social control of targeted populations
column4: he said.

column1: 'Nowhere do we see this more than in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region
column2: ' Merkley said.

column1: For years
column2: Chinese authorities have subjected Uyghurs and other Turkic minorities in Xinjiang to arbitrary arrests and restrictions on their religious practice and culture. The system is enforced by a pervasive digitized system that monitors the every move of residents through surveillance drones
column3: facial recognition cameras
column4: mobile phone scans
column5: and an extensive police presence.

column1: China's Digital Silk Road — a component of its Belt and Road Initiative to enhance digital connectivity abroad — is 'an intrusive ecosystem of internet architecture and surveillance technology aiming to expand the People's Republic of China's influence around the world
column2: ' Rep. Chris Smith said.

column1: 'Chinese authorities' relentless persecution of predominantly Muslims Uyghurs
column2: Kazakhs
column3: and other Central Asian people in the country's Xinjiang region provides a disturbing preview of what these tools' misuse [would be] on an even broader scale
column4: ' he said.

column1: China has held up to 1.8 million Uyghurs and others in 're-education' camps since 2017. It dismisses widely documented evidence
column2: including testimony from former detainees and guards
column3: that it has mistreated Muslims living inside and outside the camps.

column1: Instead
column2: Chinese officials contend that the camps are vocational training facilities used to prevent religious extremism and terrorism in the region
column3: which is home to about 12 million Uyghurs.

column1: But Geoffrey Cain
column2: author of a recent book on surveillance in China
column3: told commission members that former camp detainees and Uyghur and Kazakh refugees he had interviewed told similar stories about Xinjiang's 'descent into a total surveillance dystopia.'

column1: China uses its Integrated Joint Operations Platform to store data collected from police human inputs
column2: camera surveillance and criminal and court histories. It then takes the information to determine whether Uyghurs are likely to commit a crime
column3: Cain said. Local police interrogate and detain Uyghurs flagged by the system through notifications sent to the authorities' smartphones.

column1: The technologies developed by Chinese tech firms such as telecom giant Huawei
column2: facial recognition technology provider Megvii
column3: and AI software provider SenseTime amount to a 'system of mass psychological torture
column4: ' he said.

column1: Xinjiang minority residents have a 'feeling of constantly being watched not by humans
column2: but by crude software algorithms designed to predict future crimes and acts of terrorism with great inaccuracy
column3: ' Cain said.

column1: 'The reasons for detention could be as far-flung as whether they went through the front or back door
column2: whether they began a physical exercise routine suddenly
column3: and whether they had the flu and were simply late for work that day
column4: ' Cain told the commission.

column1: There was no immediate response about the hearing from the Chinese government.
'Situation could have been far worse'
The hearing came two days after a three-hour virtual meeting between U.S. President Joe Biden and his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping to discuss bilateral relations.
During the meeting
column2: Biden underscored U.S. concerns about human rights in Xinjiang
column3: Tibet
column4: and Hong Kong
column5: according to a briefing the following day by National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan. He did not elaborate on what was said.

column1: Dolkun Isa
column2: president of the Germany-based World Uyghur Congress
column3: said he was grateful that Biden broached China's atrocities against the Uyghurs during the virtual summit with Xi.

column1: 'If it was not for America's condemnation of China committing genocide against Uyghurs
column2: our situation could have been far worse today
column3: ' he told RFA on Tuesday.

column1: 'The Biden administration must boycott the Beijing Winter Olympics
column2: ' Isa said. 'If it doesn't
column3: it'll only embolden China to continue to commit the genocide.'

column1: In June
column2: the U.S. Congressional-Executive Commission on China urged Thomas Bach
column3: president of the International Olympic Committee
column4: to postpone the 2022 Beijing Games and to relocate them if the host government did not end its human rights abuses.

column1: The U.S. government has declared that the China's campaign of abuse against Uyghurs in Xinjiang amounts to crimes against humanity and genocide.
On the same day Biden and Xi met
column2: the 2021 China Xinjiang Development Forum was held in Beijing to highlight the success of the Belt and Road Initiative and the important role Xinjiang has played
column3: while accusing Washington of using the issue to weaken China.

column1: 'The U.S.-led Western anti-China forces time and again manufactured Xinjiang related empty claims such as ‘genocide
column2: ' ‘forced labor
column3: ' and ‘forced sterilization' and used so-called human rights issues to harshly interfere in China's internal affairs
column4: ' said Jiang Jianguo
column5: vice minister of the Chinese Communist Party's Central Propaganda Department.

column1: 'Through political motives
column2: they attempted to ‘use Xinjiang to contain China' and ‘use terrorism to constrain China.' By wreaking havoc in Xinjiang
column3: they attempted to prevent the development of a strong China
column4: ' he said.";rfa.org;6267;news;MM;en;['Roseanne Gerin'
column5: 'Alim Seytoff'];https://www.rfa.org/english/news/uyghur/commission-hearing-11172021191538.html/@@images/image;False;;18.494183;a2a84495f4cba51e36c4a2ab5ec243fb;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 198;Southeast Asia will feel economic
column2: political fallout from a more powerful Xi Jinping;A Commentary Zachary Abuza;2022-10-26 19:09:30;full;https://www.rfa.org/english/commentaries/china-xi-southeastasia-10262022145045.html;rfa.org;Regional economy driver China is every Southeast Asian country's largest trading partner.;"The Chinese Communist Party's 20th Congress saw the thorough consolidation of power by Xi Jinping
column3: elected to a third term
column4: with a leadership that is personally loyal to him. No leader since Mao consolidated this amount of political power. China's importance as a trade partner and regional power means that this will be felt across Southeast Asia economically
column5: politically
column6: as well as in the diplomatic and security realm.

column1: What may be good for Xi politically is not good for China economically. Xi stacked the Politburo and its Standing Committee with ideologues and loyalists; there are no pro-economic reform advocates left and corporate China is not represented.
Even before the 20th Congress
column2: the Chinese economy had slowed as a result of the draconian zero-covid policy and Xi's assault on the dynamic privately owned tech sector. But the markets reacted sharply to Xi's consolidation of power.

column1: The stock market index collapsed as soon as the markets opened on Monday. There was a major selloff on all indexes and some $2.47 billion of foreign funds immediately withdrew from the China market.
There's a real concern that the informal tax on the wealthy
column2: known as the 'Common Prosperity' donations
column3: will become larger and more compulsory.

column1: Capital flight is skyrocketing as high-net-worth individuals seek to move their funds to the safety of foreign jurisdictions. Money is flowing out of China as fast as possible. The Financial Times reported that the number of private Chinese family investments in Singapore nearly doubled from 400 to 700 since late 2020.
No one will speak truth to power in China anymore. Surrounded by sycophants
column2: Xi is more likely to pursue policies that cannot be reversed.

column1: This has an immediate impact on Southeast Asia as every country's largest trading partner is China
column2: particularly those that are still largely dependent on the export of raw materials.

column1: China
column2: which has been  a major source of foreign investment in the region is seeing its GDP growth continue to slow
column3: now below 5 percent for the year.

column1: While capital flight may help some sectors in Southeast Asia
column2: the gains will be narrow
column3: and not compensate for the loss of China as the driver of economic growth in the region.

column1: Workers stand beside an Electric Multiple Unit high-speed train for a rail link project that's part of China's Belt and Road Initiative
column2: at Tegalluar train depot in Bandung
column3: West Java province
column4: Indonesia
column5: Oct. 13
column6: 2022. Credit: Reuters

column1: A changing Belt and Road Initiative
While the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is still state policy
column2: Xi's signature program of infrastructure lending for projects to boost China's trade  with Asia and Africa is a diminished initiative. In 2018 and 2019
column3: even before the pandemic
column4: BRI lending dropped precipitously. The two state-owned development banks that were responsible for 75 percent of BRI funding
column5: saw lending collapse. Overall lending in 2020 was 58 percent from its 2018 peak.

column1: Very clearly
column2: many BRI projects are underwater and debt servicing had slowed. In 2018-19
column3: China quietly renegotiated the repayment terms of $16 billion in loans. The pandemic caused a further slowdown in lending.

column1: Though BRI projects recommenced in 2020
column2: they are considerably smaller in scale and amount.

column1: Xi will not abandon the BRI. It's his vanity project and too associated with him to dismantle. Indeed
column2: it was mentioned five times in the Oct. 16 Political Report to the congress
column3: compared to just twice in 2017.

column1: The BRI will likely move away from physical infrastructure and focus on fiber optic cables
column2: 5G and 6G
column3: and the export of artificial intelligence/smart cities. Emphasizing the Digital Silk Road serves many of China's interests. It deepens their control over the internet and protocols
column4: routes more traffic through Chinese servers
column5: and gets other countries to adopt Chinese software and norms. The export of their digital authoritarian model will be a key priority.

column1: Analysts are still divided on what the Congress means for Taiwan
column2: a major factor in region-wide stability. On the one hand
column3: Xi's report was fairly pragmatic and made clear that there would be no quick move to invade the island
column4: though he refused to renounce the use of force. Taiwan was mentioned only nine times in the report
column5: compared to 12 in 2017
column6: and the report offered no change in the existing policy.

column1: Although Xi remains focused on PLA modernization by 2027
column2: which obviously includes all Taiwan contingencies
column3: his personnel selection for the Central Military Commission (CMC) also suggest caution.

column1: The CMC has little in the way of operational experience
column2: in particular joint experience
column3: with the exception of its two vice chairmen. While it includes the commander of the ground forces
column4: the CMC is dominated by the army and lacks representation from the Strategic Rocket Forces
column5: PLA-Navy
column6: PLA-Air Force
column7: i.e. the service arms that would be most involved in an invasion of or an attack on Taiwan.

column1: Of course there's always the chance of a miscalculation or uncontrolled escalation. China still sees a very narrow window of opportunity to reunify Taiwan.

But Xi and the CCP cannot afford anything other than a decisive military victory over Taiwan that does not escalate into a protracted conflict with the United States and others. The reputational cost to the regime for failing to achieve a clear-cut victory would be astronomical.
Sansha City's maritime militia demonstrating knife fighting on Woody Island in the South China Sea. Credit: Xinhua News.
Downsides for security and the economy
That's actually not good for Southeast Asia. A limited conflict in the South China Sea against a much weaker adversary
column2: where they can control the escalatory cycle
column3: far away from the prying eyes of their ultranationalist public
column4: is a very good opportunity for the PLA to gain some joint warfighting experience.

column1: As such
column2: there will be a harder line and a more aggressive stance in the South China Sea.

column1: But we're in new territory here. Xi has absolute and unrestricted power; there are no institutional checks on him
column2: which makes security in Southeast Asia far less predictable.

column1: Foreign Minister Wang Yi
column2: who successfully executed Xi Jinping's 'wolf warrior' diplomacy featuring combative
column3: jingoistic envoys who hectored their host countries on social media
column4: was elevated to the 24-man Politburo. He will replace Yang Jiechi as the director of the general office of the Central Foreign Affairs Commission.

column1: On the Politburo Standing Committee is Wang Huning
column2: the top ideology czar who ensured that 'Xi Jinping Thought' was enshrined in the constitution. Wang is also a fervent nationalist and really the driving force behind the assertive nationalism and the BRI that were the hallmarks of Xi's first decade in office.

column1: Xi's army of wolf warrior diplomats will continue their hawkish rhetoric
column2: despite the fact that public opinion towards China across Southeast Asia is starting to harden.

column1: It's important that both the Minister of State Security and the Minister of Public Security
column2: for the first time sit on the Politburo.

column1: This underscores the regime's obsession with security
column2: but it also matters in Southeast Asia
column3: where the long arm of China's law has been felt
column4: with demands for the repatriation of dissidents and Uyghurs.

column1: The governments of Southeast Asia are clearly afraid of being pulled into great power competition between the United States and China. No state wants to be forced to chose sides
column2: as both countries are critically important economic partners.

column1: For the past several years
column2: Southeast Asians have largely blamed Washington for destabilizing actions
column3: including the U.S. Navy's Freedom of Navigation operations (FONOPs) in the South China Sea  or Speaker Nancy Pelosi's July 2022 visit to Taiwan.

column1: Now
column2: however
column3: Xi made clear that he is going to pursue a much more confrontational policy towards the United States. But most importantly
column4: China looks set to continue to undermine the rules-based international order that has been the foundation for Southeast Asia's spectacular economic growth.

column1: Zachary Abuza is a professor at the National War College in Washington and an adjunct at Georgetown University. The views expressed here are his own and do not reflect the position of the U.S. Department of Defense
column2: the National War College
column3: Georgetown University or RFA.";rfa.org;6267;news;MM;en;A Commentary Zachary Abuza

column1: 199;Asian Countries Welcome G7's Answer to China's One Belt
column2: One Road Program;;2021-06-23 19:38:25;full;https://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/program-06232021151152.html;rfa.org;The US-led Build Back Better World (B3W) initiative is scant in details
column3: though
column4: and some countries' leaders say they now want more information.;"Bangladesh and nations in Southeast Asia are welcoming the Group of Seven's new answer to China's One Belt
column5: One Road initiative
column6: saying it will be another source for financing their burgeoning infrastructure needs.

column1: But because the U.S.-led Build Back Better World Partnership (B3W) initiative is scant in details
column2: officials of some governments in the region and analysts say they also are waiting for more information to see how it can help their countries. China has an eight-year head start and has pumped huge amounts of money into its global infrastructure-building program (OBOR).

column1: The new initiative
column2: announced this month at the G7 summit in Cornwall
column3: England
column4: promises sustainable and value-driven infrastructure investment to the tune of 'hundreds of billions of dollars' in low- and middle-income countries in the coming years.

column1: The program will help narrow a U.S. $40 trillion need for infrastructure projects across the developing world
column2: President Joe Biden said in announcing the new initiative.

column1: B3W is 'a good opportunity for us
column2: ' Bangladesh Planning Minister Abdul Mannan told BenarNews
column3: an RFA-affiliated online news service
column4: this week.

column1: 'We will try to exploit the opportunity for our development efforts. Other than the Chinese sources
column2: B3W would allow us to explore funds for infrastructure development in Bangladesh
column3: ' he said.

column1: Thailand
column2: too
column3: 'welcomes' the G7 initiative and views it and Beijing's OBOR initiative as 'mutually reinforcing
column4: ' Thanee Sangrat
column5: spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs
column6: told BenarNews.

column1: 'Both aim to strengthen connectivity and create resilient supply chains in our region
column2: ' he said.

column1: The Philippines welcomes B3W 'but to see and to actually receive it is to believe [it]
column2: ' presidential spokesman Harry Roque told BenarNews.

column1: Indonesia
column2: Southeast Asia's largest and most populous country
column3: is also waiting to see how B3W investments are made
column4: according to Jodi Mahardi
column5: spokesman for the investment ministry.

column1: 'We welcome the B3W development initiative proposed by the G-7
column2: but we want to see the implementation. There have been many U.S.-led initiatives that are lacking in realization
column3: ' Jodi told BenarNews.

column1: 'The schemes must be flexible
column2: based on the needs of partner countries
column3: not on what Western countries see as good. I used the word ‘partner' because we don't want the relationship to be between donors and recipients
column4: we want it to be [cooperation] between equals.'

column1: BenarNews contacted Malaysia's investment agency
column2: the trade ministry
column3: and the minister in charge of economics
column4: but officials did not immediately return calls seeking comment.

column1: Economists and political analysts in these countries said B3W investments would be good alternative sources of funding for infrastructure projects.
Ahsan H. Mansur
column2: an economist and executive director of the Policy Research Institute in Dhaka
column3: described the G7 initiative as 'a big opportunity for us
column4: the developing and low-income countries.'

column1: 'This is because now we have an alternative option to get funds from
column2: ' he told BenarNews.

column1: B3W is not fully fleshed out yet but
column2: in principle
column3: is a good funding source for Indonesia
column4: said Fithra Faisal Hastiadi
column5: executive director of Next Policy
column6: an Indonesian think-tank.

column1: 'I think B3W will be a good alternative for Indonesia as a non-aligned country. But I think the problem is the initiative is still half-baked
column2: ' Fithra told BenarNews.

column1: Walden Bello
column2: co-chair of the Board of Focus on the Global South
column3: a Bangkok think-tank
column4: was blunter. He dismissed the G7 initiative as 'purely reactive.'

column1: '[A]nd purely reactive programs tend to be put together in a hurry with little serious thought to follow-through
column2: ' he said.

column1: For Oh Ei Sun
column2: an international relations specialist based in Singapore
column3: B3W will lead to countries in the region 'playing both sides to see who will be able to offer more.'

column1: 'It's all about the money
column2: let's not kid ourselves
column3: ' Oh told BenarNews.

column1: Unveiled in 2013
column2: OBOR is Chinese President Xi Jinping's signature geopolitical program that aims to build a modern-day Silk Road through a network of ports
column3: railways
column4: roads
column5: and trade routes to connect China to markets in Southeast Asia
column6: South Asia

column1: OBOR began eight years ago with a focus on investments around the world in energy
column2: infrastructure
column3: and transportation projects. Estimates about the size of OBOR investments vary widely – from $1 trillion to $8 trillion.

column1: According to a London-based financial data firm Refinitiv
column2: in January 2020 OBOR comprised close to 3
column3: 000 projects valued at $3.87 trillion.

column1: Ongoing construction in Southeast Asia includes the $6 billion Bandung-Jakarta high-speed rail project in Indonesia and the $1.3 billion Kyaukphyu deep-water port in Myanmar
column2: among others.

column1: In Bangladesh
column2: China has provided nearly $7 billion for nine development projects since October 2016
column3: according to data from the Ministry of Finance.

column1: ‘More equitable way'
Some may see B3W and OBOR as complementary
column2: but President Biden and the G7 see the two initiatives as fundamentally different.

column1: 'The point is that what's happening is that China has this Belt and Road Initiative
column2: and we think that there's a much more equitable way to provide for the needs of countries around the world
column3: ' Biden told a press conference in Cornwall on June 13
column4: according to a White House transcript.

column1: 'And we believe that will not only be good for the countries
column2: but it'll be good for the entire world and represent values that our democracies represent
column3: and not autocratic lack of values.'

column1: The democracies he referred to are the U.S. and fellow G7 members Canada
column2: France
column3: Germany
column4: Italy
column5: Japan
column6: and the United Kingdom.

column1: Biden was highlighting that China is not a democracy
column2: and alluding to what critics have said is Beijing's practice of predatory lending or debt-trap diplomacy in OBOR.

column1: For instance
column2: analysts point to Chinese loans to Sri Lanka
column3: in particular
column4: as a cautionary tale for nations planning to borrow from Beijing.

column2: a Chinese state-owned company took over a majority stake in Sri Lanka's strategic Hambantota port after Colombo struggled to repay its loans from China.

column1: B3W
column2: on the other hand
column3: emphasizes what it calls 'enhanced multilateral finance
column4: ' the G7 said in a communiqué issued from Cornwall on June 13.

column1: Multilateral development banks and other international financial Institutions 'have evolved to embody the highest standards for project planning
column2: implementation
column3: social and environmental safeguards
column4: and analytical capability
column5: ' the communiqué said.

column1: 'We emphasize the importance of transparent
column2: open
column3: economically efficient
column4: fair and competitive standards for lending and procurement
column5: also in line with debt sustainability
column6: and the adherence of international rules and standards for major creditor countries

column1: B3W-related investments are to be guided by standards such as those promoted by the updated Blue Dot Network
column2: G7's communique added.

column1: The Blue Dot Network
column2: announced by the United States
column3: Japan
column4: and Australia in November 2019
column5: assesses and certifies infrastructure projects for environmental sustainability
column6: financial transparency

column1: ‘Thailand shares G7's endeavor'
Thailand
column2: for one
column3: especially welcomes the B3W's focus on transparent and sustainable investments through clear and established international mechanisms
column4: said Thanee
column5: the foreign ministry spokesman.

column1: 'Thailand shares the G7's endeavor in developing high-quality infrastructure with a fresh approach that advocates responsibility for the environment and for the people; fiscal sustainability; the participation of international investors and financial institutions; and compatibility with global standards by adopting international norms
column2: ' Thanee said.

column1: '[T]he B3W initiative … supports our priorities.'
B3W's priority investment areas will be climate
column2: health and health security
column3: digital technology
column4: and gender equity and equality
column5: according to a White House fact sheet about the initiative.

column1: But transparency in investment
column2: and funding in gender equity and health projects may be seen by some nations as 'pet projects' that come 'with strings attached
column3: ' said Oh
column4: a senior fellow at the Singapore Institute of International Affairs.

column1: 'These are important only in the eyes of advanced liberal democracies' and not considered as vital in some other countries
column2: Oh told BenarNews.

column1: 'The G7 is also harping on transparency which is in not the norm in most parts of the developing world
column2: ' Oh told BenarNews.

column1: Oh
column2: Indonesian economist Fithra
column3: and other analysts cast doubt on whether the G7 countries
column4: however advanced and industrialized
column5: have the financial chops to compete with China's massive OBOR investments.

column1: Bello
column2: the analyst based in Bangkok
column3: noted that China's initial commitment to OBOR was $1 trillion in 2013-2014
column4: but had now ballooned to – by some estimates – around $4 trillion.

column100: meningococcal meningitis is considered as ""death disease"" because about 5-20 percent of the population in Vietnam carry meningococcal bacteria in their nose and throat without becoming sick. Meningococcal bacteria are very common and live naturally in the nose and throat. The bacteria are present in saliva and can be spread through close contact with the saliva of a carrier.Meningococcal disease can be difficult to diagnose because initial symptoms are usually similar to a bad cold or flu. The illness may develop slowly over a couple of days or may worsen rapidly over a few hours. Symptoms do not appear in any particular order and some may not occur at all.Symptoms that may occur in adults and children include high temperature (fever) – possibly with cold hands and feet

column1: 202;Is China exporting surveillance under the guise of 'smart city'?;Dr. Chester B. Cabalza;2023-03-12 16:01:00;timezone unknown;https://www.manilatimes.net/2023/03/13/opinion/columns/is-china-exporting-surveillance-under-the-guise-of-smart-city/1882447;manilatimes.net;CHINA is one of the leading countries in 'smart city' initiatives.;"CHINA is one of the leading countries in ""smart city"" initiatives. Chinese companies are involved in more than half of the world's smart city initiatives. These companies
column2: with the expertise of developing new cities and urban technologies at home
column3: are expanding their businesses abroad.

column1: As their aspirations align with the development interests of the emerging economy of various countries
column2: Chinese firms are emerging as crucial players in development planning. For instance
column3: in Southeast Asia
column4: Chinese firms play significant roles in many existing or planned built-from-scratch smart cities. Beijing's launch of the Belt and Road Initiative
column5: and its ""Digital Silk Road"" component
column6: provide high-level support for Chinese companies' participation.

column1: It is tempting for emerging markets in Southeast Asia to forge a consensual approach with China's technology investment firms despite its proneness to threats in the purview of national security.
Disadvantages and concerns

Becoming ""smart"" means harnessing data to optimize city functions — from more efficient use of utilities and other services to reducing traffic congestion and pollution — all to empower public authorities and citizens.
The digital silk road initiative is an attempt to modernize and strengthen the digital economy of Southeast Asia through increased connectivity in telecommunications
column2: the internet of things
column3: artificial intelligence and robotics. But it also has ill effects on the borderless digital cloud since China has control of the sources of digital engines and technologies. What's more
column4: the disadvantages may soon outweigh the supposed advantages.

column1: There are concerns about how supercharged surveillance is encroaching on free speech
column2: privacy and data protection. But the truth is that facial recognition and related technologies are far from the most worrisome features of smart cities.

column1: Part of what supposedly makes cities smarter is the deployment and integration of surveillance technologies such as sensors and biometric data collection systems. Electronic
column2: infrared
column3: thermal and lidar sensors form the basis of the smart grid
column4: and they do everything from operating streetlights to optimizing parking and traffic flow to detecting crime.

column1: Shanghai has installed Alibaba's City Brain public surveillance system
column2: which oversees over 1
column3: 100 biometric facial recognition cameras. A combination of satellites
column4: drones and fixed cameras grab over 20 million images a day. The bus
column5: metro and credit cards of residents are also traced in real-time. These surveillance tools are spreading. Chinese firms are busy exporting surveillance tech to Latin America
column6: other parts of Asia
column8: helping enable what some critics call digital authoritarianism.

column1: But a narrow preoccupation with surveillance technologies
column2: as disconcerting as they are
column3: underestimates the threats on the near horizon. Smart cities are themselves a potential liability — for entirely different reasons. This is because many of them are approaching the precipice of a hyperconnected ""internet of everything
column4: which comes with unprecedented levels of risk tied to billions of unsecured devices.

column1: These don't just include real-time surveillance devices
column2: such as satellites
column3: drones and closed-circuit cameras. By 2025
column4: there could be over 75 billion connected devices around the world
column5: many of them lack even the most rudimentary security features. As cities become ever more connected
column6: the risks of digital harm by malign actors grow exponentially.

column1: The partner countries involved in the project would not only allow China to monitor huge volumes of data on their citizens but also on those from other countries
column2: who are on personal or business trips. They will also be helping China to become a global leader in exporting its authoritarian surveillance technology to other like-minded regimes.

column1: Accessing data
The Chinese government is equipped with laws
column2: which enable it to access data from any device. The Chinese companies make available all their customer data to the government for inclusion in the Social Credit score. Moreover
column3: Chinese companies and nationals also participate in the country's espionage project. So
column4: anyone connected to the BRI is part of the Chinese national surveillance project.

column1: China is probably one of the best real-world examples of how a politician can use a ""dictatorship in a box"" solution to get and maintain political success.
China has AI tools embedded in those technologies
column2: which poses threat to society and has implications for the host countries. The sophistication of AI tools built-in with those technologies can bring two consequences.

column1: It could lead to addiction and tech support to win the hearts and minds of Southeast Asians or it could lead to further digital destruction igniting copyright issues
column2: and ethical considerations for infringement and espionage.

column1: Security risks

Australia's decision to remove cameras in sensitive and critical technologies from China is considerable since it breaches wider threats to national security. Australia's foreign ministry followed the lead of the country's defense ministry
column2: deciding to remove all Chinese-made surveillance cameras from its facilities following reports that the technology posed a security risk.

column1: This followed Defense Minister Richard Marles' statement that he had ordered Chinese-made security cameras stripped from defense sites following an audit that revealed at least 913 such cameras had been installed across more than 250 Australian government buildings.
The United States has already banned several Chinese vendors and surveillance products
column2: and the United Kingdom last November informed government departments to cease installing Chinese-linked surveillance cameras at sensitive buildings
column3: citing security risks.

column1: China is installing over 500 surveillance cameras in Gwadar city of Pakistan
column2: fueling speculations that it was never meant to be a port for trade. It is built like a naval base.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the ex-CM of Balochistan has revealed that many people are being forcibly shifted from Gwadar to accommodate a fenced community project for Chinese companies.

column1: Studies show that smart city implications will be a threat to maritime security. Espionage will be prevalent just like the latest spying balloon saga where China released information that the big white balloon was used for meteoric weather forecasting. But cognitive warfare brought deception that is imminent to the armed forces. As power rivalry rises
column2: we will see more manifestations of irregular warfare.

column1: While technologies can disrupt operations
column2: they can also destroy carriers
column3: submarines
column4: vessels and warships using digital configurations. The connecting dots are eminent in the domino effects of the digital economy on maritime trade and aerial operations.

column1: Identity theft
column2: unlawful data gathering
column3: and sharing
column4: phishing and espionage may become prevalent if not cautiously investigated and monitored using the doubted cyber and technological initiatives and efforts of China.

column1: There are fiber optics and electronics that can copy or transmit information without the knowledge of the proprietors and users.

There are lurking dangers in the use of language and specs of digital technologies in favor of Chinese inventors and makers of technologies. It may be cheaper and affordable to make it more marketable and reachable
column2: but the tech trap imposes a lot of dangers and threats. In China's attempt to be digitally inclusive
column3: it must perform transparency to make no excuse for information and technology thefts.

column2: University of the Philippines in Diliman. He is the founding president of the Manila-based think tank International Development and Security Cooperation (IDSC). column1: 204;'Durian! Durian!' Cry the Chinese;Jaime J. Yambao;2022-11-11 16:03:00;full;https://www.manilatimes.net/2022/11/12/opinion/columns/durian-durian-cry-the-chinese/1866027;manilatimes.net;LAST year
column3: China edged out the United States as the No. 1 trading partner of the Philippines. It was no big surprise. For nearly a decade already
column4: China has been the largest...;"LAST year
column6: China edged out the United States as the No. 1 trading partner of the Philippines. It was no big surprise. For nearly a decade already
column7: China has been the largest trading partner of the Asean region and a few years after the Asean was the leading trading partner of China. The Philippines in this respect has thus actually been a late bloomer. (Blame the enduring stranglehold of American colonization on the Philippine economy?)How this all came about may be traced largely to Asean and China entering into the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Economic Cooperation
column8: which resulted in the Asean-China Free Trade Area rolling out in 2010. Trade between them expanded rapidly as tariffs were lowered and investments liberalized between them.The logic of propinquity is writ large in this development. China is the Philippines' nearest neighbor to the north. The direct flights now available between the two countries' capitals
column9: Manila and Beijing
column10: bear this out. I barely had the time between takeoff and landing procedures to take a good nap the last time I went to Beijing. This is incredible when one recalls the time the traveler had no choice but to stop over in Hong Kong
column11: and from there
column12: take a small plane or a slow bus to the mainland. China then was truly faraway. Well
column13: not anymore. The closeness of trade between China and the Philippines would be no surprise for another reason: Trade between the Philippines and China has very ancient historical roots. Archeologists and historians believe in a Maritime Jade Road trading in jade and spices springing up in Taiwan and the Philippines from 2000 BCE to 1000 CE and reaching parts of Vietnam
column14: Malaysia
column15: Indonesia and other areas in Southeast Asia.The Philippines stood at the gateway of the Maritime Silk Route
column16: which connected Southeast Asia
column19: Somalia
column20: Egypt and Europe. It began at the same time as the overland Silk Route in 2nd century BCE stretching from Asia to the Mediterranean traversing China
column21: India
column22: Persia
column23: Arabia
column24: Greece and Italy. The Maritime Silk Route lasted longer
column25: by a century
column26: as traders abandoned the overland Silk Route because of the frequency of their being attacked by bandits of various nationalities. There were Chinese (Japanese
column27: too) in the South China Sea like Limahong but they seemed a lot fewer than the bandits on the overland Silk Route! Evidence abounds that the Philippines was part of the Maritime Silk Route in the form of the Chinese ceramics from different dynasties unearthed by excavations all over the Philippines. The Chinese exchanged ceramics besides the proverbial silk and colored beads
column28: while the Filipinos traded hemp cloth
column29: tortoise shells
column30: pearls and yellow wax.The Martime Silk Route was replaced in the subsequent age by European colonialism in Asia with the galleon trade
column31: which from the 115th to latter part of the 119th century brought goods from China and the Philippines and Southeast Asia to the Americas and Europe in exchange for silver money minted in Mexico. For some strange reason
column32: the galleon trade ended when Mexico became independent from Spain.Enter the United States by pretending to be an ally of the Philippine Revolution against Spain but turning out to be a colonizer and occupier. Faraway United States remained the top trading partner of the Philippines even after independence because of heavy American investments in the Philippines and by such devices as Parity Rights.So much for that rear view of the trade between China and the Philippines. Let's look at now and ahead. It is no time yet to celebrate China's becoming the Philippines' leading trading partner. It may only be a considered just a beginning of sorts. China-Philippines trade can only rise to greater heights because it is quite low in total volume when compared to the leading trading partners of China among the Asean countries. Two-way trade of the Philippines with China in 2021 was a meager $38.35 billion compared to the total volume of $165 billion of the top Asean trading partner of China
column33: Vietnam. Trailing behind the latter country were Malaysia
column34: Thailand and Singapore. Those four countries alone accounted for 74.7 percent of trade between China and Asean. The Philippine government is counting on the export of digital monolithic integrated circuits and semiconductor devices in the electronics and electrical sector
column35: which accounted for majority of exports last year
column36: to push trade with China further upward. These along with metals
column37: motor vehicles and parts
column38: coconut and its by-products

column1: Also tagged for the big push are fruits. The two countries' being the nearest neighbors makes trade in perishable goods a worthwhile activity. A considerable encouraging factor was their being part of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership
column2: now the biggest trading bloc in the world
column3: whose other members include the Asean countries. The partnership stipulates that customs clearance of perishable goods should basically be completed in less than six hours.In recent years
column4: the Philippines successfully pushed avocadoes to join bananas
column5: pineapples and mangoes as top perishable exports to China. Promising to be the next Philippine fruit to conquer the Chinese market is durian. A group of inspectors from China came early last year and found Philippine durian of high quality and good taste. Reception by the Chinese of the first batch of imports from Davao City later last year was more than enthusiastic. From what I gather from my friends in Beijing
column6: the Chinese fully expect the Philippines to join the other countries in Southeast Asia as big exporters of this King of Fruits.China has for sometime now been the biggest importer of durian in the world. 2021 was a boom year for durian
column7: with imports rising year on year by 427 percent to 821
column8: 000 tons worth $4.205 billion. Trust the Chinese culinary inventiveness to find various ways of enjoying the fruit apart from its natural
column9: creamy state
column10: taste and texture: as durian cake
column11: durian milk crepes
column12: durian pizza
column13: durian hot pot
column14: etc. While I had my first taste of durian in Manila and Davao
column15: I developed a love
column16: nay a passion for it in Laos where I had my first ambassadorial posting. It grows almost wildly in that country. Neighbors would gift you with their surplus produce. The tree would grow and ripen on the branch so plentifully that they harvested more than they could consume. Like all edible things grown in Laos' extremely fertile
column18: the durian in Laos is extra-sweet and addictive.Coming back on recall to Manila
column19: I found this newly-found passion difficult to satisfy. One finds durian rarely and long and in-between in the markets in Manila and he finds it only at the high-end markets at high-end prices.Some people explain this rarity of durian in Manila for its pungent smell. I find this theory as sheer sour-graping to hide their inability to afford the fruit. The last time I found and bought a durian fruit
column20: spikes
column21: and all
column22: I paid P800
column23: way above the daily minimum wage in Manila. I have never minded
column24: much more
column25: been offended by the smell of durian. I simply thought it providential that durian should have a strong smell like other fruits with strong smells
column26: e.g.
column27: mabolo and cheza. Actually there are many varieties of durian
column28: some with flowery
column29: pleasant smells and others with no smell at all. The more reasonable explanation is the fact that while durian grows in at least 47 provinces in Luzon
column30: Visayas and Mindanao
column31: more than 90 percent of the supply come from Davao
column32: and much of this probably stays in Davao. The folks there eat durian
column33: with some freshly-boiled rice
column34: as main dish. If under contracts with the Chinese
column35: all the produce in Davao were exported to China
column36: what would happen to the durian lovers of Manila?That is why I have greeted the news about durian in China with mixed emotions. I remember what happened to the mango after it became a Philippine brand export to Japan and other places. Mangoes became more expensive than apples and the mangoes one finds in the local markets are the rejects of the quality-control procedures required of exporters
column37: fruits with one dark tiny spot or two.On the other hand
column38: the export of the fruit would
column40: mean additional income for some of the poorest localities in the country. The silver lining in the exports abroad of favorite fruits is that demand abroad forces increased local production of the fruit. Mangoes were grown in more places and they became available not only at the height of summer but all year round. New uses for the mango were found. Juice was made from it
column41: even if still unripe or green. Mangoes not passing export quality control are dried in the sun and sold as snacks and by themselves are exported. I hope the same will happen to durian. Why can't it be grown outside Davao? Why can't we eat durian all day? As main dish at breakfast
column43: and durian sandwiches and durian ice cream mid-morning and mid-afternoon?";manilatimes.net;7400;science;PH;en;Jaime J. Yambao;https://www.manilatimes.net/manilatimes/uploads/images/2022/11/11/125773.jpg;True;;20.28781;8ac5d3304dda76764a0d915ebed1700d;{'q': 'Digital Silk Road AND China'

column1: 205;Asian Century: Imagine the world without China;Dr. Carl E. Balita;2023-05-25 16:06:00;full;https://www.manilatimes.net/2023/05/26/opinion/columns/asian-century-imagine-the-world-without-china/1893110;manilatimes.net;THIS column celebrates the Asian Century and shall feature a series of articles that celebrate the contributions of the East to the universe and promote Eastern cosmology that transforms towards…;"THIS column celebrates the Asian Century and shall feature a series of articles that celebrate the contributions of the East to the universe and promote Eastern cosmology that transforms towards harmony (not homogenization) and that allows co-existence amid diversity. This article is all about China.
As the world was Europeanized in the 19th century and Americanized in the 20th century
column2: it is being Asianized in the 21st century. Global leaders acknowledged that the Asian Century is set to begin (Financial Times
column3: 2019) and there is no turning back (WEF) and there are reasons to be optimistic (Nikkei). Asia's rise has been swift. Looking ahead
column4: Asia is expected to rebound faster
column5: post-pandemic (IMF). The region is home to 21 of the world's 30 largest
column6: and four of the 10 most visited countries.

column1: Home to more than half of the world's population
column2: the region has climbed from low- to middle-income status within a single generation. By 2040
column3: it is likely to generate more than 50 percent of world GDP
column4: and could account for nearly 40 percent of global consumption.

column1: China in numbers
Central to the Asian Century is China. Forty years of economic growth
column2: at an average of nearly 10 percent a year
column3: has transformed the country into a global leader in technology and manufacturing. China is home to six of the world's megacities
column4: and its economy is now second only in size to the United States — larger if trade is taken into account. Life expectancy has risen to 75 for men and 78 for women (WHO)
column5: with a mean age of 38.4 for a population of 1.41 billion.

column1: China's consumer spending is about $6 trillion per year (2020) and it has everything for the world. Over 35 percent of the global luxury goods spend comes from China. It is also a major contributor to the global tourism industry
column2: with about $250 billion spent internationally.

column1: China is a world leader in renewable energy. China is home to over 400 electric vehicle companies and leading consumer and manufacturer of the solar power industry with three of the world's five largest floating solar plants. China accounts for more than half of global electric car sales.
Pioneering China

Many of the things we use in our daily lives were pioneered by the Chinese. From the paper (105 BCE) to the printing press (960–1127) to bristle toothbrush (1498) to kites (1232) and umbrellas inspired by lotus leaves in ancient China. China's dominant silk market today dates back during the Neolithic period. The earliest porcelain emerged in the Shang Dynasty (1600–1046 BCE)
column2: matured during the Tang Dynasty (618-906) and improved during the Song Dynasty (960–1279).

column1: Ancient Chinese medicine is known for preventive medicine through food and medicine homology wherein food is the medicine and medicines are food. They have already standardized the unit of measure for medicine. Tea was discovered in ancient China by the Chinese emperor Shennong (2737 BC). Alcohol is known as Jiu in Chinese and is often used as a spiritual offering in ancient China (1000 years before Arabian). Beer was widely consumed in ancient China.
