column4: the academy has projected $511 billion in revenue from domestic tourism
column5: up 48% year on year.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: an annual survey of high-net-worth individuals by Chinese research firm Hurun Report found that interest in domestic travel jumped 31% year on year and 44% of respondents said they planned to increase their travel spending.

column1: Outbound tourism is officially discouraged
column2: and the quarantine-on-return requirements are onerous
column3: Sienna Parulis-Cook
column4: director of marketing and communications at Dragon Trail
column5: a China-focused digital marketing agency
column6: tells CNN Travel.

column1: There is also social pressure and a sense of responsibility that you should not risk others by traveling abroad and potentially bringing back the virus with you.""
While international travel remains challenging
column2: wealthy travelers are taking every opportunity to explore their home country.

column1: Because China is so vast. There are so many different languages
column2: cultures and foods as well -- different things grow in different regions
column3: Jolie Howard
column4: the CEO of L' VOYAGE bespoke private jet charter service based in Hong Kong
column5: tells CNN Travel. ""There is so much variety.""

column1: Destinations of choice
According to the 2021 Hurun Report
column2: Sanya -- a tropical playground on the island of Hainan south of mainland China -- is the most popular destination among wealthy domestic travelers. Often referred to as the ""Hawaii of China""
column3: it's filled with luxury resorts
column4: many managed by international brands.

column1: Ranking second is Yunnan
column2: a mountainous region home to ancient cities
column3: forests and tea plantations.

column1: In Western media
column2: the third and fourth destinations -- Tibet and Xinjiang
column3: respectively -- often make headlines
column4: but it's usually for reasons other than tourism.

column1: Both regions have been under intense international scrutiny due to alleged human rights violations.
The US
column2: along with human rights watch groups and other Western nations
column3: has accused the Chinese government of genocide in Xinjiang and severely restricting freedoms in Tibet. China has denied such allegations.

column1: Both destinations have remained popular among domestic travelers. Xinjiang
column2: in particular
column3: saw an uptick in visitors after brands like H&M and Nike raised concerns about forced labor earlier this year
column4: according to state-run tabloid Global Times.

column1: As a travel destination
column2: Tibet has a well-deserved reputation for breathtaking Himalayan scenery
column3: ancient monasteries and delicious cuisine. And Xinjiang province
column4: China's westernmost territory
column5: is known for its ancient links to the Silk Road trade and Uyghur culture.

column1: Meanwhile Sichuan -- famed for its giant panda sanctuaries
column2: national parks and numbing regional cuisine -- rounds out the top five.

column1: Why these destinations?
They are traditionally popular among Chinese travelers
column2: and the rich outdoor resources have made them even more popular among elite travelers
column3: Mengfan Wang
column4: Dragon Trail's Shanghai-based manager of research
column5: tells CNN Travel.

column1: Outdoorsy experiences and adventure tourism have been key trends within the domestic tourism rebound
column2: she adds.

column1: Rural high-end B&Bs have seen double-digit growth
column2: especially in popular destinations such as Moganshan -- an area of natural beauty close to Shanghai.""

column1: According to Wendy Min
column2: Trip.com Group spokesperson
column3: the group has seen an uptick in bookings for bucket list destinations like Shanghai Disney
column4: Beijing's Forbidden City and The Great Wall of China -- all offering ""easy
column5: convenient travel
column6: great cultural experiences

column1: We've seen increased visitor numbers in places like Guangzhou
column2: Chongqing
column3: Zhuhai
column4: Dunhuang and Quanzhou -- a newly listed UNESCO site -- is no doubt on many travel wishlists
column5: Min tells CNN Travel.

column1: Safety remains paramount
column2: along with can't-miss experiences and attractive scenery that ""lends itself to great photography.""

column1: By land and sea
Wealthy Chinese travelers aren't just choosing their destinations differently -- they're also changing the way they get from point A to B to C.
Driving has become the dominant form of transportation in areas such as Shanghai and Guangdong
column2: says Wang.

column1: Many people will also fly into a top city (like Shanghai) and then take a popular self-driving route in the southwest and northwest regions of China
column2: she adds.

column1: Along the same lines
column2: Wang's colleague Parulis-Cook says young and wealthy Chinese have also been taking road trips in luxury vehicles
column3: renting high-end campervans and glamping at exclusive campgrounds.

column1: This trend is highly influenced by social media and the opportunity to take photos while glamping -- on social media platform Xiaohongshu
column2: for example
column3: users pose with Fendi handbags or Hermes blankets at their campsites
column4: adds Parulis-Cook.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: yachting has become increasingly popular in leisure destinations such as Hainan island -- a longtime favorite among elite Chinese thanks to its duty-free shopping
column3: sandy beaches and lush golf courses.

column1: According to data from the Hainan Free Trade Port
column2: the number of newly registered yachts in Sanya in the first half of 2021 grew 220% year over year.

column1: More travelers are flying solo
Private air travel also appears to be riding a jetstream.
We're seeing a lot of new clients -- maybe they weren't using private jets before COVID-19 because commercial airlines were easy enough. Now
column2: they want to travel privately because it's safer
column3: faster (in terms of waiting for COVID-19 tests)
column4: and you have access to all different airports
column5: says Howard of L'VOYAGE.

column1: We've even seen a lot of growth in terms of clients buying their own planes after chartering a private jet for some time.""
This pattern
column2: she says
column3: reminds her of the industry's momentum after the SARS outbreak in 2003.

column1: At that time
column2: private aviation got a lot of visibility and
column3: again now
column4: we are gaining a lot more awareness.""

column1: And while their core customers in China continue to be business travelers
column2: Howard has also observed a shift in travel habits.

column1: It's often a combination -- for example
column2: our clients may go to Sanya for a business meeting then meet the family for a few days of holiday.""

column1: Craving deeper experiences
When it comes to purely leisure travel
column2: Howard says the company's clientele prefer to explore far-flung locales -- like Yunnan
column3: Tibet or Xinjiang -- that require a more substantial time investment.

column1: When it comes to purely leisure travel
column2: Howard says the company's clientele prefer to explore far-flung locales -- like Yunnan
column3: Tibet or Xinjiang -- that require a more substantial time investment.

column1: Before the pandemic
column2: there were international alternatives because people could go overseas. But now
column3: we are seeing elite travelers choosing destinations with nice clean air
column4: beautiful scenery ... like the beautiful mountains in the Yunnan area.""

column1: You need more than just two to three days in these adventurous places. You need time to explore
column2: go hiking or have cultural experiences.""

column1: No matter where elite Chinese travelers go
column2: Howard says excellent food is a key requirement.

column1: The food element is always very important for our customers because
column2: culturally
column3: the Chinese socialize around the dinner table
column4: she explains.

column1: A place like Sichuan is a good example since it has great food
column2: as well as authentic ways of growing and producing ingredients. So our clients would likely want to visit an organic farm to learn more about how things are grown
column3: get back to nature and enjoy the fresh air.""

column1: Pent-up demand for overseas travel
While high-net-worth travelers have been busy clocking miles within China's borders throughout the pandemic
column2: Dragon Trail says there's plenty of pent-up demand for international trips.

column1: Parulis-Cook expects wealthy and experienced travelers in China to return overseas as soon as it feels safer
column2: more manageable and socially acceptable.

column1: I would say for high-net-worth travelers
column2: where travel is part of their lifestyle
column3: it's much less about having a newfound preference for domestic travel
column4: says Parulis-Cook.

column1: But rather
column2: current restrictions make outbound travel unappealing in many ways. It's not only inconvenient but also looks bad and irresponsible.""

column1: 210;18 of Asia's most underrated places;;2022-12-21 06:45:00;timezone unknown;https://www.cnnphilippines.com:443/lifestyle/2022/12/21/Underrated-travel-spots-Asia-Davao-CNN.html;cnnphilippines.com;For the travelers who are fortunate enough to have time to dig a little bit deeper
column2: there are less-crowded
column3: equally-rewarding treasures to be found. CNN Travel tapped into its network of colleagues and contributors to ask them where the locals go. Here's what they had to say.;"(CNN) — Comprising more than 40 countries
column4: Asia can't be summed up easily.

column1: The classics are classics for a reason — from the awe-inspiring architecture of Angkor Wat and the Taj Mahal to the buzzy metropolises of Tokyo and Hong Kong and the beaches of Bali and Phuket
column2: it's impossible for any traveler to find something not to their liking.

column1: But for the travelers who are fortunate enough to have time to dig a little bit deeper
column2: there are less-crowded
column3: equally-rewarding treasures to be found.

column1: CNN Travel tapped into our network of colleagues and contributors to ask them where the locals go. Here's what they had to say.
Ipoh
column2: Malaysia

column1: When it comes to great Malaysian food cities
column2: most people think of Penang. But that's only because they haven't been to Ipoh.

column1: The capital city of Perak state
column2: Ipoh's location between Kuala Lumpur and Georgetown makes it an ideal stop for any Malaysian road trip. It's also the gateway to Cameron Highlands
column3: a district known for its cool weather and tea plantations.

column1: Ipoh's food and world famous white coffee are enough reasons to visit but there are also magnificent limestone hills and caves that are home to unique temples as well as amazing hidden bars.
Visit the Chinese temples of Perak Tong
column2: Sam Poh Tong and Kek Lok Tong and be blown away by intricate stone carvings and bronze statues of Chinese deities surrounded by stalactites and stalagmites. Ipoh's colonial legacy is also evident in its architecture: from its Railway Station to the Birch Clock Tower
column3: town hall and the Old Post Office.

column1: — Heather Chen
column2: Asia writer

column1: Isaan
column2: Thailand

column1: As popular as Thailand is among international tourists
column2: the country's northeast — collectively referred to as Isaan — is usually overlooked.

column1: But for those in search of a less-traveled destination that includes historic architecture
column2: dramatic landscapes and culinary delights
column3: Isaan ticks all the right boxes
column4: and then some.

column1: Visitors will find it's one of the most welcoming destinations in Asia and easily accessible
column2: thanks to excellent infrastructure that includes several domestic airports offering daily flights to Bangkok and a range of upmarket hotels.

column1: The only challenge is deciding which highlights to experience. Made up of 20 provinces
column2: Isaan shares borders with Laos and Cambodia
column3: and their influences can be found in the region's cuisine
column4: language
column5: historic sites and festivals.

column1: Attractions include the ancient Khmer ruins of Phenom Rung in Buriram
column2: mountainous national parks in Loei
column3: the 75 million-year-old ""Three Whale Rock"" in Bueng Kam and Bronze Age artifacts in the UNESCO-listed Ban Chiang Archeological Site in Udon Thani.

column1: And then there's the food. Isaan cuisine
column2: now prevalent on menus in Thai restaurants around the world
column3: includes refreshing som tom (payaya salad)
column4: tangy Sai Grok Isaan (northeastern sausage) and larb
column5: a flavorful minced-meat salad.

column1: — Karla Cripps
column2: senior producer
column3: CNN Travel

column1: Leshan
column2: China

column1: Most people travel to Leshan city for the sole purpose of visiting the Giant Buddha. The world's biggest and tallest ancient Buddha statue is indeed stunning
column2: but this Sichuan city deserves much more than a side trip from Chengdu.

column1: The Mount Emei scenic area — home to the Giant Buddha — is also of great spiritual and cultural importance as the birthplace of Buddhism in China. Many ancient temples are scattered and ingeniously built on the cliffs of the pristine dense forest.
On top of sightseeing
column2: Leshan is a hidden foodie paradise with local Sichuanese saying ""eating in Sichuan
column3: tasting in Leshan."" This city is where Chengdu residents come for authentic bites of iconic Sichuan cuisine: chilled bobo chicken
column4: jellied tofu
column5: Qiaojiao beef
column6: steamed meat with rice powder and more.

column1: — Serenitie Wang
column2: producer
column3: video programming

column1: Skardu
column2: Pakistan

column1: Skardu district
column2: in Pakistan's Gilit Baltistan region
column3: is a land of stark gigantic beauty
column4: with many of the highest mountains on the planet — most famously K2 — concentrated in this one area.

column1: Deosai National Park sits on the second highest plateau in the world. It is a riot of color
column2: alive with birds and butterflies. With no ambient city lights the stars are exceptionally bright
column3: with the milky way looking so close it could be plucked out from the sky.

column1: In contrast
column2: there's the Sarfaranga Desert. The world's highest cold desert
column3: it's filled with diamond-white sands and ebony mountains.

column1: Skardu has been inhabited for centuries and is studded with ancient Buddhist stupas and carvings
column2: beautifully preserved mosques from the Middle Ages and shrines of Sufi saints.

column1: The Serena hotel chain has transformed the stunning Shigar Fort and Khaplu Palace into two of the country's best kept hotels. Both are filled with gardens and climate friendly wooden architecture while serving regional food like Mamtu dumplings and grilled trout.
— Sophia Saifi
column2: producer
column3: Pakistan

column1: Nikko
column2: Japan

column1: Nikko is just 150 kilometers (93 miles) north of Tokyo
column2: but it feels like another world.

column1: This small city is one of the most important sites in Japan for Shinto culture
column2: with the ornate
column3: gold-dripping Toshogu Shrine — a UNESCO World Heritage site — its centerpiece.

column1: If peace is what you're after
column2: Nikko is the place to find it. Nikko National Park comprises 443 square miles across three prefectures
column3: with dramatic waterfalls
column4: groves of fir and cedar trees
column5: finely carved gates and rocky outcroppings among the things to experience.

column1: The park is also home to some of Japan's famous natural hot springs
column2: making Nikko an ideal autumn or winter destination.

column1: While the area has long been popular with Tokyo urbanites looking for a bucolic weekend escape
column2: Nikko is beginning to land on the radar of more international tourists -- a Ritz Carlton opened there just before the pandemic.

column1: — Lilit Marcus
column2: digital producer
column3: CNN Travel

column1: Dalat
column2: Vietnam

column1: With its fresh mountain air and pine forests in the Central Highlands of Vietnam
column2: Dalat is a popular destination for local Vietnamese that isn't as well known among international travelers.

column1: At 1
column2: 500 meters above sea level
column3: the city's cooler weather is a welcome reprieve from the tropical humidity found elsewhere in the Southeast Asian country.

column1: Centered around the romantic Xuan Huong Lake
column2: Dalat boasts everything from French colonial architecture -- a holdover from its days as a hill station -- to the ""Crazy House
column3: the Seussian creation of architect Đặng Việt Nga
column4: with its twisting stairwells and whimsical sculptures. Plentiful waterfalls and a vibrant flower industry mean that delights abound in the city for honeymooners and nature lovers.

column1: — Dan Tham
column2: producer
column3: Global Features

column1: Davao
column2: Philippines

column1: Davao City is more than just a provincial capital of the southernmost part of the Philippines — it's a true mosaic of Filipino cultures seen nowhere else across the country.
There's food for everybody at the Roxas Night Market
column2: which is lined with barbecue and grilled seafood
column3: along with humble yet complex delicacies such as the fresh seaweed salad called lato and hearty law-uy vegetable soup. Nothing represents Davao more than pungent durians
column4: which grow in abundance across the region as well as pineapples
column5: bananas and sugarcane -- served in all forms from shakes to pies.

column1: The city takes pride in its indigenous roots and celebrates the Kadwayan Festival in August to showcase local textiles
column2: woodwork
column3: song and dance from 11 tribes that reign from the mountains and its surrounding sea.

column1: A ferry ride away from the city will transport you to luxurious Samal Island
column2: best known for its pristine beaches and pearl farms. Take a roadtrip along the palm tree-lined paths that lead to the surfer spot of Mati
column3: or perhaps a detour to Mount Apo
column4: the highest mountain and volcano in the Philippines.

column1: — Kathleen Magramo
column2: breaking news writer

column1: Meghalaya
column2: India

column1: The northeast Indian state of Meghalaya
column2: which translates to ""abode in the clouds
column3: boasts some of the country's most peaceful and lush landscapes. As it requires a permit
column4: it can be challenging to visit. But it's worth it.

column1: Meghalaya is home to the towns of Cherrapunji and Mawlynnong. Both hold records for being the wettest places on Earth
column2: having received nearly 12
column3: 000 mm (472 inches) of rain a year. The results are verdant
column4: leafy forests with rivers and creeks running through that can be explored through crossing the state's famous bridges.

column1: Built by locals out of the roots of ficus trees
column2: some are as old as 500 years and symbolize the self-sufficiency of the Khasi indigenous tribe and their relationship with the forest. The living root bridges
column3: known as ""jingkieng jri"" in the Khasi language
column4: can be found in over 70 villages and continue to be used and nurtured by locals to keep them alive for future generations.

column2: they were added to UNESCO's tentative list of World Heritage sites. The most famous living root bridges are the Umshiang Double Decker root bridge in Nongriat village
column3: south of Cherrapunji
column4: and one in Riwai near Mawlynnong
column5: certified as the ""cleanest village in Asia"" since 2003 by UNESCO.

column1: — Manveena Suri
column2: freelance producer

column1: Palau Ubin
column2: Singapore

column1: Thought Singapore was all about parties and skyscrapers? Think again. Located offshore from its northeast Changi region is Pulau Ubin (Malay for ""granite island"")
column2: a nature lover's paradise with jungle trails
column3: mangrove wetlands and majestic quarries.

column1: Getting around the island is a breeze: In true Singaporean style
column2: everything is well-marked
column3: from jungle trails to concrete footpaths
column4: but the island still remains very untouched.

column1: Mountain biking is particularly popular
column2: especially on weekdays when crowds are few. But Ubin really comes to life on weekends -- when families
column3: couples and nature lovers descend
column4: hoping to catch a glimpse of old Singapore.

column1: One of the most popular attractions on the island is Chek Jawa
column2: a saltwater mangrove wetland rich in marine life. A well-built wooden boardwalk runs through the mangrove
column3: allowing visitors to observe plant and marine life such as sea sponges
column4: octopuses
column5: starfish and cuttlefish
column6: at close range.

column1: — H.C.
Samosir Island
column2: Indonesia

column1: Indonesia is comprised of several thousand islands -- and
column2: in the case of Samosir
column3: an island on a lake within an island.

column1: Samosir Island is a volcanic island in North Sumatra's Lake Toba. one of the world's largest crater lakes.
The Batak tribe calls this land their home
column2: and you can meet these locals as they sell handicrafts from their villages along the waterfront
column3: where their houses are built from wooden beams lashed to stones and have tall red roofs that resemble a ship's sails.

column1: As Samosir is several hours' drive and ferry ride from the closest airport
column2: opt to spend the night in a homestay and support the community by purchasing ulos
column3: a UNESCO-recognized woven
column4: naturally dyed cloth that is used in every important facet of Betak life.

column1: — L.M.
Pakse
column2: Laos

column1: Northern Laos — home to elegant Luang Prabang and adventure-loving Vang Vieng — get the lion's share of attention. But head south for a different kind of experience in Pakse
column2: where two rivers converge in the country's second biggest city.

column1: Pakse is diverse
column2: pulsing and modern. It has buildings left over from the days of French colonialism
column3: but these days Vietnamese and Chinese communities bring their foods
column4: traditions and references alongside the existing Lao presence.

column1: While in town
column2: head up to the giant gold Buddha at Wat Pho Salao
column3: stroll along the Mekong at sunset
column4: and then go off to the Bolaven Plateau to get deeper into jungle.

column1: — L.M.
Bangladesh
India casts a long tourism shadow over its neighbors
column2: including Bangladesh. But this smaller nation has outsized offerings many travelers to South Asia might not realize. This is especially true in architecture
column3: history
column4: nature and food.

column1: In the capital of Dhaka
column2: the Ahsan Manzil is an ornate
column3: stunning vision in pink. Set on the banks of the Buriganga River
column4: it was finished in 1872 during the British colonial era as a palace for the local rulers of the time. It is now a popular museum.

column1: For a sample of Mughal Empire architectural splendor
column2: check out the incomplete Lalbagh Fort.

column1: And if you'd like to visit a mosque
column2: consider the exquisite Star Mosque (Tara Masjid)
column3: renowned for hundreds of blue stars on its gleaming white domes.

column1: — Forrest Brown
column2: freelance writer and producer

column1: Tengchong
column2: China

column1: Even though China is still closed to international tourists
column2: Yunnan province has already welcomed about 350 million domestic visitors in the first half of 2022 alone.

column1: If you'd like to see the historical Yunnan like an experienced local
column2: head to Tengchong.

column1: Bordering Myanmar in the west of Yunnan
column2: Tengchong has been a critical trading stop on the historic Silk Route and Tea Horse Road in the past.

column1: Today
column2: many local travelers first visit Heshun
column3: an old town built surrounding a mountain and a lake. The Double Rainbow stone arch bridges
column4: the Laundry Pavilion and the 98-year-old Heshun Library -- the biggest rural public library in China -- are some of the must-sees when visiting the cozy village.

column1: Yinxing (Gingko) Village in the northern side of Tengchong is known for its thousands of ginkgo trees
column2: turning the village golden yellow every autumn.

column1: — Maggie Hiufu Wong
column2: freelance CNN Travel writer

column1: Gogunsan Islands
column2: South Korea

column1: The Gogunsan islands — meaning ""an archipelago of mountains"" in Korean — have been a popular summer destination for locals seeking a break from city life.
A group of 63 islands on South Korea's west coast
column2: the islands offer a picturesque view of verdant hills scattered amid gentle waters.

column1: The world's longest seawall and a series of bridges connect the islands to the mainland
